post:
I rented skis for the whole season from pro ski in Thalwil.  That allowed me to try out 3 different skis for at least a few weeks each. ( I think you are allowed to change only once, but the second time I changed it was already towards the end of season so they let me have a pair which was just returned) When I thought I had a good idea of the type of skis I would like, I looked out for sales on specific skis around the end of last season.       
Found my blizzard Brahmas previous-season model here for 50% off, free delivery, zero German VAT,  but needed to add the usual swiss tax and admin charges on top. Great service.            
So I rented and tested the skis at probably less than 50% the cost of new skis, then bought the skis at also 50% off, I think overall it was a good move!      
In terms of bindings, the only thing you want to look at if you are buying wider skis is to match the width of the bindings.  I got the marker griffon which looks too wide for race skis but matches mine perfectly.

Squats and deadlifts - two best full compound exercises out there. In last 5 years I've not come even close to anything as comprehensive as these guys. These alone are good enough for me to have a gym membership (plus treadmill for those crappy rainy winterish days)   
Other great excercises - variations of pullups. Some lucky people can mount constructions on doors, but in all of my Swiss rentals (5 of them), I've never had a door frame that would support one of these, so gym (or some parks) are the only option.
To add to my original post, I'm 70 kg and want to find someone to climb with starting now till Jan 14.
I do too. Especially when they deliver quickly in crap weather, and when our lift is out. Again!

Check out reddit r/crossfit for a lot more candid discussion about CrossFit itself.     
I did CF for about five years quite intensively, even did some qualifications and coached a bit.  Like any high intensity training/workout you need to take some ownership for how hard and far you push yourself. My own experience was no more injuries than from running, skiing or football.   
Also, you have to understand that CrossFit is a loose affiliation system, not a franchise, so "boxes" vary greatly in quality.  However, both of the Meilen operations are run by serious and experienced owners.   
Try it out...

Mild steel? Oily rag? Have I wandered into a post on steam locomotives? I can't think of any moving parts on brake components that require lubrication and as a rule of thumb, I wouldn't go anywhere near the brakes with lubricant. Any areas that do need lubrication should not be lubricated with WD40, as this will just attract grime, which will aid the wear process on moving parts. (Use a silicone based lubricant or any specialised lubricant)      Dirt often gets ingrained into the lubricant and if not properly removed will wear those components. Regarding any acid based degreaser, this can strip all protection leaving components/areas of components accessible to the elements

Kind of a late update to this situation but I figured I'd post it in case anyone else is curious. I bought a half-fare subscription and they provided me with a SwissPass with the half-fare loaded onto it. Later in the week Saas-Fee sent me an email to finalize my ski pass and on their webpage I was able to enter my SwissPass card number so that the ski pass was on my SwissPass. At Saas-Fee you just hold your SwissPass up to the sensor and the gate opens up so you can go through. Simple and easy

There are two girls hockey teams in Geneva - Servette and Meyrin.  Both are registered with the Swiss National League C.  My daughters play for Servette and this is their first year in the league. There are also a number of club teams, but these teams are only active during the winter and play on outdoor half ice. There are a number of other girls teams in Lausanne, Morges, Neuchâtel, and number of other towns in Canton Vaud.

If you are having any health issues like insommia, fatique,  arthritis, asthma, depression, etc. try Qi Gong. Qigong (pronounced  -gong)  is an ancient Chinese exercise  and healing technique that involves  meditation, controlled breathing and  movement exercises.     
 I have arthritis with some joint pains. I have been doing some  exercises thanks to my husband's training. Doing regularly Qi Gong just  for a few weeks has already eased the stiffness and pain significantly. I also feel energized.   My husband took a two days course in Qi Gong last year in Sion, Valais  with Master Ligin Yang (7dan). My husband was suffering from left shoulder  pain due to heavy weight lifting. He applied the exercises he learned  from Master Ligin and not long after his injured shoulder was healed.    
On Nov. 19th and 20th the same master will be giving a course for two  days in Neuchâtel. If you are interested to take the course check under  the category "events" in the English Forum and click on commercial  events then you will see Qi Gong for Health. Click on that and you will  have all the information and details on the Qi Gong course. You will  definitely benefit from it! If you want more information or details go  to Google or Youtube. You will see some video demonstrations.

Check out this post  . myClubs offers a monthly flat rate so you can train at many different places and do sports every day if you like. You can visit each partner up to 4 times per month but if you want some variety and not always to go to the same place you may like to try it. It is not just gyms though - it is also yoga, crossfit, TRX, Power plate, EMS, Bootcamp, spinning etc. There are 67 partners in the Zurich partner network to choose from. As an example you could in 1 month get 4 day passes at Luxor gym near Paradeplatz and 4 day passes at Airport Fitness, do 4 classes at Balboa, 4 classes at Velocity, 4 classes at Atomix and additionally 2 times EMS and 2 times Power plate.

post: Was just going to mention Medlake too, but I've been beaten to it. It's really handy to use in all weathers if you don't drive, because you just get off the train at Goldbach station, take the platform level walkway into the Goldbach building and get the lift down to ground level.

The new   prices have been published. There are no new resorts for 2016/7 although les Portes du Soleil is back after a one year absence. Toggenburg, Hoch-Ybrig and Val DAnniviers have fallen off the scheme, sadly, and a couple of minor resorts are now only listed online.   
Adelboden, the 4 Vallées, Saas-Fee and many Graubünden resorts have seen hikes around 10%, partly down to increased rail fares and partly increases in lift pass prices. However Zermatt has kept ski pass price flat, as have a number of other resorts, including Les Diablerets, Leysin, Villars, Grindelwald, Wengen, Mürren, Gstaad, Meiringen, Sörenberg, Melchsee-Frutt, Klewenalp, Airolo and Stoos. Although some rail tickets have gone up, some routes from Luzern to local resorts have fallen slightly.

Everything is expensive here, including plastic surgery, but it's not insanely more than in comparable countries. I have many friends who have had minor to major surgeries here and in London, NY and LA and the amounts spent are not so far off.    
I think the thing to remember is that we not judge one another. (or make jokes at the expense of others.) while I think we can all agree that it would be wonderful to live in a world where the media and society did not demand our perfection and self-objectification, this is our reality and we must each determine what is best for us and what makes feel good about living in our own skins.    
Life is hard enough without the constant (and unfounded) judgement of others.    
Best of luck to you.

Back to this old post - can someone recommend a good swimming teacher for my son (7).    
I am amazed by the way locals handle swimming lessons here - they take it so easy and slowly... My son has been attending for 2 years now some local swimming lessons ina small group to cover the basic 'local' levels (1 to 7), and for 2 years they've been 'getting used to the water' (what you learn for the first 2-3 days in a normal swimming training school) which I find an outrageous loss of time. post: Corrected age. 34 years

No worthwhile information can be obtained at this early of a date. There is only one trend that you can count on and that is to not expect much good snow early season anymore. Treat any good snow before New Years as a bonus. There will almost always be storms that dump some snow somewhere in the Alps starting from now but you can't reliably predict where it will be. Plus, if you get a big dump in early December in Davos (or anywhere), you can count on that being quickly followed by a rain event up high or a foehn storm for a few days that will completely ruin that snow.    
The odds are that the glaciers will be fine for skiing in mid-December and it's quite probable that you can ski to the valley floor somewhere in the Alps as well. I wouldn't book a long weekend at one place expecting good snow though. As is said every year, availability is not an issue so just book a few days before you leave.

post:
Davos Dorg Train station    XC (July - October)    4 29Km may not sound much but 1400hm is...    4 (some tricky rock sections and switchbacks on descent, some tricky climbing).   
Start out from Davos dorf by heading into town, round the one way sytem and turning left at the EGG bar into Dischmastrasse. Folow this to the start of the valley where you go past the Lumber yard, then turn left to In den Bulen. the trail is now sign posted.   
After the climb (av 12%), the trail darts through to the Fluela valley by a short section of single track, leading to a fireroad. Then the trail heads up parallel with the river all the way to the Geust House at Tschuggen, good climb (ave 8%) but not technical.   
Now begins the real ascent. At Tschuggen the trail leads through the guest houes garden past the little church. It is pretty hard going (ave 12%) with rocks and switchbacks to contend with until it hits a wider path around 2200hm   
Once past the Pischa Berg station you follow nice rolling (and rocky) single track to the Horli where the trail cross the ridge and starts descending. At the top before the descent is a nice bench if like me you want to put some pads on and have lunch.   
The descent is I think tricky with loose rocks, loose dirt and switchbacks, no jumping required though. Half way down you will be treaded to the most fabulous view of Davos the Parsenn and Klosters and a 180 degree panoramma. The best view of this area I've seen.   
After the view point the trail got harder for me as it was quite overgrown and became a foot wide and about 1/2 foot sunken, made some corners hard. also hit my head on a few branches. Became quite hard to see more than a couple of meters of the actual trail.   
The end of the trail was a nice fast run through some easy single track before coming onto a farmers 4x4 road, across the railwayline, round the lake and back to Davos Dorf.     
This trail was about as much as I could handle, in fact slightly more, I could do maybe 75% of the climb and 80% of the downhill. I consider my self an XC rider of average ablity and fitness.    
However I'm very glad I did it, it's 80% singletrail and I only saw 5 people during the entire ride. Plus the view of Davos - wow!   
I also had an endo near the end due to a rather large hole / rock combo that I just didn't see - wouldn't have been so bad if I hadn't been slowing down to give way to two hikers, who, by the way, didn't stop or ask if I was ok as I lay sprawled across the track - they just stepped round me.....

I think I have already mentioned in older threads:       
They ship DHL by default (which is actually a Deutsche Post), with pretty fast delivery (BD usually in 3-4 days), and customs is only 8% VAT (after they subtract German VAT automatically) and this you can pay to DHL online, in case you were not at home during delivery. Oh, and the most important - many items are much cheaper than bikester (which is a special rip off if you use their Swiss site unless there is some special sale).

Supplements are really expensive in Switzerland, even when bought on the internet. I first started like that after discovering how easy it was to order from the US, I haven't even thought of buying here again.    
My favorite shop is iHerb. They have a really excellent choice of products, great prices and best of all free shipping to Switzerland for orders over 60$ and 4$ otherwise! The trick is to keep the orders just over 60$. I've never paid taxes after more than 20 orders (66CHF is the official limit but iHerb generally indicates a lower value than what you have paid). But if you wan't to play it sure, you can pay the 4$ shipping and order less. And if you are in a hurry and want to be able to track your shipping, you get good prices with DHL (the free/4$ can be slow sometimes, but 100% reliable for me until now at least). You have to be even more careful with DHL with the customs, because they charge you higher fees for administrative costs than the Swiss post. For a 5$ discount on your first order, you can use the following code: PEK942.   
I've never had any problems with customs due to what I've ordered, it seems Switzerland is pretty easy on this. I don't think iHerb sells much that would be illegal here, which is not the case in Finland where even over 400IU of vitamin D would be stopped by customs (I luckily saw that before ordering for my parents there).   
As for protein, Country Life BioChem and Jarrow Formulas are great for Whey. They have a good selection of non-dairy protein too, but they mostly taste quite bad if not mixed in a smoothie or so. The best I have found is Nutribiotic Vanilla. Jarrow Formulas is ok for smoothies (especially putting a banana helps a lot with the flavor).   
Hope this helps!

The search function one way to find previous threads with similar topics.

post: I agree with Assassin above. Don't assume you need knee support before examining the knee itself and running style. I ruptured my ligaments years ago and assumed i NEED knee support. Have been running half-marathons and squatting with heavy weights since then with no knee pain.

but be careful not to get tangled in the rope..

For Fitnesspark, it depends ln whether you want to take classes or only use the gym. They usually have a campaign in the summer. The full package is 1,340.00. Expensive, but some complementary insurance cover part of it. I'm very happy with them, been there 2 years. It includes 5 sessions with a personal trainer to review your program. I've had one ok session and 2 excellent sessions.     
Active fitness is cheaper, I was there one year but then we moved and it wasn't convenient anymore. No PT included, they prepare a program at the beginning but it's kuch less personalised. But the one I went to was nice, however it got a bit more cramped at times than the Fitnesspark I go to now.     
Both offer daycare, but only in the morning on weekdays.

You are probably better off using one of the forums dedicated to mountain bikes to explore your product choices.   
There are numerous ways to purchase bikes - direct online sales (Rose, Canyon, YT, and more in Germany and the UK, for instance), online sales (plenty of shops around), local bike shop.   
And then you have used bikes, e.g. on Ricardo.ch, tutti.ch, velomarkt.ch, traildevils.ch to list only the largest _Swiss_ sites.   
Simply make up your mind what attributes you want, who delivers, then go shopping

Or just walk and then hike. You can start that immediately and will be able do it much longer than running at first. It will burn a shitload of kcal if you are carrying around extra kg.  It will get your joints well used to jogging/running in due course.   
Yes you cannot just exercise your way to thin, diet is key.  But walking 60mins a day will burn 500kcal a day easily at your weight, and that is 1kg every two weeks... or 25kg in a year, or half your goal (as long as you control the kcal you eat).  That will be much healthier than cutting 500kcal extra from your food.   
As for heart risks of endurance running, unless you have an anomaly, that is risk for people who do massive mileages and/or aim for very fast times.   
But with 60kg to lose, please do that with medical supervision.

post: send me a pm

i have 2 29ers and a monster surly 'cross set up. i drank the cool-aid years ago and haven't looked back. up front--you may not need to get a full suspension 29inch to enjoy big wheels. nice but not needed like you would need them on a 26. spend that extra cash on a nice fox fork for up front.    
those big wheels eat so much of the trail chatter that i prefer a 29er hardtail any day over a FS even if it was the same price. I'm also riding a Salsa El Mariachi full rigid single speed as my main steed so take my opinion for what it's worth. but a nice steel frame, good tires and a good fork up front will make it feel like you have a full suspension with all the pedaling efficiency. really!   
You have to test ride these puppies to see if it's your cup of tea. For the most part, to me at least, if you're on really tight trails with a lot of technical turns, etc.--26er might make more sense. they're more nimble some would say, all things considered. while 29er may be a bit sluggish or slow in turning, i also feel that because of those wheels, you choose routes differently and ride differently to a certain degree. as for roots, rocks, etc... it's night and day the roll you get with big wheels. climbing, you may lose traction if you're up front the whole time, but downhills are brilliant on 29ers! i don't see the disadvantages in the setup, just focus on the pros of big wheels.    
i personally wouldn't use the person's size argument for whether to go big wheels or not. i know people close to 7' tall who still like 26 wheels. I'm 5'8 and run big wheels without a problem. it's about the ride quality, not your size, although some would disagree i'm sure.    
ultimately, the best bike is the one you have most fun on--whether it's a schwinn beater or a fancy carbon frame. try one out, you may just have  the time of your life.
There are a number of different 1275 tunes - the Kestrel IIRC was a pretty hot one - but they are massively tuneable. (Based on what my dad used to do with them anyway.)

As far as apps go GPS-Tracks.com is the best free app.  If you register (free) you can download and export all the gps tracks to your garmin or just overlay them on your phone.  And they have tons of tours here in CH, probably because its the most popular app here.  Every single Swiss that I've ever ridden with has this app including all my friends so they seem to have the biggest data base for trails.  All my expat friends tend to use different apps.  When in Rome.... 
Now regarding the Etrex 35,  its a small unit,  a bit smaller than I thought. But I didnt want a larger screen as that reduces the battery time. Plus I only need it when I'm on a new trail and need to know which way to go when I come to a fork in the trail.  Its not like I'm going to be looking at it as I'm riding.  Thats like texting and driving.     I find it easier to plan the routes in basecamp and just load it on to the device.  Its too cumbersome to do that on the device with the smaller screen.

Its also important to consider how the SAC compiles the above statistics: Only people killed during sport are counted. If a person dies in an avalanche in a car while driving to a ski resort this accident isnt included. But if the same person dies one hour later in an avalanche sitting on a sledge drinking a Rivella  J  it makes it into the SAC numbers.       Therefore the SAC figures do just give an idea but should not be considered perfect. For mountain climbing they are probably fairly accurate while other alpine sports are not covered as well as those activities are not what SAC members are mainly interested in doing.

I'm a decent skier, not amazing, but there really isn't a piste I can't tackle. In CH, when I go off-piste, I always go with a guide. It is pricey, but the piece of mind is well worth it. Usually we go to a normal resort where we meet the guide, they'll usually take us to find powder within the range of the lifts, or with a short walk or trek. I find that most resorts know of the off piste within their area and do make an effort to have it relatively safe---but they always stress, they are not monitored.     
When I was younger riding back-country in BC and Alberta, I never imagined about getting a guide, the increased risk is that in Western Canada---if you make a bad turn, you could be lost for weeks! Here in CH it's not as likely to get lost :P

Ok, so that's really very small climbs, compared to Alpenbrevet. For example, Grimsel alone is 1500m of climbing, all be it over 26kms. For me, that's 1hr 30 to 2hrs. Nufenen is around 1100m over 13kms. Gotthard 12.5kms and 870m. Then to finish off, Susten is another long one, 20kms, 1200m.   
If you're going for gold, you really need to know if you can several long climbs in one day. But first, you really need to try just one climb aroudn 1000m. Or start off with something like Sattelegg,  with is 720m over 11.5kms from Siebnen.   
And as someone else said, 34x32!!

The problem is, swimwear needs to be fairly tight, or once in the water it creates drag and may also sag or come loose causing an embarrassing situation.   
If she can't get off a one-piece, or deal with any fasteners, I don't think there is any other option....   
.... apart from a helper. I appreciate that people with disabilities want to be independent, but even Paralympians need help, Para-Triathletes have to be carried from the water and helped with their wetsuits. I think the focus should be on finding someone who can go regularly to the pool with her and help her, rather than finding a swimsuit.    
Maybe look into disability swimming/sport associations, I'm not sure what exists in Switzerland. Or maybe just find a volunteer.

I'm a member of the Uto section which is the bigger section, has a few thousands members. Lots of activities, but the number of participants is limited per activity, so there's some competition about getting a place on a tour.    
Most members are Swiss and German, a few internationals here and there. You will def. meet them, and will be awed by the Swiss Alpine training and fitness.    
For me understanding the Swiss German is not easy, and most tour leaders try to speak Hochdeutsch, but social chatter is going to be in Swiss German.    
Most tour are free, and the leader gets 5CHF / participant. You nee to pay for your own transport. Extra costs are specified in the tour description. This is Uto specific, other Sections have other structure.
That's true. Once the kids are 10 years old, it's pretty difficult to tell who started at 3 and who started at 6, apart from the kids who are born in the mountain and ski a lot during a winter.

Hi - I got this helpful information from Flumserberg   
We have a small and a big point card. The small one kost CHF 36.00, the big one CHF 90.00. Each point card has 30 points on it and is valid on this lifts :   
small Point Card   
B2       Chrüz                          7 points per ride 
D2       Schwammkopf          3 points per ride 
D4       Mittenwald                  3 points per ride 
D1       Tannenboden             2 points per ride 
D3       Madils                         2 points per ride   
big Point Card   
C1       Prodalp Express         3 points per ride 
C2       Prodkamm                 3 points per ride

post:
Alright, I read a lot of reviews, asked everyone I know and finally bit the bullet and bought a Tacx Vortex Smart T2180.   
Its hard to get a lot out of reviews, as its usually by someone who bought it, so its not comparative with what else is out there (although some people will compare their new trainer to their old outdated one), and is often tainted by a lack of objectivity, their first impressions, or a negative impression which might be unrepresentative.   
Anyway, I have found a reviewer who stands out, he is called DC Rainmaker and is an IT guy who is also a very keen cyclist - extremely thorough and readable and comprehensive in his tests and reviews. He actually uses each piece of equipment before reviewing it, so it experience based. And unbiased.     
Apps. There is a sudden explosion of virtual reality apps now, as some like tacx have gone open source, and i found the choices boggling, but the top 3 - and each has free trial period - zwift, veloreality (vride) and kinomap.

post: I have a SUP and in case you have never seen one from up close: they are huge. Much bigger than a surf board and even bigger than a beginners windsurf board. Mine is over ten foot... and I think that's unpractical to carry around in Seefeld (but probably something a hipster might do...). Some people swear by the new inflatable type as you can carry it around in a backpack and I see the point, but for me personally does a board need to be a board. A good one with paddle will cost at least 1000 CHF... so better rent and try it out before you invest into a hobby you don't enjoy in the end.

the keratin treatment is something done at the hairdresser.  They apply some gloop, straighten the hair, wash it, more gloop, more straightening, another wash.  errr.....does it show that I don't pay any attention    Takes a while and is boring.  But saves so much time at home, that I'm happy to pay the price in time and money one Saturday afternoon 3 times a year   
I've had it done twice now, the results last about 4-5 months on my hair, and make it way way easier to style.  I was sceptical  before trying, but  it's a must-do for me now.   
I have it done here (no connection other than as a customer)...the description is "Keratin Glaettung".  It does not use Formaldehyde.  I don't know much about hair (as you can read!) but it looks that formaldehyde is bad for hair.

I know lots of smaller providers that offer drop in classes. They often give much better and more flexible offers than the bigger gym chains like Holmes Place. Boot camp, metafit, pilates, barre concept, and various other kinds of fitness classes are all possible as drop in classes at the providers I work with. I work with No Excuses (bootcamp and metafit), Ghetto Gym (many different types of fitness classes incl Cross Yoga and Ghetto Parcours), Strictly Fitter (Barre Concept and Pilates) and others. PM me if you want to know more. If you can find a group of people interested in doing Metafit classes on Tuesday or Thursday mornings from 7.30 to 8am at Hallenbad City then I can probably get you a good deal. The usual price is 20CHF (excluding Hallenbad entry) but if there are a group of you this might be able to be negotiated as the room has a massive capacity.

Have a look at Ski Rental Zurich     
They provide great service (in English), you can rent new/used equipment and can buy at end of the season (rental fee is then discounted!).  A good way to test before you buy...

Hello all, 
probably the nature of football-posts here is more "casual" and one-off, but I though I might share our efforts here as well, since I guess there could be some ex-pats interested! (FYI, I am only coaching there, not playing)   
It is in general greek-community based, but one could find swiss, italians etc in the team. Trainings are in a mix of languages (football doesn't need a language) and we can definitely offer a great ambiance, passion, a slight different environment from a regular "swiss" team.   
This year the clear aim is promotion, there is a serious new start going on, and we would welcome anyone that can play and take part in this!! Just as an appetizer, we won (with only 11 players and no player on the bench) our first game, cup match (one off), against a higher-division team. It is going to be a great year, and anyone to contribute would be very welcome!

There is also the car share service :   . I saw there are trips offered Geneva to Morzine cheaply most days. Although you might also have trouble with the bike but you can easily rent one up there.   
Cheers   
Sam

Hi all, 
Lets make a list of all the public places where one can spend a Sunday  tanning/swimming generally enjoying themselves during this heatwave.   
the park on the right side of the lake 
Arboretum, Mythenquai, 8002 Zürich, Switzerland 
Really nice to tan, however very crowded. Also access to the lake for swimming is limited.   
Seebad Utoquai 
The left hand side of the lake. Less crowded, and a great swimming spot.    
The river close to Hardbrucke 
Kloster Fahr-Weg, 8037 Zürich, Switzerland 
Great tanning spot. 2 bus stations away from Hardbrucke. Swimming not encouraged due to strong current of the river.     
Those are my contributions. As I explore Zurich I will add more...

post: My husband swam across the lake last year from Lausanne to near Evian and he had to get permission from the lake border police because of crossing one country into another - they were very nice and wrote him a letter no problem.

Your best bet is probably to join a shooting club, there are oodles in Zurich city, probably more than one close to you.    is grouped by shooting range on city ground, try google or tel.search.ch (phone register) if URL is missing.    
Finding a club with an english speaking instructur/tutor shouldn't be that much of a problem, and if you understand some german you should be fine. I'd expect for clubs even today to provide the training weapon (probably can't be taken home though) if needed. Back in the day I did a training on the swiss army rifle as a 15-year  old, the gun was provided by the shooting club.   
The bonus: 
You also get to know people from your area with at least  one  common  interest, a good starting point if you want to find  friends. Chances are many pro-gun people are also pro-US.   
I think you need a C residence permit in order to get a license to buy a gun, club members will know with certainty. Being a shooting club member, perhaps with a couple/few years  membership, will definitely help getting a purchase license as club board  members can be expected to act as reference, and probably will do so  gladly.    
I would expect for you to be admissible in most clubs, though perhaps not all, each club defines its own admission rules.   explicitly says every person above 10 year age can join, while another says the kantonal military commission must give the OK for foreigners (which I'd guess is just a formality if you have C permit and a clean criminal record). Additional conditions, if any, are on the level of "should be a good sport and must be careful with the weapon".

For trainings are plastic studs much more confortable. Alu studs are good for competitions, Meles, you have more force but they are not so confortable... I would really need both later but I prefer to start with the confortable ones. :-)   
Round plastic studs. I think I will find this type in normal soccer shoes.

This is propably the best website I've found for plotting biking and running routes.  . You can simply plan your own route, or let it do it for you and is particularly good if you want to plan a pre-determined distance. You can then save (with a login) or download the route to load onto your favourite GPS device.  
The auto-planner is not so good for XC routes, which is where the self-planning comes in nicely. I used to use Bikemap.net, but this is far superior I reckon.

Ok, so I spent a fair amount of time searching to find this information so I thought I may as well share it.     
The best gauge near Basel is at Rheinhalle:       
This is above the Birsfelden dam, so it may not be reflective of water levels in Basel for swimming/paddling. However, it provides water flows in-addition to water level. Note that the Swiss decided to report water level as meters above sea level, which is very helpful considering how close Switzerland is to the sea. If you click the "Station Data" tap you will see the reference height of the gauge, you have to subtract that value from the graphs to get the actual water level. Unfortunately they didn't provide a red-line or other guide for the eye on the graphs so it's relatively tricky to guess the water velocity.     
The gauge in Basel-proper has just water level:       
and the water temperature (and quality) is availabe from the Weil station on the German border:       
For completeness, here is the Birs, which is a little class 2- whitewater (wildwasser) river that dumps into the Rhein.         
Note that the Birs is polluted and not suitable for swimming. It has some little drops and hydraulics as it nears the Rhein, and when it's in flood it has some fairly beefy surf waves.

I was a member of ActivFitness for a year. It's a chain with locations randomly scattered all over Switzerland, and you can access any gym without any additional cost. Price-wise it's one of the cheaper chains, but the facilities were always clean and well maintained. An Abo for a year is around 750 CHF (if I remember correctly), which is a few hundred cheaper than MigroFit or ActiveFitness, for example.    
I used the one in Oerlikon a few times. It's in the new UBS building, on the two top floors. Never too full, and a rather OK selection of machines. I'm sure you can do a test training for free the first time to see if it fits your personal program    
I have nothing negative to say about ActivFitness and would still be using it but it doesn't make logistically sense anymore since I moved and no longer have one easily accessible between home and work.    
Good luck!

The only one I know offering monthly pay options is FitMade near Claraplatz, they are a reasonably priced gym but of course charge more if you're only signing up on a monthly basis, I think it is 90 chf for the month!

I get a lot of bike stuff from Wiggle, including a couple of bikes over the last few years. They deduct UK VAT at their end, but you are responsible for Swiss VAT when it arrives here plus import charges. This is normally 8% of the cost, plus about CHF20-40 for the courriers charges. If it is a small parcel it comes with the Post, and you have to be the tax on delivery. Larger parcels come with DHL and you get a bill from them a week or so after delivery.   
Given the crazy shop prices here, as long as you are spending roughly GBP 150 or more you should be comfortably saving money.

Since it's the spring time, and many are getting bikes out of storage, do note this recall on any Trek mountain bikes with disc brakes sold between 1999 and now.       
Apparently the quick release can over open, and get stuck in the disc causing serious consequences.   
Personally I don't ride Treks  ( ) but my SO has two that we needed to check out.    
Free fix and 'sorry' gift certificate.   
Ride safe!

I've also had a great experience with the Montrail Mountain Masochist. I tested out at least 8 brands/models for UTMB before arriving on the Masochists. Excellent grip in all conditions and very comfortable even late in a long run. For muddy and winter runs, I've enjoyed the La Sportiva Crosslite (great lugs and stability). I'm not so fond of the Crosslites for really long runs though. I ordered my Montrails from the States at shoes.com. Even with the shipping charges, the price was half what it was when I could find the shoes in Switzerland or Chamonix.       I've tried out various slip-on spikes and landed on Kahtoola's micro spikes.   Excellent for snow and ice running. They never fall off (unlike all the others I tested) and they are perfect for variable winter conditions (excellent grip without getting in the way of running). I throw them in my backpack for winter runs along the Albis Ridge and just pull them on once I hit the snowy/icy parts of the trail. The only downside is that you can't just head out the door in them (to run on the non-snowy bits on the way to the hills). With some of the other slip-on spikes (more designed for walking to the train than winter trail running) and some of the shoes with built-in spikes, you could actually run on them even when not on the snow. It's never been a problem for me though because I do all my winter trail runs with a backpack.

An LCHF diet means you eat fewer  carbohydrates and a higher proportion of fat. Most importantly you  minimize your intake of sugar and starches. You can eat other delicious  foods until you are satisfied – and still lose weight. 
A number of recent high-quality   and to control your  . And that’s just the beginning.       Eat when you’re hungry until you are satisfied. It’s that simple.   You do  need to count calories or weigh your food. And just forget about industrially produced low fat products.

post: I joined Sihouette in Bellevue over a month ago and am very satisfied. There's no wait time for machines, even during evenings on weekdays. The machines are well maintained, there's enough room for floor exercises, and you're never waiting for a particular set of free weights. They also have a sauna room that I have yet to try out, and more than enough showers, hair dryers, etc. The only downside is that the gym opens laterish in the morning, so I had to say goodbye to my early morning workout plans. Overall, for the price you're paying the services and amenities are pretty good.

post:
I have found no "lost & found" forum, so am posting this here as a "best guess", but am happy to move it if required.   
On Monday evening, 16th March, at 18:15, I unintentionally left my ski boots on the Zürich-bound train platform (platform 2) at Unterterzen, the SBB train stop that serves Flumserberg. I went back yesterday in the hope of retrieving them, but they were no longer on the platform, nor had they been handed to the ticket office at the bottom of the Flumserberg ski lift, nor to the Heidiland office next to the SBB station. I filed a lost property report with SBB, but nothing has been handed in as yet.   
The boots were Salomon brand, approximately 2008 model, size approximately 44-45 (or at least, that is my normal shoe size), burgundy red and black in colour, with four clasps, a velcro strap above the uppermost clasp, a carrying handle on the top of each tongue, and moulding foot inserts with the word Comfort fit at the top. I do not know the exact model number, but the attached photo is of a very similar boot.   
I broke my hand a couple of months ago, and had only just been able to start skiing again, so any assistance that anyone might be able to give me in getting my boots back to their rightful owner would be very much appreciated.   
Many thanks, 
Martin Reed

Regarding your question about hiring, this means that you can rent the skis for the entire season, for example, pick it up from the shop in December and use them the full season and return around March/April (exact dates depend on the shop I guess). Good luck!

post: Crans-Montana  Tourisme & Congrès (CMTC) proposes a spectacular marketing campaign  this winter: an exceptional offer made possible thanks to the hoteliers  of the station, several apartment rental agencies, the  Crans-Montana-Aminona (CMA) ski lifts society, and the Association of  Six Communes of Crans-Montana (ACCM).     This offer, intended to boost the end of the winter season 2015, has been baptised    «Ski for free».  It is intended as an invitation to reserve a stay in one of the partner hotels, and receive as a present a ski pass. An offer valid from 15 March to 19 April 2015 for every stay in one of the partner hotels.    The  principle is simple: one night spent in one of the partner hotels  entitles the hotel guest to one day of skiing offered. The offer is  subject to a skiable area being open.    For information and reservations go to  http://www.crans-montana.ch/hiver/en/skiforfree
thread: PSA: free lift pass in Crans Montana.

post:
Hi All,    
Last summer something quite unique (for me at least) happened to me.  
I woke up on Saturday morning in mid-June to find that my cellar (and we live in a big apartment block) had been emptied of all the high end bikes.    
Some other people lost bits and pieces, I lost a top of the line BMC racing bike, and two custom Intense MTBs. I'd only just finished putting the final touched to the BMC and then it was away....Never to be seen again.    
Anyway, long story short, it took till September to finally get the insurance money and then the road season was pretty much over.    
However now with the weather warming up again, I visited my local BMC shop - Squadra Mondo in Altendorf, (who have been excellent and very supportive during the insurance process - they gave me a loaner in June, which I still have) and ordered a new road bike.    
Ok, we are now coming to the point of this thread (and hence the reason for the title).    
To finish it off nicely, I wanted a set of carbon wheels for my new BMC, and have decided on Enve 6.7s.  
Checking around the web for prices and availability, there were lots available in the US (they are handmade in Utah) and the UK (I previously bought them from Evans), plus a handful in Germany. Thinking a European warranty may be easier, I looked into a few of the German ones.    
All much of a muchness, apart from Toms Bike Corner ( ), which caught my eye....most items in stock, or available quickly and very competitive prices. I also noticed a remark - call for the latest day prices on these items....so I did. 
I dropped Tom a mail with my requirements (and a couple of questions on hub choices). I received a response with an hour with some clear answers. Based on this, I made my choice and asked about the special price of the day. Well Tom looked after me, and I ended up paying below their website cost, and not just for that he gave me discount on a bunch of other components as well.    
Fast and friendly service (he actually wrote me back in English and dealt in that language too) great selection of products and fantastic prices. What more can you ask for?   
Prices before the CHF/Euro thing here were competitive, now they are simply great. I couldnt recommend Toms place enough. If youre thinking of buying some shiny carbon (well actually most of it is matt.) or other toys, its worth dropping an email to Tom for a price. Im very glad I did.    
Just to make this very clear, Im not getting anything out of saying good things about Tom, just looking to help out fellow cyclists/bikers with a great find I came across.   
Now I just need to wait for my parts to arrive!

post:
Before this one, I had an rcx3 from Polar which I lost  . I had used the rcx3 for over 9 months and it was pretty simple and easy to use.    
The box comes with  
- The rcx5 watch 
- WearLink+ Hybrid strap for monitoring the heart rate 
- G5 gps with a strap holder 
- Datalink USB stick   
With the datalink you can upload your workouts on the polarfitness website. With the GPS you can check out the map of your run or bike route. It also gives a gazillion other info about heart rate, calories etc etc. I am just a beginner in this area and primarily bought the device to keep a track of progress and motivate myself. It is just cool to see your run on a map and how hard or easy it was for you to do.    
For a very detailed analysis of the watch, check this article

Rim overheating. I just read up on it on a bike forum. I had no idea it could cause a blow-out  - apparently rim gets so hot it softens/melts the tyre or bead and if its a loose fitting rim, the tyre can pop off and tube blows, presumably high pressure is needed too. However, the forum contributors also emphasized it is very rare and even if you *try* to make it happen over a very long steep descent - e.g. by braking hard for a few kms down a 15% grade  - even then, its hard to get a pop.   
I think you just had a faulty tyre or a foreign object.   
I haven't had a puncture in the last 9,000 kms of road cycling.   
Since you're getting a new tyre, try kevlar reinforced tyre     
or buy the kevlar strips you can put between yhe tube and tyre.

post:
He did have an hour on skis - his instructor did have experience of autistic children and struck up a surprisingly good rapport with him. Unfortunately our son does have physical disabilities - notably dyspraxia - which although isn't terribly visible,  became much more apparent when placed on skis.  Whilst he gave it a good go, it was clear that any progress on skis would be very slow this year and is something perhaps best left a little while.  Afterall, he only learnt to kick a ball a couple of months ago so skiing is a little adventurous ..   
But you allow me to highlight that it is a common misconception (and one that I laboured under) that this sort of skiing is only for those with physical disabilities - the instructor was very keen to stress what a wonderful experience it is for all people who otherwise would not be able readily and easily get up on a pair of skis on their feet.  The pure adrenalin rush and accompanying stream of speech (my son usually only speaks very little and in pre-learned set phrases) from our son is testament to the unexpected side effects of such an experience.  As he said to me when I tucked in him bed at the end of the weekend "a lot of fun" Never heard him say that before

post:
To be honest I am not a god enough skier to tell the difference in the lateral stiffness of a boot. The flexion/extension stiffness can be adjusted in my boot, but the soft option is only for walking not for skiing. I think to really tell the differences on this kind of stuff you need to be someone who can drive an edge very hard at high speed. The majority of skiers who I see on the pistes (me included) tend to release the ski to slow themselves down as they come out of the turn.    
Yes I have touring bindings too, but would have gotten a hybrid boot regardless of touring bindings are not. I am not a world cup downhill skier and don't intend to be so absolute stiffness at a cost to comfort does not interest me. It doesn't make sense to get this set up unless you intend to tour (and then you also need alot more safety equipment too). The bindings and boots are more expensive for touring, so it would make it a very expensive option if you were just going ride on the piste.

When hiking, mountain biking, snowshoeing, skiing (especially off piste) - please remember that you are invading the native wild animals' space. You are the danger, not the other way around.   
Switzerland's many hiking trails allow us a closer relationship with nature than we might find elsewhere - we are very fortunate to have this opportunity. But we must approach nature with the respect it deserves, and it is incumbent on each of us to ensure that we disturb these glorious animals' habitat as little as possible.    
If you hike the mountains, learn how to respond correctly to the animals you might encounter. Here's what the 'Respekt deine Grenzen' website, has to say about encountering Steinbock:

post:
The Tanzhaus Zurich offers a 'youth' dance course:       
This is suitable for young people (teens) who have not danced before, or are not 'ballerinas'. Our daughter has just started in the group and it is very focused on enjoyment of dance and learning to move their bodies.   
For anyone who has a teen with a rapidly changing body shape, who perhaps lacks self-esteem or confidence, or who is creative but not ballerina shaped... this could be a really great introduction to the enjoyment of dance, without over-emphasis on physical appearance or the perfectionism of ballet. (My sister was a ballerina so I know how kids who do not fit the classic body-shape lose out once they hit puberty).    
They do movement, rhythm, of course exercise, but also the teacher has organised for the group to see a play as well as go to a dance performance.    
Our daughter joined as a social outlet as well as to build her self-esteem. The group has only a few members and they need to grow. There are at least two kids who are fluent in English but the group is German-speaking.   
If you want to ask any questions, let me know. We travel from Adliswil with her and organise to pick her up each week so that she does not travel on the train alone - we would be happy to coordinate this if there are any teens around Adliswil/Leimbach/Sihlcity who want to join the group.

post: Thank you Jern - much appreciated!

so anyway i went to basefit and bought a day pass for 20chf. because of their 400chf per year intro offer and the fact it's still only about 500chf now, and because 20chf is about half the price of the next cheapest gym day pass i could find, i was expecting a no-frills gym. and maybe it is a no frills gym, but that zurich has again just raised the bar when it comes to what is considered frills. then did this for 10-12 reps and ate a banana    
because basically, basefit is brilliant. and of all the gyms i've been to, it's probably the best. i had a free trial at holmes place once like i was ever actually considering it, and that was as totally utopia as any place where you can ride the elevator in a big white dressing gown can be (totally), but holmes place doesn't really count because actually i remember sitting in the splash pool there thinking that if i ever joined the place i'd probably just get fat(ter) unless i could burn the calories from drinking smuggled-in bailey's-cream miniatures by going up and down in the elevator in a dressing gown afterwards.   
basefit is big, spacious, modern, and packed with equipment; there are four or five of each of the most popular machines. there are also plenty of other machines with more obscure missions such as the one that works your lower back and that no-one uses without coming across as a right pelvis thruster. there's also a free weights section, a unit of men in and around that section who occasionally make across-the-forest noises, and best of all a group exercise room where a new class starts every 20 minutes and is taken by a retroly-leotarded avatar on a wall screen.    
anyway: recommend.   
and free juice as well.
Good to know, I definitely won't be doing it in 2 hours   With a combination of stopping for the views and or breaks i'll probably be pushing 5 by the time I'm back

I pretty much go on solo rides, so I wouldn't mind a bit of a company. But I tend to go a bit earlier (around 7:30 - 8pm) and I'm on a road bike.

Hi Markarina   
I have used it; it is great as you do not need to pass by the cashier anymore. And with the same card you can ski in Davos, in Andermatt, Gstaad, Crans, Saas Fee etc. No need to buy each time a new ski pass.    
I have subscribed for the premium user model, what they also call automatic payment (post payment). So I keep the skioo card in my jacket, and on the website I have linked it with my credit card. I then go skiing and just get an SMS afterwards that they will charge my credit card.  
They are doing it the way that only the time is charged for what I was skiing. If I was there for half a day, then I am charged just half a day.   
The best is to try it out. After the first day, you will not want to miss it. 
Cheers   
Patrick from Zurich

Whilst I agree that finding a mooring place and importing a boat to Switzerland can be difficult, it is possible!     But there are other possibilities.... come and sail with us! We are always on the look-out for new members with whom to share our passion.     We are a friendly,multi-national, multi-lingual group who own and sail International 12-foot Dinghies. Designed in England by an amateur designer over 100 years ago these boats became the first small boats to be granted international status and the first small boats to be raced in the Olympic Games. Against all the odds the design has outlived many more modern designs and large fleets are to be found cruising and racing in Italy and the Netherlands.      Being just 12 feet long our boats are easily towed and stored and there are now 15-20 of them around Lake Geneva. During the summer we take part in many of the local regattas (Régate des Vieux Bateaux, Classique de Sciez, Fête des Canots etc. etc.) and also meet for cruises followed by picnics and barbecues. We also welcome visiting boats from other countries for events such as the Swiss 12' Dinghy Championships which were held at Vevey (2013) and Morges (2014).      Visit   for more information or email me at   to arrange a sail.

Hello all,   
I'm a beginner ski-tourer who just got kitted up last season.  I've done a few small 'side country' ascents and have done some powder and crud descents on touring skis.  I'm looking for other beginner or early-intermediate ski-tourers who would like to partner up for a few day-tours this winter.   
I am a very experienced alpine skier who is comfortable skiing in all conditions from black pistes to mixed-snow off piste (crud, powder, etc.).  I have limited experience with skinning / ascents on touring skis but I didn't have any problems the few times I have tried.  I would say I have a medium-level of fitness overall, but I can endure long-hard days on occasion.   
I also have a set-up which is more free-ride oriented -meant for short ascents to access free ride areas near resorts.  If this is more your style I'm also interested in hearing from you!   
I live on the border between Zug and Zurich so the Central Switzerland area is most convenient for me.  I don't mind travelling a bit further though to access the Bernese Oberland or Graubunden/Engadin, etc.  I usually make a few weekend trips to the western part of Switzerland each winter and tend to go to Chamonix when I have a week or more available.   
So, anyone out there keen to join me?  At this point I'm eager to get a bit deeper into the back-country but need a partner or small group!  I'll see if I get any bites here before looking to sign up for guided group tours.   
Cheers,   
KH

Fine. I did it. You have your bloody poem. I  . Unintentionally, the meter and rhythm sort of changed in the second half, and are less 'Raven-ish'. I guess just think of it as prose instead of a poem.    
To anyone contemplating doing the Engadiner, it really is quite the event, and I'm highly recommend doing it once just for the experience. Yes, it is very crowded, but it is stunningly beautiful, unbelievably well-organized (there is  purpose-built train stop at the finish line!) and, like all sporting events, there is a great feeling of accomplishment in finishing it. So long as you go in expecting it to be a bit of a squeeze, and just relax and enjoy the experience instead of aiming for a blistering time, you'll have a blast. (Oh, and I'd recommend some sort of training program too.  )     To anyone contemplating writing a race report inspired by literature, I would highly recommend that you pick something simple. It's a bit hard to bring everything into a poem. (For example, what rhymes with s-Chanf?)   
'Poe'-etically yours,    
Heather

Sports that you can play to develop your quads (thighs) muscles:   
Gymming (squats + seated front legs raises on machine) 
Football 
Skiing 
Squash 
Tennis 
Badminton 
Basketball 
Volleyball 
Hockey 
Running   
Etc...   
Practically any sport involving use of legs will help you to gain muscles. There some activities that can help to get in shape faster than the other e.g. leg workout in gym. Just google it and it shouldn't be too hard to find about the basics.

Event was fun. Atmosphere was pretty good for a Swiss sport event (I find some are a bit too serious here in Switzerland and forget a little about the fun, although I'm a competitive person this is the feeling I have).   
If I was to provide any advice it we be not to underestimate the stamina element. Whether you are winning or losing matches you do end up playing a lot due to the way the event is run.   
Unfortunately I'm concentrating on other sports at the moment and am a bit far away from you to train together.  Perhaps in a year or 2 I'll get back into it and we can meet up at an event.    
Anyway ,I thought it was a good format and was pleased I found out about it so would recommend it to others who are considering it.

As everyone has covered the creams already, I'll give my 2 Rappen on makeup. Less is more after 30.    
Use tinted moisturizer with SPF more than foundation, and go sparing on the rest of the makeup. If you can, buy sample sizes in a couple of colors and see what works best before you spend a lot. If you're like me, you need to change shade slightly between summer and winter.    
Only line your upper lid, not your lower one. This helps your eyes appear more open. Avoid waterproof mascara, because it's harder to remove and you'll tend to scrub the heck out of your eyes to get it off. Don't wax your upper lip if you can help it. If you smoke, stop.   
If you don't like my advice, just listen to edot. She looks half her age. No joke. Whatever she does is the ticket to looking like a teenager forever.

I have been flying for 4 years now. I trained in Switzerland and have nothing but good things to say about the Swiss system.    
Switzerland has the highest per-capita participation and as a result has a well oiled training regime, highly proficient paragliding association, and enjoys a good reputation as a respectable sport. Importantly, paragliding is not considered a high risk sport by insurers and has no impact on heath or life insurance.   
The training process is essentially: 
(1) Basic training 2-4 days. This gives you a knowledge of the equipment and its safe use. This is the only time you might have to put real energy into walking up a hill (unless you chose to!) 
(2) High flight training. This takes you through a structured course under radio supervision, and ensures you have mastered normal and abnormal flight situations. 
At this point you will have to pass a theory and and practical exam. Thereafter you are able to fly unsupervised essentially anywhere in the world, as long as you adhere to local air laws and have the appropriate insurances.   
For a list of schools have a look at the paragliding association website:  . I would urge you to research the school you choose thoroughly; how well the instructors can communicate instructions to you (in fluent English), how fun they are to train with, and their track record of getting students through the exams first time will be facts you will have to live with for 3-6 months!

The walk from Stand to Titlis goes over to the top of the Laubersgrat chairlift and then goes up the ridge on what is known as the "Sommerweg". The Sommerweg will end at the bottom of the Gletscherlift and from then on up, you just walk up the ski piste (just a cat track at this time of the year) to the Klein Titlis. Don't wander too far off the piste as there are some crevasses. If you are going next weekend as part of the Bergtrophy Titlis, just follow the groups and you'll be fine. Have fun.

Yes, Bent Branderup. My wife has taken several courses with him.

For proper Downhill: 
Best is Portes du Soleil, and Chatel in France is a good access point. Very popular so can get busy including lots of Brits coming over from the UK. Morgins is also a good access point, and my preferred area, with some great downhill tracks (mainly reds). 
Verbier is a nice spot, has far fewer runs than places like Chatel, but rarely gets busy. I like it a lot, but haven't been for a couple of years. 
For something that has a longer season (May to October), Leysin is worth a look.

It was tongue in cheek, but yes.   
I guess actual martial arts that include less than average contact, or do not absolulely require contact [such as Judo, Aikido, various jujitsu], would be    
Certain federations of karate, which I am not familiar with.     
or;   
Capoeira is really cool, has less contact [you want to avoid the spinning feet, etc], but is going to require either a lot of youthful energy, or time to develop muscles most people don't think about or use.  I have seen a lot of it, but never trained.   
A great thing about exposure to these sorts of practices is that it is an opportunity where you have to approach, or even leave certain envelopes in one's life, such as physical contact.  Even non-contact karate may involve correction from the instructor, where they simply move the student into the structure they are trying to teach them, rotating limbs, joints into position xyz.   
One art I would like to see here in CH is Schwingen

I think it's simply because it's easier.   
On our first hiking trip to the alps, my wife and I would set off at 5.00am every day and walk uphill for hours. 
We would arrive at a top cable car station (or the path near one) after walking for four or five hours solidly uphill, and meet all the fresh-faced people who had had a lazy breakfast and taken a leisurely trip by cable-car.   
At the time, I thought that going up by cable-car was cheating!
Fitness Malley belonging to Migros means that the contracts will have less nasty suprises than some - but if you need my help for a translation or anything I am willing to help anytime

Any hike in Switzerland will be scenic..   
Flumserberg has a nice hike which overlooks the Walensee.   
Otherwise Amden, Brunni, Etzel, Sattelegg, Sattel, Santis, Rigi...The options are endless. Just park the car at any Passhohe or Gondolastation and look out for the yellow signs. The time indicated is very accurate usually. Just avoid the white-red-white marked yellow signs and youll be fine.   
Bring good shoes though as the ground will still be very wet.

Thanks again for the replies. 
I will measure the bike tomorrow and see how it fits in with the recommendations on that website you posted, Craban.  
Yeaaah, it is one of those bikes that you're supposed to go faster on to keep balanced. And I do know the problem is me with the bike, not with traffic- it's so quiet where I am, haha. Out in the country! There's even a flat, 'back' route into town to the grocery store, so I have no traffic excuse. Just a fear of being up so high and having to go much faster than I used to.  
I really wouldn't mind using a slower bike, to be honest. It's still faster than walking, yanno? But I've only got another three months here, so we'll see- otherwise at the weekend I think I'll try to get out to one of those larger bike rental places I've seen at some of the other nearby train stations like Murten and rent something more my style to get that balance. I liked going fast in the past, so I'm sure once I just get back the balance I'll be golden, even if the monster-bike is a bit too tall.    
Thank you all again for the replies- I was so frustrated last night after trying and failing yet again to find a sense of balance on the monster-bike, haha.   I really appreciate the thoughtful responses!

It is in Irchelpark, if you take the tram to Milchbuck and walk into the park, it's on the left (north) side, there is a path that goes past the football and tennis fields (with the fields on the left), before the path goes under a "roof" the climbing wall is on the right.  It is not very high though, I've never seen anyone there with a rope..   
There is also an excellent bouldering wall at ETH Hönggeberg.  From the bus station you walk towards the sport center (heading roughly east), it's close to the sport center entrance, on the other side of the pathway.   
I went once to minimum bouldering, it was okay, pretty difficult problems though, it's a sort of a lifestyle-climbers kind of place  .  Only options that I know of for rope climbing are Schlieren and Milandia which are very expensive (imho), but big and with plenty of routes of all levels.  Pretty crowded in the afternoons though and not inside zone 10, when I go to Schlieren I usually take tram 17 to the end station (inside zone 10) and then it's about 20 minute walk.

As you refer to A/B permit, I assume that you have a non-swiss paragliding license. If you are already qualified, and are resident in Switzerland, you will  need to pass the Swiss exam. Details are to be found here:    
In order to get you through the exam, I recommend that you contact a local school. There are many great paragliding schools in Switzerland. You can find a list on the free flight association website ( ). Personally, I would recommend   above all others. They usually fly around Lake Luzern, which would be very convenient for you if you are in Basel. They also have a lot of ladies training, or already qualified, so you should find some good company there.   
If you are just visiting Switzerland, and have an IPPI 4 or 5 then your are most welcome  to fly in Switzerland. If you want help on where or local site/meteo  knowledge, just contact me.

Hi there - I don't mean to criticise, but why didn't you attempt to "bike it" properly, i.e. unassisted? 
Maybe go for less distance, but more exercise, and a quest / challenge too. 
For example I remember distinctly seeing once a middle aged couple on recumbents climbing up the Gotthard (Uri side), obviously huffing and puffing (and it may even have been raining), but really "into" the challenge. Bet they took something home from that experience!   
Just wondering if maybe you've gotten yourself into some kind of mental trap re: age* (or as some say "lack of youth"), lack of physical preparation (many times the bar is irrationally raised to olympic levels), danger(s) and other unknown unknowns, not owning a "proper" (i.e. somewhat expensive) bike, etc, etc.   
Cheers   
Paul 
*50 y.o. avid mountain biker, not necessarily in top form

I have recently ordered something from Wiggle (UK based) and Roseversand (German based).   
Wiggle ... item was £38 (excl.  VAT) with free postage.  It arrived in 3 days.  It had been stopped and inspected by customs (they had taped the parcel back up with tape marked DOUANE ZOLL CUSTOMS) but obviously quickly left to continue its journey.  Outside of package had item description and cost.  I assume they opened it to check postage costs ("free") and maybe to ensure the contents matched the description.  So, no extra charges, just £38 vat free.   
Roseversand ... items came to 130€ and took 4 days to arrive. They had removed the 19% German MWST, added the 8% Swiss VAT and charged 1% for doing this.  It arrived untouched by customs as there was a Swiss customs declaration already on the parcel.

This reminds me of a scene out of the zany story "The Third Policemen" by Flann O'Brien which describes the relationship between a man and his bicycle. However, in terms of a bizarre atomic theory where there is an interchange of "bicycle" and "man" molecules especially at the saddle and handlebars, the points of closest inter-contact. This resulting eventually in the bicycle developing human characteristics and likewise the man developing bicycle characteristics.

Personally I can't help on the details, but the windsurfers only seem to go out when it is howling. One good spot to meet up is   - I often see a few people rigging up there when the wind is up. Overall though it isn't going to be consistent or regular.   
The prevailing strong winds are called the bise, which comes from the North-East and is therefore cold. It also means that you get reasonable waves coming in from Lausanne direction so the water is fairly bumpy.

Starting point   Koblenz AG   GPS Route and Photos     This run was done on a mountain bike  racing bikes would be less suitable for bits of the trip. A ride with lots of variety and not too many people!    No restaurants in the valley of the Schwarza and on Monday many of the others are found to be closed. Sankt Blasien is a real tourist centre with bakeries and cafés etc.    Leaving  Waldshut the route goes to Schluchtal bei Gurtweil. From Gutenberg one follows the road with plenty of bends but little traffic to Witznau.   The sun was warm which was a pleasant surprise after thick fog and 10° in Koblenz.    Surprisingly, Müllers, where e-bikes (pedeliecs) can be hired, was still open.    Sometimes, when signs say that the road is closed, it is worth going down it to see how closed it really is. Often enough there is still room for a bike to get through even if the road is up. You can see one of the 'closed' bits on the photos.

I ride a bike as part of a commute every day, up to 30 minutes each way. It's tolerable (with the right clothes) even in bad weather. On the rare occasion that it snows, I may take a day off!   
Just make sure you use lights when it's dark, and be careful in the wet. Also watch at some pedestrian crossings (some are combined cycle and pedestrian crossings, some are only for pedestrians).   
Proceed with caution, practice, and you will get used to it. As sandgrounder says, it's often the fastest way around the city.   
You will find many decent bikes second hand for the cost of one or two month's tram tickets.

Even easier, take the train to Aigle, then the bus via Vionnaz to Torgon, which then links up to Chapelle d'Abondance, and Tour de Don and on to Châtel and super Châtel, and down to Morgins- and then on ...   
Torgon has an excellent English speaking ski  and snowboarding school and beginners area, with restaurant next to the baby slope too.   
Had an excellent day there (drove up to Plan de Croix, just before Torgon) with huge car park and restaurant- plenty of snow and excellent conditions- although a couple of slopes a bit in the afternoon. Thanks BMXgirl and friend for company.   
If you want to stay for a few days in an English speaking environment, with lots of British, OZ and NZ staff- have a look at     
A great company who can organise everything for you on spot and right next to the slope, ski or snowboard hire, lessons, accom, meals, ski pass, etc. Highly recommended.

I would say just choose the club local to you, there will be training a couple of times a week, and matches (half of which will be at your home pitch).   
Kids football over here is really well organised.   
My son was 9 when he started playing for a local swiss team (and he spoke no german as we had just moved here). He has been playing with the Swiss teams for over 5 years now.   
You will also find that as the kids get older the Swiss kids will want to try out their english, so they find a way to communicate with each other in a mix of languages. 
It also helps with learning Swiss-german, and gets them out of the "international school bubble". (if your son is at International school! mine is) 
The teams are very well run, disciplined and have amazing facilities. 
Our experiences of kids football over here have been really positive and I would recommend it to any family with a kid who loves football. 
Good Luck!

Ended up deciding on a different direction this time.  We cycled to the Greifensee (lake of Uster), around it, and back.  The way to the lake through the Zürichberg, Gockhausen, Geeren, Pfaffhausen, and Fällanden, the way back through Benglen, Pfaffhausen and Witikon - see   of the path.  It was a really nice ride!   
I'm not in good fitness these days so the way to there across the Zürichberg was a bit difficult - that hill goes on farther than I expected climbing, and as my legs were somewhat tired on the way back through Witikon I did the steeper parts stepping off the bike walking, but overall it was not too strenuous.   
The weather was good, and a big part of the ride on the hills is in paths in the woods, which is coasy, especially with a mountain bike on the stones and roots.  The villages and towns going down to the lake aren't too exciting but pleasant to bike through nonetheless.   
The entire trip was about 45 km, done in a relaxed pace of 5 hours including pauses.  The path around the lake, about 20km, is nice and easy with view to the alps part of the time, though on an Easter Sunday we were not alone...  The hills in between are climbs of about 300m.  We did it all in a relaxed pace in 5 hours including pauses.   
Definitely recommended!  I'm looking forward to more bike rides in the area.  Next time I guess I'd check out some of the routes to the Zürcher Unterland, the Limmattal, or south west the Sihltal.  And perhaps at some point with company a full day to go around the Zürisee.   
  Cheers, 
  -- Tom

If you fly with Swiss then they are also pretty good with sports equipment.

The link earlier to the Velomarkt is also a good option, but you will also have to factor in an additional 'service' cost to the bikes before you use them..... they might be fine, but generally second hand bikes are not. 
The velomarkts are also rarely that cheap.

Best of luck.

Look at this website for the Ski Company based in Greenwich and the Portes du Soleil. they are hugely experienced in ski courses, do their own transfers, ski and snowboard hire, closely linked to English speaking ski/snowboard school and right next to slopes, where beginner lessons take place- with a restaurant for hot drinks, food, pizzas right next to it.        
and click on week-end packages. Gerry the owner, Becky and Oli, his management team, will happily answer any questions. I have no connection with them, apart from having organised dozens of trips with schools and friends from UK. Fabulous value at £65 per day!!! to include:   
This price                                     includes  accommodation, buffet  breakfast, packed lunch, afternoon tea and cakes, 4 course evening meal,  lift pass with 60 lifts and 150kms of slopes plus complimentary hire of  ski or board equipment. (transfer extra- but you can get there by train and bus from Geneva airport station easily- train to Aigle, then bus via Vionnaz up to Torgon). It is one of the closest Swiss resort to access from Geneva via transfer or train/bus directly from airport.   
That is £260 per person all in for arrival Thursday, ski pass and equipment hire +full board   (about 1 hr).  Lessons extra depending on number of hours wanted, and    running ski trips to CH since 1984.  Easy peasy. They run courses in several other resorts- but Torgon is the nearest and easiest for a week-end. I can whole heartedly recommend them, as I've used them for over 20 years.   
Check their Facebook page too.   
Zermatt is indeed gorgeous, but so much further unfortunately- so really not sensible for a week-end.  Very easy to get to Verbier too from Geneva, train to Martigny from airport, then change train to Le Châble and gondola straight up to resort- but very expensive and not so good for beginners.

post: Try Heather at  . She is a personal trainer and swimming coach who has been giving lessons in the region. She teaches all levels, from beginners to budding triathletes.

To use a great German word "Jein". Some schools will give lessons on riding off piste. This is aimed at the skills required and will use slopes that are within the ski area and have minimal avalanche risk. This is a lesson on how to ride powder on your ski's or board and not a lesson on avalanche safety.    
The guides can teach you avalanche safety, but not necessarily the technique required for you to ride off piste.         I did the course and some powder days with them in Engelberg. Best bet is to contact them and see what they say. If you get enough people together you might be able to organise a private course.       There is a simplified reduction method which I don't have time to look for now that I use pretty much every time. That is if the avalanche risk is 2, I stick to slopes less then 35 degrees, if its 3 I stick to slopes less then 30 degrees. If I go into the grey areas (over 35 degrees in risk level 2, or over 30 degrees in risk level 3) then I use the reduction method along with any other information I have to decide whether to go or not.  I am not someone that likes to ride stupidly steep coulours etc so I am normally happy riding areas of about 30 to 35 degrees and just cruising.
Excellent, I'll message you.

Hi Calvin,   
it can sometimes be a bit of a science to understand snow reports. Atleast in Switzerland they are more truthful then some other places i know.   
Im based in Lenzerheide and can say the conditions are pretty good right now.. Almost all of the ski runs are open and all of the lifts are running. This part of Switzerland is haivng an ok winter so far. We could all use some more snow, but there is definately enough to ski on. In high trafic areas you can get some little rocks coming through at the end of the day. Its not just Lenzerheide that has this problem but most resorts in the region.   
Sorry wrong info, the lift to Arosa isnt open yet. That should open in the next couple of weeks. They still have to make the finishing touches.   
The best snow info is    its the avalanche forcasting website for Switzerland but you get a very good picture of what the conditions are like. Combine that with webcams and snow reports and you should be ok with where to go and ski.   
Have fun this weekend

I don't believe that taking supplements daily is very good for you. I think that your body should be given what it needs in food and learn how to extract it itself. If you give it a nice tablet everyday it'll get lazy.   
Saying that I am not anti-supplements, I think they have their uses as a supplement, not as a regular diet. eg:   
I took a vitamins, omega and folic acid supplement when pregnant and breastfeeding, because folic acid is important, and I don't eat fish or a lot of eggs so omega supplements were the best way to give my child what she needed.  
My daughter had two ear infections after colds in winter, so my (Swiss) GP recommended that she take supplements every day, I only give her them if she has a cold, or.... (as both infections were in winter) over winter.  
I take vitamins only when I have a cold.   
Basically, good for the occasional booster, but not so good to rely on them everyday.

post:
Here's some advice that may be of help.  I shipped my triathlon and CX bike from the US here a couple of months ago.  The bike shop in the US was great in letting me use their account and get a really low rate with FEDEX, however I got hit with a significant duty/tariff upon arrival here.   
It seems to be all based on the value that is placed on the Commercial Invoice (i.e. a lower value - lower tariff).  So you can save some bucks if you use a lower amount for the value.  Obviously, you'll have to weigh that against the amount of insurance you select, so there's some trade off there.   
Good luck with your shipping.
