post:
DeniseMarieM, for the skis you showed, you can have basically two types of bindings: 
-"flat oriented" - BC versions of profile bindings like Rotefella NNN or Salomon SNS - better for longer trips on rather flat areas, where active walking or even running is desirable. I believe that a set of shoes Salomon X-Adve 8 + bindings BC SNS Raid can be bought in any bigger XC shop in Switzerland (I sow such a set in the 'megalopolis' called Delémont, so let's say in Zurich it should not be a problem)       
-"downhill oriented" - e.g. 3 pins+cable - better stability on slopes, less comfortable for "active" stepping. Unfortunately I don't know much more about them.   
Regarding the areas for BC in Switzerland: I live in Jura so I go out from my apartment, look around and decide on which ridge I ski that day ;-) 
Basically whole Jura (the region, not the canton) is quite nice good place to do BC XC.  
I'm planning now a BC XC 1-2 day trip, maybe around Chasseral or Creux-du-Van or completely different place, just with map and compass. Would you be interested in joining such a trip?

La Balme (la Clusaz) is also partially open.   
So are the Three Valleys (though a bit further afield).   
All depends on what sort of weekend you have in mind...

post: I would add that if you are on a glacier either skiing/snowboarding/snow shoeing you should have be wearing a harness and be roped (as mentioned by kiwiguide) AND have a length of rope/flat climbing strap that is attached to the front of the harness and goes over your shoulder. If you are stuck down a crevass they might not be able to hook onto the harness in the front but they will be able to get to the strap over the shoulder to hoist you out. It will not be elegant but it will work. You can get these straps at any sports store that sells/rents harnesses. An investment of CHF 25 that might save you some day.

I don't know of any pools within walking distance of the airport (maybe there are & I'm just not aware of them) but my daughter used to swim for a club that practiced at the Servette pool.  Really nice indoor facility next to the hockey rink, with easy tram/bus connections.

post:
The Snow and Rail offers are only for the Swiss side of the Portes du Soleil normally, and not for the French side resorts. You'd have to take the train to Cluses (Thonon is a long way off) then up to resort by bus- but I am pretty sure you'd have to do this from Geneva- and would not be included in offer.   
Chatel would be much easier to get to, very close to Morgins (on Swiss side)- but again- you'd have to check if it is covered by snowRail offer. SnowRail offers are put together to help Swiss tourism, and not French...   
Just checked, and as I thought. The SnowRail is only to Swiss side resort- but you can get reduction on the ski pass for the whole of the Portes du Soleil, both Swiss and French, including Morzine, but only if you pick them up on the Swiss side- so Morzine is just not possible on that offer by public transport.              21 December 2013 to 27 April 2014 (based on the snow situation)

Hi folks, 
I'm heading back to the States in mid-December, and am hoping to do a bit of snowboarding in Switzerland before I leave.  (This would probably mean a day or weekend trip from Basel on the Nov. 21, Nov. 28, or Dec. 5 weekend, or possibly earlier, if the lifts are open.)  Would love to meet some people who might be up for some early-season skiing or snowboarding, and also to get some advice about the best resorts to check out.  I'm an intermediate snowboarder (don't know how Swiss ratings work, but I tend to ride the blue square slopes in the U.S. (mostly Lake Tahoe area), and occassionally try to scrape my way down a single black diamond.)  Would like to find someplace that's snowboard-friendly (preferably not too many flat spots or drag lifts) with a good variety for novices/intermediates, and hopefully some nice, wide-open cruisers.  For a day trip from Basel, I was thinking perhaps Engelberg or Meiringen-Hasliberg, though I read somewhere that Meiringen has quite a lot of surface tows - would this be an issue for a snowboarder who's used to chair lifts? I'd be very interested to hear other recommendations.     
If there is any interest in a weekend trip, I would also be up for venturing further afield, maybe to Zermatt?  I don't have a car in Basel, so would probably be going for a snow n rail pass, and would also need to rent gear.  (I figured I would rent at the resort itself; is this generally an OK option here?)   
Anyway, let me know if you might be interested in a ski/snowboard trip, and thanks in advance for any advice!

I can really recommend David gym!    
- generous opening hours 6-22 weekdays, 8-20 weekends 
- I always find a parking spot  
- the place is huge, you never have to wait for a machine to get ready (only been there once during rush hour - but they have multiple versions of all machines) 
- I haven't tried their classes, but it seems they have a great variety of martial arts, aerobics and more  
- it is clean and neat  
- I like that there are a lot of big (muscle wise people training there), I find it inspiring 
- they have saunas (a northener like me need one - and that the gym had one was an unexpected serious bonus) 
- you can buy nutrition there as well (haven't checked the prices yet though)   
All in all - great service and great environment. I really find it worth my buck, (I got a special deal so I pay 300 for 2 months - it's not cheap but it is definitely worth it).

UTMB, is that one of the Mont Blanc ultras? start at 02.00 and complete 150km in a day? 
I know a guy who's done that 1x or 2x (he's an iron man tri).  
I've done a few training runs with him and he intro'ed me to the so-called 
Elefanten weg along the Elefantenbach (named for a rock) that goes up  into the forest from Bergwies (near the Tram museum). Massive network of  trails, go in the direction of Forch and Pfannenstiel, you can go  forever with good climbs and height difference (although it's trail not  mountain piste running).   
We start at the Migro Fitnesscentre in 3Koenigstr and go along the lake  before heading up to Bergwies and the trail (which is also a so-called  Pfadiweg, Pfadi = boyscouts, there's even a plaque commemorating  Baden-Powell). You hook up with one of the stages of the SOLA. From the  health club I've done 2.5 hours out & back - my guy keeps it short  for me . then sauna and a bit of craic. can't beat it.

Went last night and picked up a few things for less than CHF70 including some crap I didn't need and donuts for the road!    
It's all low quality stuff to be fair but can't see anything wrong with it so far. 
Was quite impressed with the goggles though, they're not that bad at all given that they're less than 10% of the stuff sold at Ochsner Sport. They have two versions, sunny day ones and cloudy day ones, as I already have the sunny day ones it was a good time to get the cloudy day ones. It remains to be seen if the texture of the snow's visibility is improved and whether or not they will steam up. They fit over glasses easily so if you're blind as a bat it should be no problem too. 
Thermals, gloves and accessories are cheap as chips and will keep you / your visitors warm on the slope. 
Jacket and trousers I wasn't very impressed with but can't really go wrong with CHF20 trousers that you can throw away if you have to after one season.   
Only problem is size as there are no changing rooms, so you need to know your size before you go, maybe take a pair of your own to measure against. 
Popular colour for trousers seems to be green, as I couldn't find my size in that colour so ended up going with a boring colour (black).

It needs a special tool to contain the file/grinding plate at the correct angle, and a certain amount of skill and judgment, but it's not rocket science. Most shops will do a 'base grind' and wax on a machine which takes away the manual effort for a simple service, but a proper sharp edge requires a little more patience.      The main thing people notice is if, after a service, you're constantly 'catching' the inner tip or tail of the ski - it may have been sharpened too close to the end, so 'detuning' the last 20cm or so might help. But it's worth bearing in mind that if you have a good fore-and-aft weight distribution over the skis then this won't happen anyway. So go get some lessons too

post:
Oh...so tempted, but Berlin is a hair far.  If it was in Stuttgart for Frankfurt we would be all over this.  We have not done a mud run since we moved to CH.  The last one we did was a tough mudder.  We had a team of 5 but you really did not need one...everyone is rather helpful and encouraging.   
The TM event we did was held at a ski result and was in total 17km.  However, we could only run about 10 of it because of the climbs up three of the slopes.  So...in Berlin...you might actually have to run more...But its not a timed event so who gives a crap?   
A few notes about our experience: Three of our team of 5 had injuries of some type or another.  Only one of us needed a visit to the hospital...where there were so many others waiting to be seen.  I have a lovely scar on my side.  This experience also helped redefine what cold is.  When our race started it was -3.0C and it never got about 5C all day.  Being wet and cold became less noticeable as the end got nearer...but at 7am when we started...holy...that was an eye opener!     
As a result of that race, rain, cold, and other things don't really mean that much anymore.  I have but one recommendation: where merino wool athletic clothing.  This will help keep you less cold than other sport clothing options.  Especially a hat and oddly enough...gloves.  Looks funny, but you'll suffer less.
I'll stick to my beer method, thank you very much.

Cheers everyone.    
In the end, the answer came to me as I was hooking up my existing 26er to the kiddie trailer - the clearance between the wheel and the frot of the trailer was very small. After measuring it I discovered that a 29er would give less than 2cm clearance - not enough to account for flex and turn when riding - so 26er it was for me.    
I shoppe around in Zurich where 2013 bikes were gettin thin on the grous, and as I discovered for the bigger brands (Specialized, Cannondale) almost no 26er bikes are being offered in 2014. Specialized offer the Rockhopper in 26er only to a size M frame in 2014 - I'm definitely a large/19inch frame.    
So, I checked the Internet and ordered a Cannondale Trail SL3 from bike24.de. Decent price, and a good frame. Drivetrain isn't brilliant, but easily upgrade able.    
Thanks for the advice all!

The Brassband Zurich is the only Brass Band in Zurich and ranked in the 3rd category at the Swiss Brass Band Competition in Montreux. ( ).     
We are searching for musicians, perhaps even with Brass Band experience, and motivated to join our band. At the moment we are searching actively for Cornet players, but generally everybody is highly welcome to support our band. The next event will be the Brass Band Competition in Montreux (23.- 24.11.2013) and our annual concert beginning of next year. post:
It's true, 28 CHF is quite a bit for a map, but there is sooo much info contained in them - a lot more than your average driving map.    
For hiking, the 1:100,000 are certainly marginal. However, I've used them for a lot of long hikes and they are generally OK when paired with the frequent directional markers. However, they don't have all of the hiking trails marked on them, so before leaving home I'll often have a look at the area I'm going to on the   website, and then copy onto the map any additional trails that I think might be useful.   
Of course, I also have a couple of national 1:300,000 maps that are best for long-distance route planning; one that is good for driving, and   that has all of the cycling routes marked on it. One can never have enough maps

I can only agree on what most posters have said already. Insanity is not for beginners. It is tough and very challenging. First I did P90X almost 2 years ago but I adapted it to my own routine as I still wanted to commute by bike (2x20K) so I didn't do the cardio days. I did my own diet stuff too but still I managed to shred 8-9 kilos and reduce my BF% to around 11.    
P90X was intense so I had a 3 month break before I took on Insanity.   
Insanity is in my opinion more challenging than P90X and much more fun. It is extremely tough too and as I mentioned before it is not for beginners. If you struggle to complete the fitness test on day one I recommend you to pick another program and save Insanity for later.   
I have also bought P90X2 and Insanity Asylum but unfortunately I have been forced to rethink my exercise routines due to a painful "Spondylarthrose"   so these two programs are on stand by until I am pain free....if ever.   
Doing Insanity is the best thing ever happened to me exercise wise.....the program kicks butt and in particular I like the fact that there is no thinking to do. Everyone can put in a DVD and follow the instructions given. You don't have to be a fitness expert to get the result you desire.   
And since the warm up is very thorough and the stretching likewise......everything is covered.   
Good luck to everyone who decide to change their life with Insanity, P90X or other BB products.   
BTW: I have just purchased Ultimate Reset and will do the program in August. It needs careful planning in order to be successful.   
More BTW: I bet most of the pictures showing "before" and "after" Insanity are true. I went from "build" to "almost ripped" in 60 days......but since I am facing fifty this year it takes a lot of effort just to maintain.....a lot!

Nice....   
On a serious note don't they say that virtually every 20 pound note in England has traces of Cocaine? So it would be possible to come into contact with the stuff, but not internally.   
I heard there was a study to analyse sewerage pipes for cocaine traces In London, obviously it would be more accurate than a guestimate from the Govt. Quite clever I thought, I'm sure the findings were way above the expected levels of cocaine use.   
Story, from my prev workplace....   
I used to work in Forensics in the UK and one of my friends worked in the drugs lab.    
Well anyone know's after a bust they test the purity of substances so imagine the scene in a lab with 50 odd 1/2kg bricks of cocaine being weighed etc.    
Anyway back to the story, so to test drugs you need a pure substance as a reference, this happened to be 1/2kg of 99.99% pure Cocaine. Over time something strange started to happen the reference stock started disappearing quicker than was expected, and some wierd purity results were seen. All of this is controlled, signed in etc etc and I have no idea how this was done.   
Anyway it's noted that the reference block loses more that it should when one certain guy is around.    
Now at this point what would you do? Deny it, or admit it?    
The guy actually admitted it and said that he has a problem and he hasn't felt right for the last month or so after working in the lab.   
A full investigation is launched and the findings are the extraction filtration system is not good enough and hasn't ever been. So the occupants of this lab have in some cases 5yrs worth of exposure to illicit material in their system.   
At this point the company has to quickly offer alll member counciling inclusive of the guy stealing the coke and ensure that he's placed in a clinic to deal with his addiction.    
How bizarre is that? Go to work and gain a class A addiction.   
My personal favourite at this lab was watching the rasta security guard follow the weed busts around building on route to the drugs lab

post:
It could be the dealer's mate from a different IP address, but it could be totally innocent.   
There is an automatic bid function on Ricardo, for when a user may not be available when the offer closes. He just needs to put his maximum bid, and the system will out bid any other last minute bids until the maximum is reached.   
This happened to me once, and I was naturally suspicious, especially as the seller contacted me, shortly after the close of bidding, and offered me another of the same, for my last highest bid - which I declined.   
So it could be price bumping or automatic bidding.     
From Gonsers own site:       
If it goes above 257,00 drop out.   
Also see this thread:

SAA Works very hard to have almost zero no shows on their events. All the events run are accessible from Zurich. The feeling is that anyone can take a run down the Antenna trail at any time, so while the evenings are long we try to get people out of the city and show options that most people wouldn't otherwise think about. You would be surprised how much stuff is actually quite easily accessible from Zurich after work.    
As an example next Tuesdays afterwork ride is nearer Luzern, but a number of people still travel from Zurich for it. Coming up there will be rides on Geissberg, Altberg, Zugerberg and at some point we may even revisit Uetliberg again.    
If that is not your cup of tea there is always the option to suggest a ride that you find more suitable. With over 800 members and nearly 200 events in the last 18 months I don't know of any more active cycling communities in Switzerland.
I would love to ride on  these

There is the occassional community wrorkshop for bikes in Europe - I have come across the in neighbouring France, but have personally only come across one this side of the border.  (though others may exisit).    
I have bought both metric and nonmetric allen keys from the same bike shop here. With those and an adjustable wrench , there is little basic maintainence that I can't do when touring.    
Yes, bikes are cheaper to buy over the German and French borders.  Can you be specific about what sort of bike you are looking for? Brand?    
If it was me who was able to freight a bike over, without cost, I would do so. I would imagine that tools are also cheaper to buy in the USA than here ( this side of the border) so would also look at buying the basics keys, wrench, chain tool etc and shipping those over as well.

If you're bike has a standard schrader valve (same as a car tyre) then you can go to any service station, and you'll find the air there.   
If you have a "Presta" valve (French valve) or even worse - a woods valve, I'd suggest that you pick up your own pump to carry on you at all times.   
I think most service stations also carry the adaption, so just ask inside if you get stuck.

Paddy,   
I used to ride with a bunch of guys in Australia and they were getting multiple punctures all over the place. I became a professional tire change watcher, sometimes I helped with the occasional hint they should try running tubeless . I run tubeless tires with the goop in them, they are a little heavier but I have never had a flat in over 18 months of riding on them. I now swear by them. I have a spare tube just in case, its pretty painless to put a tube in if u do have a flat. Flats have become a thing of the past for me.   
Hope the alternative approach helps.

I run XT and they where making a heap of noise after I washed the bike. LBS suspected I had some lube or something on either the rotar or pads, anyway recommended to get them really hot. Chris

post: Spice it up. Warm up properly, do it 3 times round fast run between stations and forget the bendy stretchy exercises and sub for full body weight exercises at each station. Say 21 reps each time first round, then 15 then 9... Crossfit style. You will have earns a giant lunch after that!

Hi there - Welcome to the Forum 
The Swiss idea of 'spontaneous' is making plans about three weeks ahead (and this is for an invitation to a cup of coffee).    
Switzerland is basically not a disability friendly country. Things are improving but I've said before that the main reason that the Swiss are so good at the longer distances in wheelchair racing, is because they are used to racing from one WC suitable for wheelchairs to the next! There are hills all over the place. Some new trains have wide doorways and are roll-in, roll-off. Some trains have narrow doorways and narrow steps. Some trains have broad doorways but stop at stations where descending from the carriage is training for coming down from the Matterhorn! Restaurants often have steps all over the place and ramps tend to be steep.   
There are lots of rules regarding dogs and bringing them into the country involves about three hundred of them.  I'm not trying to put you off but forewarned is forearmed. Check out 'Meloncollie' on here for excellent dog advice and loads of tips.   
Since you say you speak some German, I suggest you take a look at this site -    is the 'Home' of Disabilty Sport in Switzerland and has links to the Swiss Paralympic folk who will have far more detailed information than we have on here. Try under 'Leichtathletic' for handbike stuff. Swiss Skiing is clear. I would e-mail them and ask for suggestions and advice. The national teams travel a lot for training and competition and will know all the tricks of the trade and the best places for you to enjoy your sport.    
Be prepared for this sort of thing... I asked at the cash desk of an indoor swimming pool, if the cashier could take care of a perfectly behaved Guide Dog, while the swimmer, who is blind,  took part in a training session in my group. The reply - 'We cannot start doing that or everyone would be asking. If the lady comes by car, she could leave the dog in the car...'   
Good luck in your plan making.

Hello,   
Before I start, a brief intro about myself, I am British from London, 30 years of age and I have been living in Basel for over 2 years now with my husband - I speak no German and I work 80% with my current employer.    
Now to my situation - since being in Basel I feel I have a lot more time on my hands compared to when I was living in London, so I have taken to doing things that I would not normally have the time to do, these are mainly pampering myself with Beauty treatments i.e. doing my own fake nails, pedi, mani, waxing, facials etc...the reason I did this is I struggled to find someone in Basel who did the job properly or to the standard I am used to (I am quite picky with beauty treatments and I am sorry to any qualified beauticians) and thought I could do this myself.  So I did. From time to time  people comment on my nails and ask where I go and I say I did them myself, same with my mani, pedi etc. This has got me thinking and I would like to go back to the UK to train as Beautician.   
And to my questions - does anyone feel like Basel is lacking good Beauticians at reasonable prices? Would this be of interest to people? Or could I be wasting my time?   
I have discussed with friends already who think it is a good idea. If all works well, I will do a few courses this summer and then look to do treatments in my spare time and day off, mobile or at my home and then the price list will be based be similar to UK converted into CHF.   
Look forward to any advice and I will keep you posted on my training

My point is, most of the time you do have the time to use both and even try to swim or try to cut out of it.  Again too many variables to say anything with certainty.

Okay.....if it isn't too late to avoid being anal I will say this. 
The Asian dude bought a specific pair of glasses from CRC (most likely as why else would he make a review on their store?) So in my view he is obviously reviewing the glasses they sent him and since he bought them in Europe and intend to put them on his Chinese face, they will not fit well (as CRC sells the European model and not the Asian model).   
If a reviewer of a lens xxx "feels" that the lens is sharper than xxx, he is right. Not that the lens is sharper but that he feels that it is sharper despite any test saying opposite. If he had wrote that the lens "is" sharper he would be wrong.    
So any review have to be sorted into "facts" and "feelings" because even though I read reviews myself in order to learn about other peoples experience with a specific product, it is important so know what is facts related to a product and what is a personal opinion.   
See.....I had to be anal

X-bionic is "functional" compression under garments and will have little effect on warmth vs classic odlo or whatever but is purposefully really tight to lower fatigue and help recovery.    
I've never tried more than compression socks, but most people who try those from xbionic or other makes are positive that they do help. I will certainly be using mine on the slopes this year, as I think lowering the swelling and expansion of the lower legs will avoid ski boot discomfort.   
As to whether its worth the money that's your call.  Just like you can get a 10 CHF watch to tell you the time...

post:
In mountaineering the thought is "climb high, sleep low".   
Even if you aren't training just being at altitude for the days before the race will help out.  But you loose acclimatization fast, so if you can you should stay slightly below your race altitude at least the day before.  Don't go all the way back into the valley.   
I've done a fair bit of high altitude mountaineering.  What works best for me is to drink a lot of water and gain altitude slowly.  The better hydrated you are the less chance you'll get headaches.  And if that fails, try some ibuprofen and relax.  And it that fails, it's time to descend.   
You'll be in the AMS zone altitude-wise, but it sounds like you're training pretty seriously, and as long as you listen to your body you should be fine.

for a similar reason to you.   
It was a cheap bike and wasn't worth the money to fix it.   
Fixies are pretty hard to ride, and the whole 'fixed' thing freaks me out a bit. It seems to be a whole lot of trouble for the benefits fixie riders say it's worth.   
My gears were crap, and rather than replace the derailer, I just shortened the chain to the most common gear I used.   
Obviously the bike was stupidly light afterwards which was great, and I've since seen other people who also just buy a single gear cog, and spacer unit to fully replace the rear cassette. I just didn't want to spend anthing on the bike.       
I kept the brake cables, solid freewheeling single gear racer...... great bike now.

Hi thaider   
Have you started training already ? Just curious about your experience!

Stoos is brilliant for the views.  Not so for beginner skiers.   
For pre-intermediate + skiers, Fronalpstock has excellent runs, especially in the morning.  They become slushy in the afternoon as the sun warms the slopes.  Some of the best views in Kanton Schwyz can be seen from the top of Fronalpstock.     
Klingenstock is fantastic for intermediate + skiers.  Not many people and steeper slopes.  The butt-warming chairlift in cold weather adds to the enjoyment of the day.   
If you can barely snowplow or make turns, the only lift advisable is Sternegg, located in the middle of the village.

Did you find a running club?  The hash runs are good but starting locations do vary.   
Otherwise, this one looks interesting and is based near Enge or in summer at Saalsportshalle which is easy from Adliswil.

post:
I think Zermatt, Saas Fee, or Glacier 3000 are the only options in Switzerland.    
Many pro skiers come to train in the summer. In Zermatt 1 piste is taken up with gates, one is made into a world cup mogul course, which leaves 1 piste and the park for free skiers. The lifts are open from 0630-1300, it takes with the large queues 1 - 1.5 hours to get up there. So you need to stay the night before. Also it is prone to high winds and regularly doesn't open which is frustrating!   
Everywhere in Switzerland is reachable by public transport. Zermatt has a train station, Saas Fee you get the train to Stalden-Saas then get a bus.

post:
I don't think it is underhand. Did you miss the bit where I said   The taking of photos of people   is a bit off though.       Yes, they often do. E.g. at Engelberg, all five of us have to queue to get the tickets, as we have two adults, one student, one youth and a child - all requiring verification, and must be present at time of purchase.       Specifically, I've been at Ski Amadé (Austria). They   require a photograph for day passes less than 9 days.  In the ten different resorts I've stayed at over the last ten years in four different countries, I've never had a photocard for a 4/5/6 day card. I discussed this on a skiing forum, and most people there were surprised at the requirement.   
What's really stupid, and probably why they don't mention that they photograph you through the barriers, is that if you want to cheat the system, it's really simple. The two of you just need to be of similar build and wear similar clothes/helmets/scarves.

post:
Hmm. I have been skiing since my 6th, and have been taking lessons until after my 25th. My wife has been skiing for 4 seasons, and my 9y/o kids outski her. Anyway, here is my 0.02p.   
Hire a private instructor for the both of you. My kids learned from a french ski instructor without knowing one word of french. Language is not important, you should not be talking anyway. Learning how to ski is done by example, and then try to reproduce it one step at a time.    
"Variation" of skislopes is BS for beginners. You will not be able to enjoy the panorama nor the "variation" of the skislope until you know how to brake, how to turn, how to avoid colliding into each other, how to fall, and then how to get up again. It is all part of the learning curve, and it should be fun. If it is not fun, get another instructor. Once you know how to do all that and still enjoy yourself, only then start looking for "nicer" slopes and bigger ski areas.    
Usually, absolute beginners would start with moving around on skis on a flat area. One ski, then two skis. Learn how to climb a small hill using your skis (and not take the lift). Learn how to get down that small hill while staying vertical. Learn the pizzapoint, and move on to parallel skiing after a few years. Only a very few areas teach parallel skiing from the start with relatively short (1.20m) skis, and progressively move to longer skis when skills improve. More expensive.   
Anyway, all of that can be done in all ski areas. You will only know whether there is chemistry between you and the ski instructor after you have met him/her. As mentioned, just change instructors if he doesn't fullfill all your needs (there is a limit though). As long as you don't expect to ski down a red slope after 1 week you should be fine. After 5 days 2h/day instruction most people are able to navigate down a blue slope without too many falls.   
I don't know either of Pizol/Sattel areas. Just pick the one where you can get the easiest/quickest. Or, if costs are an issue, where costs are the lowest. The advantage of a slightly larger area, like Sorenberg, Flumserberg, Brig, Engelberg, is that they have more ski instructors. Usually they are also slightly more expensive.    
Make sure to get a good ski outfit, because if you are cold you will definitely not like it, however good the ski instructor.    
Arriving at around 9-10am is not early. Most lifts open at 8:45am. Most courses would start at 10am, but hiring a private ski instructor would probably allow you to pick your hours yourself. Also, take into account that it may take quite some time to get from the railway station up to the slopes. Are you going to rent your skis? Do you still need to fit shoes? The first day, that may take an hour or two as well, depending on the popularity of the place.

I imagine all sorts of factors come into play, such as location (ie level of rents), cash reserves etc. Another factor my local shop is citing is that they find it really hard to find apprentices for a niche market in the first place, and even if they do, they don't tend to hang around as the prefer to try and set up on their own elsewhere, so they're suffering from the costs of training people then losing them as well as succession issues. Likewise, just because shops in Engelberg - which probably have a bigger concentration of potential customers in resort than my local shop - can sell at lower prices, doesn't mean that is the norm either.

It can be detrimental. If you have probs with knees, best is to run on softer grounds. Threadmill really useful here. With time, and some weights training, you get stronger muscels around the ligaments, then you can start running on harder ground. But best to avoid concrete - it is much harder than tarmac.    
Also, including some uphill parts during your runs helps with strengthening your knees.    
The trick is to take it easy, build up gradually and listen to your body... and enjoy our run.    
Cycling as countertraining is also recommended.

I own the Lightning Ascent 25". Have really abused them and they are great for climbing.   
Just so you know, in the MSR LA range, there are the 22" women's model (they are cut differently), the 25" mens and the 30" mens.   
Assuming your friend is a man, the choice is 25" or 30". Some of it depends on the height and weight, and as well the planned usage. The 30" is useful in really deep snow (especially if the person is heavier). The 25" will be easier for the climbing (if you decide to climb up a ski hill for example).

Yes, you should get a medical. The BSAC makes the following additional recommendations about when it is appropriate for Asthmatics to dive:   
Asthma may predispose to pulmonary barotrauma and air embolism, which may be fatal. An acute asthma attack can also cause severe dyspnoea which may be hazardous or fatal during diving. However, there is no evidence that the mild, well-controlled allergic asthmatic is at significantly more risk.   
Asthmatics may dive if they have allergic asthma, but not if they have cold, exercise or emotion induced asthma.   
Ashtmatics should not dive if they have any chest symptoms, have needed a therapeutic bronchodilator in the last 48 hours, or regularly need to use a bronchodilator.    
During the diving season the asthmatic should take bd peak flows. A deviation of 10% from best values should exclude diving until within 10% of best values for at least 48 hours before diving.   
== ==

As far as logistics go, getting to quite a few resorts is easy from Basel either by train using the sbb snow n rail discount, this is easy and the stations have storage facilities, I take my boots and skis on the train, or you can use the snownrail discount at intersports shops.  And nowhere is particularly far by car.  
This is a very useful website.

post:
I purchased my boots from Jelmoli this year and as far as I am aware, no, they do not do what you want.   
They do a very basic fitting service, but better than say Athleticum, whereby you just pick up off shelf and buy.   
I was evaluating the whole "custom boot" spec now that I am skiing a lot and before going all out I wanted to try a cheaper option i.e cheaper than 1,000-1,500 CHF.   
I discussed my ski style, where i get pain (outer right foot) and what type of skiing I will be doing.    
He took measurements, identified the wide point on my right foot where I said yep, thats where i get pain, and then picked 4 boots with the widest spec. I tried them all on, and went with the ones I felt most comfortable in after walking about for few mins in each.    
He then heated them on a machine and I wore them for 15-20mins around the store. We then put in medium arch footbeds (not a custom footbed).   
The boots gave me a lot of grief on day one this season. Day two I didnt have them as they were at the shop with skis for service so used my old boots. Day 3, I played about with the bindings and effectively just used them to secure the boot rather than tighten the boot as its such a snug fit. Result was a great day skiing pain free.   
Sounds like you need a filler, like a sponge, some people use these to pad out space in boots. Alternatively, as Ace said, mouled liner, but these are expensive, but by all accounts, well worth it if you want to invest that amount of money.   
Oh, the service I received was free and I only paid the cost price of the boots...490..I think....Salomon Quest 110

Funny video. But it shows exactly what would happen. Most tough guys with a bit of muscle think they can automatically fight and that the weight difference will be sufficient to win. But a)most guys without training cannot fight at all, they can hardly land a decent punch (try it in front of a mirror and look how ridiculous and clumsy it looks   ) and b) you will be much to slow to land any hits, any fighter with a few years of training will see your hits coming from a mile, you would have to land a lucky punch, fat chances of that. C) Your body is not conditioned to take hits, especially kicks to the leg and body, a few of those and you're completely gassed out and limping. So a tall that is only slightly lighter but taller than you would easily take you out in the first round.

Lads and Ladies,   
GAA, Gaelic Football, Ladies Gaelic Football, Hurling and Camogie have all grown significantly in the last few months and years all over Switzerland.   
Zurich still has a damn good Camogie and Hurling team and they train and play all the way through the spring and summer. they always look for new members so come and play.   
Zurich has a mens and ladies gaelic football team that has won some serious silverware this year and they also recently had their 10th anniversary game with over 40 players men and women taking the field.   
Saint Gallen Bears are tipping away with about 13 men and 4 or 5 girls. come and join   
Geneva Gaels played in their first european tournament in maastricht with 13 or so men. get in contact, get involved   
Basel have the start of a team maybe. Players in Luzern, Aarau, Neuchatel, Bern, Freibourg and down in the Italian area have all been in contact.   
At the last european tournament of the year they were over 60 players representing switzerland there (48 men and 13 ladies)   
There are people all over Switzerland involved now from all ages.   
Four members of the European County Board live in Switzerland so we are trying our best to grow it all over at all ages and levels. we are working on securing funding to help grow this project from youth all the way up. we hope to have a swiss cup next year in maybe hurling, football and ladies football so it would be amazing to get as many people involved as we can.
Grindewald

post:
All good tips, another one is Swiss alpine club (SAC/CAS), they usually do little bit more advanced stuff like glacier treks, skitouring in winter, trainings etc. Drawback is paid membership (~170/year, every canton has different prices - don't ask me why), the way they organize events few months in advance is far from ideal (at least from what I heard). You will also get discount on Swiss huts accommodation.   
Or - you can do it like me (sometimes) - get a good & lightweight camping equipment and go by yourself. 15 kg backpack is not that limiting, and if it is you'll get a good training and improvement in strength & stamina   Plus if heading for peaks you can leave it somewhere below and do the summit lightweight (great feeling & speed). 
There are no dangers in that - bears are only animals that might pose a danger to lone trekker in europe and they are not present in these parts of alps as far as I know. Camping in the middle of nowhere under super-starry sky is simply amazing - and if you find other people to participate fun is doubled

This is a group for people in the Lausanne region who would like to have the opportunity to run socially and have a (optional) drink after.   
This is a run group is for all levels and abilities. Anyone who wants to get out of the gym and enjoy the outdoors in this beautiful place - and its very motivating to run in a group.   
The group meets every Wednesday at 7pm by the three headed water "fountain" next to the pedaloes/Chateau in Ouchy. Bring a 10 CHF note and we can all grab a beer or coke at the MGM bar afterwards...   
Looking forward to seeing you!

Hello there!   
I've just moved to Zürich from London and I'm excited about getting into life here.   
My Partner and I just got married this summer in Ticino. He is Swiss and I am British.    
We are both architects and have our own practice and right now we're offering free quote for any scale of project.   
If you have a project in mind and are unsure of it's feasibility, drop us a PM and we can help you.   
I'm also interested in running a yoga morning at our flat once a week.   
Before opening our practice I worked for a very large & renowned practice in London which offered a great yoga course in the evenings.    
When I came to Switzerland I realised that most yoga courses charge high rates comparatively and it's not so inspirational practicing yoga by yourself all the time so, I propose that all lovers of yoga meet up for a morning session, some tea and a get together.   
Drop me a mail if you're interested.   
Have a wonderful day!

Usually Swiss univertities organize ski camp in winter, everyone can join but students have cheaper price. For example, Geneva university has ski camp annually:     
I heard there is the same one in EPFL and Uni Lausanne and guess other uni should have sort of it.

Are you only going to ski 3 days the whole season? or is this for guests?   
I agree that the resorts for a few days aren't any more expensive really than other places plus you can take them back and change things when they don`t work out (like some boots for a guest of mine last year).   
If you plan on doing 2 days here, 3 days there, etc it will make sense to rent for the season.   
The rental cost of skis is most expensive for 1 day and then gets a lot lower as you rent for more days. Makes sense as they spend all their time measuring you for skis, boots, setting the bindings, the skis are waxed etc.

Hello Everyone,    
My Name is Steve and I coach a Women's Hockey club in Villars sur Ollon (Vaud).I am currently looking for female players to complete my roster.     
The only obligation is to have a valid working visa (B or C) so you can register with the league.     
The league is the Female national League C (west) we practice ounce a week and strating in november will have games every 2 weeks or so.     
The level of players ranges from beginner to intermidiate.  ages varies from 14  to 40 years old.     
Playing in a club is a great way to merge into the swiss culture, exercise and have fun playing the greatest game on earth.     
You miss the Ice, you want to meet new people and have some fun dooing it, you know someone who could be interested  send me a PM ( Private Message ) via this site.
Thanks again!  I will check these places out.

Hello   
A friend has asked if I can spread the word about pony club games.  She runs a couple of pony club games (mounted games) teams and is looking for more riders to bring on and perhaps make up a 3rd team.  There is no age limit to pony games in Switzerland with many different age categories.     
She is based in Wila, Kanton Zurich and is hoping to promote and encourage new teams to start up.     
You dont need a pony, but you do need to be able to ride, and looking to have fun as part of a team.  Non german speaking is not a problem.     
If you are not sure what the games are you can always come along to the Swiss Pony Games final next Sunday in Inwil Lu.   
Please PM me if you have any questions, or are interested in the pony games.

If anyone is interested in mountaineering and would like to add a little extra to by going in vintage gear and outfit (1920s to 1940s) please PM me and I can fill you in onmore of the details.   
I'm part of a club that does this and sometimes we got a larger group or just a couple. There are routes for all levels from going up to a hut and having a little grill night to going on a multi day trek past the 3000-4000m mark all done just like they did 70 years ago but still very safe. We pay attention to detail though as we want to escape from the mordern world and live a simple live for a day or longer. Of course we have the modern safety items (such as a cell to call REGA) but we keep that out of sight as we don't want to ruin the impression. So nailed boots, breeches, funny hats and good, real food! But maybe some funny looks if others see us      
But I should add that the places you will see....you will remember for the rest of your life along with the expereices you will have. Our club knows some really speacial places, no matter what the skill level, but be expected to get a little freindly push once in awhile to get yourself to "higher goals".   
Ladies: our club would be more than happy to welcome you, and don't worry, we don't bite, we're really a good bunch of gentlemen.   
If you're still interested by this point...let me know. All languages welcome but main languages are English, French and German.

Snooker tables seem to be getting more scarce in Lucerne. There's 'The Tom's' in Ebikon that is great for pool & darts (had snooker tables there until a couple of years ago.    
The Pink Billino in Emmenbrücke has pool tables and 2 well maintained snooker tables.    
The next place would be in Cham (Zugerland Sports) which has pool and 2 x snooker tables. The National in Littau is the home of the Swiss Snooker Association. Here you can pay membership which then entitles you to a key, providing unlimited (including out of hours) access to the club.   
Or do you mean buying one?

I have skied it regularly and it is a really good location with mostly intermediate slopes.    
The main issue is if the season is not so good with less snow then the lower height of this resort does mean it is not so good but with good snow its brilliant. It can also be a bit foggy and icy near the bottom at times. I guess the other thing to consider is that if you ski the Chasserugg area there is a rather long t-bar that gets a bit tiring espcially on cold periods as your feet dont get respite from the cold ground.   
However it remains one of my favorite and from schaufhaussen you should be there in under 1 hour by car

Been working with The Ski Company in Torgon for years, organising ski trips for school, and mixed groups of friends of all ages- both skiers and snowboarders.   
The Ski Company has some weeks when they are not full, and are happy to take on small groups of 'fillers'. These dates won't be known for a while yet- but should be clear around November - these are only available for long-term customers/contacts.   
 They also organise ski weeks for kids 13+ February half-term- mainly kids from the UK so would be great for any English speaking children living in CH. As they have separate apartments for adults, they might be able to accommodate whole families for those dates.   
Would some of you be interested in forming a EF group - Torgon links with the Portes du Soleil - and the pass includes Torgon, Chapelle d'Abondance, Chatel and Super Chatel + Morgins, so a huge area. The ski and snowboarding hire is great quality and in-house, ski/snowboarding school and lift 50 m from chalet- all English speaking staff (UK, OZ + NZ). And with prices that can't be beaten, especially for those 'filler' weeks organised by long-term contacts.         BTW they are still looking for staff for this coming season. Salary is very poor, but accom and food free, ski/snow equipment + ski pass thrown in - and loads of time to spend in the snow every day but change day.

Hi all,   
I am a capoeira professor with +4 years of experience teaching (+7 practicing) 
I am living in St-Prex right now and I want to start teaching in the area. Anybody interested? please tell me your contact details, where you live as well as your availability so we can work something out.   
For those who want to know a bit more about our capoeira: 
The group is Abada-Capoeira based in Rio de Janeiro, Brasil founded by Mestre Camisa almost 25 years ago. 
The largest and most pedagogically advanced capoeira organization in the world, present in the 5 continents and all states of Brazil.  
for those who know already about capoeira: we learn Sao bento grande, Benguela, Angola and iuna  
we learn to play all the instruments (berimbau, atabaque, pandeiro and agogo) and to sing in portuguese. 
Classes should normally be in portuguese but I speak eng, spa and ger (unfortunately only basic french)   
We play a fast, more dangerous capoeira, we throw kicks in the opposite direction and learn many takedowns. You need to ALWAYS keep your eyes open and dodge! but the best part is the community: we are a family!   
We train hard as it can be, sometimes people from other sports can't keep up with our warm up!  
(but you can make stops is you need to, don't worry)   
"Força, sabedoria, energia e paciência"   
Graduado Sonic

There are various free locations around zurich with air compressors for bike tires.   
I know of one at bellevue (between Terrasse and the river) and one at Helvetiaplatz (by the 32 bus stop direction limmatplatz).     
They're very easy to use, and have a pressure gauge. Read the value on the sides of your tire and inflate in short spurts of air watching the pressure gauge until the desired pressure. And make sure the gauge is working (needle moving).

The via ferrata Farinetta    is located inside the Gorge de la Salentze, a tight and quite panoramic canyon with waterfalls above Saillon, and is named after some Italian/Swiss kinda-Robin-Hood guy, who died there trying to escape the police:    It is composed of two parts, a first and easier part of 2 hours and a second (optional and more difficult) part of another ~1h30. I found also a video which might give you a better idea of what to expect:    Participants are supposed not to have fear of hight and to come duly equipped with:  - harness + assurance for via ferrata - climbing helmet (bike ones are not recommended, but acceptable) - good hiking shoes (i.e. with vibram sole) - climbing gloves (biking ones should again be ok) - (optionally) a   backpack with some water and chocolate
Just seen their price for Racing Ralphs....rep on your way even though it wasn't remotely aimed at me!

I wouldn't worry about the 2012/13 models, it's just a paint job generally (obviously not always)   
Bikes can be rather expensive (I bought my cervelo tt bike from Germany over the internet for about half the price of a similar bike in CH). Canyon do some good bikes, focus too, though not sure re dealers. Shimano ultegra is probably the best value components.    
However, really, most important is a bike that fits you, and that you like the look of. There isnt really that much of a difference in performance. Its all about the engine    
Get measured properly, chat to some good bike shops - not sure where you are but if ZRH then tempo, backyard, veloatelier, thomus etc and speak to the guys, maybe get a proper fitting (pay for it) and narrow the choice down that way. And make sure you have a indoor trainer  for the winter

Switzerland is a good deal more populated in Canada, making the value of registration less. You have to look to find a trail that doesn't get walked over regularly in the summer. Also, cell phones don't work everywhere in the mountains, but you normally have signal when you have a view of a valley.   
All that said, people do die in the Swiss alps, and not just from BASE jumping.   
As mentioned, the "Zurich Hiking and Outdoor" group on meetup is fairly active. They generally don't do anything technical, but the hikes are not professionally guided tours either and Swiss terrain can be steep. The   is also something to consider, especially if you want to do more technical or otherwise intense things.   
Occasionally there have been attempts to arrange hiking meets with this forum, to the best of my knowledge they haven't had great turnouts.

Eventually got the one from Manor (Challenger 2), tested it out on Lago Maggiore last week. Was fine for the kids playing around in altho steering it was a bit difficult at times and we did tend to go around in circles fairly often,but they had great fun so that's all that matters.

The second Zug Corporate 6-a-side league is shortly to begin and an  open training session and social evening will take place on Friday 24th August at Kantonsschule Zug, Lüssiweg 6302 Zug for a kick-off at 1830.  
The objective of this event is to allow teams from last season's competition to dust off the cobwebs and for new players and teams to come and get a feel for the conditions of the competition.  
The league is scheduled to begin the week after on August 31st, and there is still space for up to 3 more teams, so please invite any friends/colleagues that might be interested in playing.   
After the games, at approximately 20.30, all of the players are welcome (and encouraged!) to visit the Mr Pickwick Pub in Zug for a post-match drink.    Additional Info: Registration and payment details can be requested by interested participants separately.

Following my attempt to terminate my membership of the Formhaus GmbH gym and health club in Basel last year I reluctantly accepted that I had not followed the letter of their procedures for leaving the gym and paid up for another year. I wasn't happy and frankly felt their behaviour was not only bad customer service, but a bit sneaky as they did not even tell me my membership was due for renewal until afterwards, when I got a demand for payment.    
This year I carefully did as instructed for terminating membership and sent a letter by recorded delivery well in advance of my subscription end date, followed up by a copy letter in an email. However Formhaus deny receiving the letter (I still have the post office receipt and frankly I doubt that it did not arrive), they do not accept the emailed letter and rather sniffilly tell me that they do not accept my resignation.   
My inclination is just to ignore them, but I don't know what leverage they have and in which way they might claim I made some infraction of their resignation requirements. From feeling like an innocent abroad I now feel like the victim of a mugging.   
Frankly I did not think Formhaus was a good gym. I found the equipment limited and the staff all a little creepy.
Athleticum is my favourite sports store, and is consistently cheaper than the others mentioned here. I bought my rollerblades there last year and they were very helpful

Cavendish will never win le Tour - he's not quick enough up the mountains or in the time-trials - so I don't believe that he sacrificed it for Wiggins.   His role is to win individual stages during the sprint finish, which he is very good at (ranked fourth in the overall classification of stage wins).   On stages when he is likely the have a chance Wiggins and the others go all out to make sure he is in with a chance.   On the days when he is not likely to be a contender the roles are reversed and he has to play the domestique role.   
He's entitled to disappointed as he was labelled the 'favorite' by many at the start, but giving away the strategy to the opponents openly is always a mistake!

i would like to advertize the existence of our badminton group here in Lausanne. we play every wednesday (except during school holidays) from 20-22 close to La Sallaz in the gym of the school Coteau-Fleuri, Chemin de la Grangette 77, 1010 Lausanne. we have 3 courts. we play for fun and players of all different levels are very welcome to join us.  
the fee depends on the number of people present, but is very low: we pay 10 CHF per hour FOR THE WHOLE GYM.  
so far, we charged 35 CHF per semester for subscribers, 5 CHF per session for visitors. sounds like unfair competition, i know. well, it is    
it would be great to see some of you there! just drop me a mail and we can arrange the logistics.   
cheers,

Are you based in the   area and keen to play some   (or „Landhockey“ as it is known in Switzerland)?   
Then come along to training and introduce yourself!   
The   is always looking for new hockey players and reinforcements for all squads. We have two mens teams, a ladies team as well as Junior & Senior sections. We have a diverse, international mix of players, welcoming in recent years players from Germany, Holland, England, Ireland, Scotland, South Africa, Argentina & Austria amongst others. So there is usually more than one language heard in the changing room!   
Men‘s 1st XI plays in National League A both outdoors & indoors (the highest league).   
Outdoor Season: Aug-Oct / Mar-Jun 
Indoor Season: Nov-Jan   
For more information just visit our website on

. Every Sunday, let's go hiking (a gradient of 800 meters, 3 hours hike-up). Meeting at 10 am at the terminus of bus No 8 at Veyrier-Douane (not at Veyrier-Tournettes, 100 metres from the border direction Switzerland, departure at 10H05). A responsible (excursion leader) of the Association Genevoise des Amis du Saleve (AGAS) welcomes you in all weather. No prior registration necessary. Depending on the route chosen, you will expect a 5 to 8 hours hike. Hiking boots (crampons in winter, hat and solar protection lotion in summer), raincoat or umbrella, passport, money, picnic and something to drink as well as good health are indispensable.

Our next 6-a-Side league is due to start on Friday 31 August. The first league was a great success, and we are now looking for new teams and players.   
Matches are played on a Friday evening on the astroturf pitch at the Kantonsschule in Zug (Lüssiweg, behind the Metalli). The games are competitive but fair and friendly. The league will last for approx. 7-8 weeks, depending on the number of teams registered.   
Fuller details can be found on our facebook page        
If you are interested in playing, please pm me or get in touch asap via the FB page or website. Full teams are obviously welcome, but we're also happy to help individuals and/or smaller groups of players to get involved and join a team. Whether you can make every week or not isn't too important - the idea being to have a bigger squad of players from which to call on the 6-8 players needed for each match. The league offers a great opportunity to play competitively, have fun, keep fit, make new friends, and enjoy the odd post-match drink.   
Any questions, let me know, and I hope to hear from you soon!    
Thanks   
Daniel 
Super6Swiss.ch

post:
Not trying to preach to those you feel they need to use them but:   
I firmly believe that unless you are are suffering (or recovering) from a medical condition which prevents absorption of specific vitamins or nutrients, then as long as you eat a healthy balanced diet, you don't need to spend money on supplements.     
The supplement industry (like the diet food industry*) has created a product that people now think they need and cannot live without - clever and very lucrative for them, but unnecessary for us.   
I know people on here consume this stuff because they say they haven't got time to eat properly but in this case perhaps they need to change their priorities.   
A lot of studies have also shown that some of these substances do absolutely nothing for you and others are actually harmful.   
Of course some have been shown to be beneficial -  including folic acid for pregnant women.   
On one of the supplement threads - one of the posts said some thing like, "Oh, my supplements are coming tomorrow and I can't wait !".  Get a life, I say.   
It's more to do with the fact that people think they can get a quick fix for their own limitations.   
*Low fat - but high in sugar etc so not good for you at all.

post:
2k seem about right, but there's massive variety of factors. It could be as much as 50% out I recon.   
Also, re: "two bananas" - that's not the energy your using. You are actually running in deficit - the same goes for your fluid levels (especially if its hot).    
You're only replacing some of the carb/glycogen stores with two bananas - if at all. Chances are, if the pace is sensible and you have a fair amount of condition, you might actually be burning a lot of fat or Glycogen stores.   
FYI - I also use a 705. Todays run: 
Body weight: 80kg 
Road ride - 30km 
Av Spd: 36kph 
elevation gain: 95m elevation loss: 300 (ie it's a downhill run!) 
Average HR: 147bpm 
Average cadence: 87rpm 
Calories: 1,200   
PS: Babenas...An average HR of 158bpm??? Wow, that's beasting it...

1200m Sprints!? Wow! Typically I just run a ladder work out. Well for the Iron man I dont know how much you will sprint (I dont know how these things work) but for lung capacity you might want to make a day trip up the mountain and torture your lungs a bit

the valle verzasca, just north of locarno, is amazing and it all starts/ends at a very large dam (it was used in some james bond film - not sure which one cuz i don't watch them).  there are numerous trails (varying difficulty) throughout the valley.  a major trail runs parallel to the river and it is very doable for kids and the elderly (well marked). there are many waterfalls and a farm with reindeer (i think), and even a trailside honey stand (i kid you not). An added bonus - along the trail north of lavertezzo there is a exhibit of really cool, funky sculptures.  it is really beautiful and amazing and relatively flat.  In the three weeks since arriving i have hiked to the top of mt lego and walked along the river from levertezzo to ganne.  not sure about the precise distance from zurich but it should fall within your stated time parameters. enjoy, and be sure to bring your camera.

Bumper plates can act as a safety mechanism - but I've found that dumping heavier (for me!!) squats can cause some problems. I had to dump a 260 lbs load a few weeks ago, and I twisted my left elbow letting it go. No major damage, but it was inflamed for a couple days.    
Since then I've noticed that you can use a second set of construction stands as safety rails. Just set up the second pair behind the ones being used to rack the barbell; put them to a height just below bar level at the bottom of your squat. I lift with a friend right now, but I actually prefer my "safety rails" to him spotting when I'm pushing my boundaries on squats. (Just don't starting dropping the bar from any kind of height. The stands can't take that much.)   
BTW, I think you've already picked up on this, but advntur/Jeff Grant is right in your backyard, and he has a complete rig, not to mention being a great coach. Nothing in the world like lifting with company ...

Thanks!   
Fewer than in winter - and, well, colorful. My daughter and I discovered five different species:   
1) The pro skier. They're up there because they have a career to get off the ground. Stick to themselves and talk about anything but skiing, except with their coaches.   
2) The wacky tourist. They just happen to be in the area and suddenly think, "Hey, instead hiking like normal people, let's go ski!" There were two complete beginners from the UK with an instructor. They spent an entire day sliding down head first and admiring the scenery. (Pretty inspirational, actually.)    
3) The fanatical skier. Not necessarily very good, but obsessive-compulsive about skiing. Just DYING to talk to the pros about proper hip to knee angles when carving at 63 kph. (Probably the reason the pros seem a little shy and nervous.)   
4) The radical park dude. Ride down backwards and turn double back-flip-twisty things while rolling a joint with one hand and filming themselves with the other. Some of the boarders may have thought they were actually  on skateboards. Friendlier than the pros - and they get to the slope later.   
5) The civilized mountaineer. Hairy people who spend the entire morning skiing up the side of the piste carrying ice picks, ropes, flares, tents and rubber rafts. Presumably, they then disappear into glaciers or climb up  sheer rock faces - but I suspect that they actually just ski back down the piste once and go home again.   
(All in good fun ... )

That's about right for summer prices which are valid in some less popular places but the court hire is very seldom included in the hourly rate. Expect to pay: CHF60-80 for a decent one-on-one lesson. Most definitely the charges do not include tennis courts in winter. Just as an example of   sports center which is a very popular hub for expats living in Aargau and Zurich with tennis, squash and badminton facilities. The certified Swiss coach will charge you as much as CHF100-130 plus tennis court CHF35-65 depending on time of the day. My wife is in business and we lowered our prices quite a bit to be able to tailor the rates to expats taste and expectations, who initially are shocked by local rates but after exploring the market, they will realize that those are the common running rates in Switzerland.

The sun is shining, the birds are singing, great weather is finally starting...time to get on the crags!   
3 years ago I was the organizer of the Switzerland Outdoor rock climbing meetup group, and we had a nice group going climbing almost every weekend during the summers.   
Then life happened, I moved away, and couldn't maintain the group anymore.    
Well, now I'm back in Switzerland and it is summer again! So, I've rescued and re-started the group. Please check out our meetup page and join the group to meet other like-minded rock climbers and find out about our outings. The first one this year will take place next Sunday at Roches d'Orvin. Links here:       
and     
Note also that we climb all over Switzerland, and though I'm personally based in Bern, you don't have to be a Bern local to join (the group has climbed as far as the Jura, Geneva, Oberland, and even Tessin area, so there's stuff for everyone).    
Beginners most welcome! Also adventure hikers (we often have trips to fun via ferratas at all levels, i.e. Rotstock, Kandersteg, etc).   
And...if you want to organize an outing yourself, the group settings allow you to do so. You don't have to go through the organizer if you want to announce a cool spontaneous climbing outing to the list.    
Anyway, that's all I'll say for now before EF bans me for too much group self-promotion. I'm just announcing it here cuz we used to have a bunch of EFrs showing up, and everyone knows the EF people are the most fun to talk to, right?    
CU on the rock!

post:
Hi,   
I'm training to be a chartered sports psychologist, and I have an assignment to complete as part of my masters program.   
I need to perform an intake interview with an athlete, we could explore issues like using imagery, self-talk, relaxation skills, and goal setting  these are all core techniques used by successful elite and recreational athletes worldwide, and extensive empirical evidence supports their effectiveness; these are the things that separate the winners from also-rans.  The output could be in the form of a report (for your personal use only, not shared elsewhere) recommending strengths to leverage, ideas for areas to work on, and reference material supporting follow-ups.  What I can't do is then work with you on a continuing basis to address these things; the way sports psychology is regulated I am not allowed to 'practice' until fully qualified.   
The session would be filmed but footage would be confidential and only seen by my tutors. If this is interesting drop me a PM and we can get into further details. Meanwhile, here's some info on work done with Sir Chris Hoy:       
Cheers John
thread: Boost your performance - volunteer serious athlete sought

Hi all,                It's coming around to that time of the season again where the sun comes out and so does the rugby ball. If your new to Lausanne and looking to meet new people and join in on the social life, or just looking for a summer game to get outside and enjoy yourself then touch footy/rugby is the way to go.    This year the Swiss Touch Association has organised Touch football fun days all around Switzerland to promote the sport & bring people together. They have reserved this year, the beautiful location of the Rugby Field in Dorigny on Saturday 19th May (located on Route Cantonale, opposite the University of Lausanne), to bring the ever growing sport to Lausanne. There will be members of the national squad for the Swiss Touch European Championship this year there to help, as well as coaches and players from other cantons in Switzerland. This day is aimed at all levels of touch footy/rugby experience from beginners to experts, from all ages including children, and it's purely to promote the game and to introduce new people to the sport. The beauty of this sport is, it's for both males and females to play together. It's a great way to meet new people as well as getting in some good fun exercise in the sun. There will be a bar-be-que and drinks on offer, with a demonstration game, some coaching / skills session to help you understand the game or play it better, then we will break up into teams and play a round robin on the day to end it off. All for the nominal cost including some food of CHF10.     To RSVP or If you have any questions please feel free to email :     coaching@swisstouch.org      Looking forward to seeing you there........

post:
So, quick report on the cycling in Ticino:   
1. It rained 80% of the time. That sucked, but I still managed to get in three rides by keeping an eye on the radar pictures. Although during one ride I got soaked twice and ended up shivering down on the descent.   
2. AMAZING area for cycling! Totally recommended, and the pdf (see earlier posts) was invaluable. The hotel had an original copy in large form that I took with me.   
3. Bring your ID/passport - so much fun being able to ride into Italy    
4. There are a few direct trains each day to Locarno, which is worth it to not have to bother changing trains with the bike. The bike spots are limited though, so suggest getting to the train station as early as possible. Taxi to Ascona was approx ~28chf with bike.     
This was the only nice weather day of the four day weekend. The gradient in Valle Maggia is quite easy, and part of the ride has separated bike lanes. I used these on the way up, but stuck to the road on the way down. Worth doing though because they take you into the beautiful little towns along the way. 
Val Bavona is much steeper and a good challenge. All the way along you're following the river and there were constant waterfalls at the side, most notable the big one at Foroglio. 
The descent back through Val Bavona is steep and twisty and a lot of fun, but I hit a strong head wind in Valle Maggia and it turned what was supposed to be an easy 20k back into a slog (with a puncture 12k from the end, just to top it off!). Apparently this is not uncommon in Valle Maggia. 
Strava link:      
I waited until a break in the rain on the afternoon of the second day then decided to give this long ride a crack. It was AMAZING. The climb up Val Cannobina starts off quite steep then settles into a managemable gradient. It gets steep again near the end though, and quite narrow. I almost had a heart attack a few times when the drivers came down honking their horns before corners. The first part in the forest is absolutely stunning, again lots of waterfalls and an incredible gorge off to the side with a fast flowing river. 
By the time I reached the top of the 20k climb I was over being wet and cold, and happy to start the descent. And wow! what a descent! It starts of super twisty and steep so I wouldn't recommend doing this ride in the opposite direction. Wet roads and rain made me a bit cautious but can't wait to do this again on a dry day. The towns of Malesco and Re are quite beautiful and worth a stop on a nicer day. 
I stopped over the border for a hot chocolate and some Smarties at the service station, and to warm up a little. Thankfully there weren't many cars at all because after that point there is a brilliant descent through Centovalli. The roads are well maintained and the scenery is awesome. 
Strava link:  
(Note on Strava, the elevation seems to be way out on this ride, refer to the elevation graph not the elevation gain that's quoted.)     
I got up very early to beat the weather on this one, and it was totally worth it. I was able to ride right along the shores of Lago Maggiore on the usual pedestrian path only as there was no-one about. The climb from Tenero to the Contra Dam (James Bond Dam) is pretty intense, but worth it for the photos at the dam - so cool, and totally empty at 7:30am. 
After Contra Dam the gradient is quite relaxed, and the valley climbs and climbs. There is the beautiful village of Lavertezzo along the way, with it's old stone bridge (as seen on postcards of the area). The river was an amazing blue/green colour from all the snowmelt. 
Eventually arrived in Sonogno, which is a well maintained stone village at the very end of the valley. Thankfully even at the early hour the cafe was open and I was able to get another well earned hot choc before starting the descent back to Locarno. 
The descent is AWESOME. The part up until Contra Dam is not too steep but you can still get a bit of speed and it's a really pleasant ride. I was a bit surprised when I reached Lavertezzo so quickly, you forget how much you have climbed. The final descent from Contra Dam to Tenero is not for the faint-hearted, but if you're any good at these kind of steep, twisty roads, it's absolutely brilliant. I was lucky enough not to have any cars near me so I could fang it the whole way down. 
Strava link:    
All up, despite the horrible weather, it was a fantastic weekend. I will definitely be going back there again to re-do the second ride and hopefully try out some of the other rides as well.

Sent you pm.

Yes we ended up staying in Nendaz and skied both there and Siviez with the family.  The village of Nendaz was great, lots to do and really great restaurants.  The drive up the mountain is not for those with a fear of heights   For the skiing I think for true beginners as small children the Siviez set up is better.  We were with 2 three year olds, a five year old, and a 6 year old.  Those stairs in Nendaz with the number of skis we had to carry were not ideal.  However once you are there Tracouet is great for the kids.  Our five year old had a huge tantrum out of fear in the freezing snowstorm in Tracouet the first day and it was not fun getting her and the skis back up the stairs.  The ski instructors needed help getting all the kids and the equipment down the steps.  For our adult friend who is also a beginner, Nendaz was perfect and the stairs were not an obstacle.   
Siviez was a very easy and close drive to ski with everyone.  Parking was not an issue, even during the busy time over the Feb break.  All of the children (and adults) were able to keep their same instructors from Neige Adventure who met us in Siviez.  It was a great experience, with everyone skiing from the top of the mountain by the end, with our littlest happily playing in the nursery at the bottom of the slopes.  The main trail did get very crowded in Siviez however.   
It is best to stay in Nendaz, even with skiing in Siviez I think, because there are more restaurants and things.  The views from all of Nendaz are amazing.   
We never made it to Villars to give any feedback.  Recently though, we did end up in Morzine which was fantastic for families with small children.  It is a lower altitude though, so not sure what it would be like now.   
Thanks for everyone's advice!

For those of you whose children are inconsiderate enough to grow much faster than your wallet allows, every spring there are a number of, what I like to call "bike swap" events throughout this fine land.  
Officially they are called "Velobörse" and you can do your own search in your area, if you don't find anything here.   
You can come along and sell your old bike- you label it with your theoretical price, (the organisers get a small cut) and leave it there for the day. Pick up your cash, or unsold bike at the end of the day. 
And you can buy a pre-loved, new bike for yourself.   
Just like in any market, of course the best ones, at the best price go first. 
Run-arounds usually go for about 50-100 chf. Kids bikes, 5-50 chf. 
A decent racing road-bike.. well, you can find them there too. 
"Follow-me"'s, trailers, babyseats, tricycles.. they often have these there too. Luck of the draw of course.     
Here is a list of a few that are coming up:       
Feel free to add some as you find them.   
And some reviews might be good too.
Do it! You wont be disappointed I promise!

Janine Hug, Lomi Lomi Massage therapist and Body Worker   
I had a pleasure to meet the above mentioned person during the massage workshop this weekend. Janine is very skilled massage therapist/teacher  and a lovely person. After 3 days massage workshop I can't recommend her highly enough.  
She is very laid back and supportive instructor with lots of good energy.  
If you don't speak any German or very little you are still welcome to join as Janine speaks perfect English and can run the courses in both English and German so translating is not a problem, however, the main language is local language so you will also pick up some Schweizerdeutsch during the course which is another benefit.  
She is absolutely passionate about giving and teaching Hawaiian Lomi Lomi massage so if you are looking for Lomi Lomi massage experience as a client or professional Lomi Lomi massage instructor, do not wait any longer and contact Janine.    
Her workshops are not very expensive but she is worth every money and is very busy with clients and teaching. 
After learning about Hawaiian touch you can also attend massage exchange weekends and meet other massage enthusiasts there. This is fantastic opportunity to meet many open minded, friendly, Swiss people. 
Her website:

Hello everyone,   
Since some time now I am interested in learning and practicing wall climbing. I live around Zürich and I found two nice indoor climbing centers Kletterzentrum Milandia in Greifensee and Kletterzentrum Gaswerk in Schlieren. The problem is that I have never done it before, and when I asked for the Grundkurs 1 (the basic climbing course) they recommended me to find an english speaking partner since I am not so fluent in german.   
So, I am wondering if anyone would like to join me, or if anyone has some tips.    
Adrian.

For that same 40chf (maybe a few more) for supplies  and a few YouTube videos you can do it yourself.  It's not that hard to do a good tune, it's actually harder to do a bad tune.   But if your not interested then take it to a board shop and avoid the migros service.

My advice is don't get seduced by the big resorts. If you are real beginner - and need only to master turns - there is not point paying out big bucks when you'll only need the lift half a dozen times.   
Amden/Arvenbuhl is currently in very good condition - although I suspect by the weekend the bottom slope in Amden will begin to suffer from holiday season and the rising temperatures. Arvenbuhl has a chairlift slope - and 2 draglifts - one of which is without camber - and nice and gentle.   
You'll also learn more in 1/2 day with private tuition than in 2 days in a class (IMHO). Once you have the basics get out with friends/colleagues.   
What level are you at?
