Indeed, if a tad hot, though less hot than last year and they gave out sponges at the start. Each of the refreshment stops had a trough to cool yourself. My hubby put a wet sponge under his cap which seemed to help. 
Saw quite a few with cramp, maybe worth trying taking magnesium if you think you might be one of those more likely to suffer from cramp and for gods sake don't ignore the warning signs of muscle twinging that sometimes occur before full on cramp.   
Of the four of us who did it i think we'd all recommend over estimating your finish time to get in the best start block and so reduce the chances of getting stuck behind slower runners on the single track sections, which can be frustrating as over taking isn't easy. 
A simple formular would be to add 30 mins to your normal half marathon time. A expected 3hr finish time puts you in the last/slowest block (5th), 2:45 in the 4th and 2.30 in the 3rd. In reality it took us all an hour longer than a flat course. 
If you want to be particularly competitive then starting near the front of your block and running the course before hand are good ideas. There are all sorts of tactics that could be deployed to this course.   
and lastly we stayed on and enjoyed the area (running and climbing) for the following week which was a splendid idea and highly recommended. 
other fantastic running routes are; 
Belap - Blatten vie Riederalp furka and the new-ish 124m suspension bridge. 
and Ried morel - fiescheralp via the panoramweg.   
both are quite long but  stunning and in a non race day you can just take your time, plus it was so nice to be high above the valley heat too.   
happy summer running

There is a team of mechanics to give advice about a bike, usually there is a long row of people waiting for the advice though.

post:
Hey all,  The tour I was gathering info for with this thread so many weeks ago now is done now, so I thought rather than just disappear into the ether I'd touch base and offer an executive summary and thank you all again.   
The tour ended up covering a little less distance than I'd though initially but I did manage to tick off almost all the passes I'd set out to do and overall the trip was a smashing success!   
I started out from Zurich on the 31st heading south to Monza via Meiringen, and the Grimsell, Furka, Gotthard passes all which were open, though only the north (Hospental) side of the old cobbled Gotthard road was open. The other side being covered in snow. 
From Monza where my new friends at the   workshop were very welcoming helpfull and generous with their time I headed up to Lecco, Ghisallo and Bellagio to see the Madonna dei Ghisallo and nurse an aggravated knee with a couple easy days. 
Then a day spent getting up and east over to Tirano.   The route from Colico to Tirano being the only stretch I would look to avoid doing it again simply because it was boring as hell.  ..like stationary trainer miles. bleh. 
From Tirano the next day I headed up towards Bormio with Stelvio in mind but just could not ride  the mortirolo. not knowing when I'd next get a chance at it.. so up I went.  That was really hard. The first few km I wondered if I might wake up on my back with an oxygen mask and a crowd around me, but then I got used to the effort and the rest went really well if really slow. 
Back down to Grosio and on to Bormio and up Stelvio.  The Prato side of Stelvio was still closed, but I was so roached out by then I was actually relieved.  So, I headed back and down Umbrail to Mustair to call it a day.   That might be the hardest day I've ever spent on a bike. 
The following day, I headed back west via the Offen and Fluela passes to Davos and the next day just over to Klosters to be a tourist for a day before training it back to Zurich to prepare for coming home.   
Over the next week I'll be posting some pics and details of the ride at a blog in case it's of interest;     
Nevertheless, I'm very appreciative of the tips and links I was offered here and the other info gleaned as well.  You lot have an incredible country to explore.  A feast for the eyes, and the cycling / scenic opportunities are simply astounding.  I'm already formulating plans for another trip.     
..maybe with my 5&5 all-mountain bike to do overland passes. hmmm, ..would definitely call for a rotor size increase, but yeah. That could work..     
Anyway, 
Cheers! 
Mark

post:
The passes in the Vaudoise and Fribourgoise Alps are all very nice, although I would call them medium-sized rather than "big" because they top out at   1400 to 1800 metres altitude.    
Col des Mosses is the most accessible but the least fun - the road up from Aigle is normally a bit too busy until you get past the Leysin and Diablerets turn-offs. Doing it from the other side is fine, because you do the busy part going downhill, at the same speed as the traffic, but then it is not that long or hard.    
Doing Col de la Croix from the Rhone valley is the longest climb in the region; take the road up from Bex because it is much quieter than the one from Ollon.   
The nicest climb I've done in the area, and probably the hardest (over 1100 m of climbing in 13 km) is just north of Col des Mosses. It doesn't even have a proper pass name, but is normally referred to as "Les Agites" as far as I can tell. It starts one village north of Aigle, called Yvorne, and goes up to a valley that contains a military area and a reservoir. You can then follow the road around the reservoir to get to the Les Mosses area, or another road that comes in above Leysin, or follow the road down the river to Montbovon (the top section of which is now only open to cyclists). However, you can't go through the military area between around 9am and 4pm on weekdays, except during their break during most of July and August (but I'm not clear on the exact time and date restrictions). There's also a tunnel near the top of the climb that has restrictions to make sure that traffic is only going in one direction at a time. See more details on   (I'm the one who wrote the description and submitted the statisctics for it   ), this is the profile graph from that site:

Just wanted to let everyone know about some free fitness sessions that are being run over this summer on a Wed and Sat (sponsored by the Communes and insurance companies).    
Its called Urban training and its about using the city surroundings to keep fit. A bit like the bootcamp concept - so dips on benches, pushups in the park, lunges etc - but you can do it on your own or with some friends.    
All details are on the website -  
Here you need to subscribe and answer a few health related questions - all in French I'm afraid, but I managed with my basic french  Its limited to 20 participants and is run by a personal trainer.    
The workout is designed for beginners, so don't worry if your just getting started with your fitness, but also don't expect a full-on workout. You should at least come away with some new ideas.   
Please note:  I am not associated with the training, I just tried it the other day and thought some of you might be interested.  Happy training.

At 2.500 m they will hardly be yellow hiking paths but more likely red and white mountain hiking ones.   
If you actually mean, YOU have never got lost, that's fine. But I've temporarily missed the path quite a few times in my forty years of hiking here. And most people I know have too.   
I agree that it is fairly difficult to get completely lost in most regions, the paths are usually well-marked, but if the signs have been removed (the trees with the marking on are sometimes felled! or something has grown over the marking, or something is put in front of it; if the stripes are on a stone and it snows...  but in  mist without a map, a compass and an altimeter, it is really not that easy. Even here.

Hi Anthony,     You can join the Migros golf for CHF250, but you need to present them with a handicap certificate. Get your old club to email or fax it through to you.      The process of getting your Migros Card operates with typical Swiss efficiency....give them your handicap cert, they will then invoice you, pay the invoice and they will send you the card in the post.   
Migros Golf are based in Otelfingen ( ) so call out there and they will give you the form and other information etc. Once you have the card you can logon to the Swiss Golf Network and book tee times ( ). I think that there are 7 Migros golf courses in total, but not absolutely sure about that.

Hi Anwar,    
I highly suggest   this weekend. This Saturday and Sunday they have a nice program, open door for everyone. Worldchampion and Recordholder Kurt Nünslist will be there and will give 1 hour introductions from 10 am.

Just a short note: the fitness training is good, and extremely valuable - part of the success of the Rugby team is this fitness training, and they've been national champions for most of the past 25 years. They're understanding if you have trouble 'keeping up', as I sometimes do, but the important thing is to be in there and moving!   
So, for your first visit, rock up about 20:40 so you can be introduced to the equipment and some concepts ... but after that it's great to get into the water right on 20:00! Most of us (hockey players) do get into the warm-up, but some have jobs with late meetings that hold them up - part of the joy of working in companies that sprawl across time zones!
In case anyone hasn't seen it there is an online version which is heaps of fun... and FREE!

post: Stretching *after* running is the current wisdom these days. It's argued that your muscles have warmed up and are looser post-exercise and so you'll not only be able to stretch easier, you'll be stretching them further than if you were cold.

I've been running with Care Vevey Athletisme for nearly two years (although I struggle to get along to their winter runs). Their website with lots of information is   . I run with the second "groupe hors stade" which meets twice a week - Mondays up near Mont Pelerin and Thursdays in St Legier. The Monday run is longer and harder - usually about 75 minutes which includes around 15 to 20 minutes of reps. Each week we head out in a different direction, and it's nice to get to know lots of different paths and the scenery is obviously lovely! The group is predominantly female and quite friendly - I'm the only non-swiss runner, so conversations etc are all in French. If you're interested, the details for contacts are on the website. Unfortunately, I can't go for the next few weeks due to holidays and lack of childcare, but should be around a bit more towards the end of the month.

post: The lake road obviously gets you there fastest and easiest; the views are still very nice and the road is plenty wide enough so that the high traffic volume is not really a problem. The wine road makes for a nice ride with even better scenery, but is still reasonably busy in sections (I use the road going through Villars-sous-Yens and Lully to do the bit between Morges and Aubonne). If you want a real workout then go up Col de la Givrine from Nyon, into the Vallee du Joux, then back over Col du Marchairuz.

post:
What is all this about back ache and frame sizes etc?   
Once you have been in the saddle for four hours, your back will ache. Riding position is not your normal posture unless you are born something like Neanderthal Man.   
If you have raced competatively, you will know that you will actually often move your body along your saddle forward or back an inch to change slightly the muscles you use as you would pull up on your toe straps as opposed to pushing down on your pedals to relieve your muscles.   
Measuring all your body dimensions and using some table is not going to mean it is the correct frame, though might help.  Some of us have more rounded shoulders especially when cycling in a crouched position so I don't think all these measurements mean that much.   
The pain generally goes the more riding you do. perhaps you have not been on your bike for a while.   
I went out on an old mountain bike for the first time in two years and only rode 1.5 hours along the canal tow path for two days in a row (no suspension as that is for wimps) and I have had a back ache for the last three days so badly that I have been walking around like Neanerthal Man. I just put this down to my body not being used to it (plus back accident in 1998) and I am pretty convinced that if I had continued riding every day I would be OK.

I asked around at work for good gyms to join (I just moved to Zurich), and I work with several alums from ETHZ. They told me that this is a gym for academics in this city. They gave me the contact information, I called in yesterday and they confirmed that I could get membership just by showing them I have a University degree and that I am here in Zurich legally.   
The lady on the phone was a little unclear about the University degree part. Apparently the system in much of Europe (other than UK) is unlike the 4 year College + Graduate School system I am used to. She did enquire as to the exact nature of my degrees, including the institutions before giving me any details. She told me that I was eligible, and even sent me the forms!   
May be worth calling them at 1-632-42-10 before you go.

I was riding a 2006 Litespeed Vortex (6/4 Ti frame) and I bought a 99 Merlin ti frame (prior to the Litespeed purchase of Merlin) off eBay for $500 - it was going to be my rain bike.  I outfitted it with an old Ultegra group and found that my 7 year old ti frame with straight seat stays rode better then the new Litespeed that had bent seat stays and all sorts of fancy shaped tubes.  Then, to confirm the ride, I took a Serotta for test rides, and I became an acolyte of old ti bikes. So, I updated the group on the Merlin to a mixed Campy group.     
I haven't ridden a Moots, but it's sort of my holy grail of bikes.  But, I certainly understand the cost issue.  You might be able to pick up a vintage Merlin off eBay and build it up.  If you do, make sure it has Merlin headtube badge and Merlin stamped on the drop - a lot of people have taken Ti Sports frames and put Merlin decals on them, and tried to pass them off as vintage Merlins.     
You can strip all the decals off the merlin, buy a box of Scotch Brite pads, and after a few hours of polishing, you can have a brand new brushed ti finish.     
Enjoy finding that new bike - after riding, buying bikes has to be my favorite sport.

post:
I think this is the most recent thread with cross-country (nordic) related skiing info (last posts in December, although it extends back a couple of years). Since the Snowsports 2009/10 is primarily focused with the gravity-assisted type of skiing (not that there is anything wrong with that...) I was wondering (would like to propose) if a separate sticky could be made for nordic skiing information (say reviews of trails, links to snow conditions, where to rent/buy gear in Switzerland etc. etc.). It seems that it gets mixed in and is tough to find at times, but participation seems to be increasing both on EF and amongst the general population. Of course, the name of the thread would need to be changed and I'm not sure if that can happen or not (I'm rather new to the possibilities of the internet). So perhaps someone could advise me if this idea is not so prudent and I can begin a new thread and try to collect as much of the info from other posts as possible.   
I was personally out today at the trails in   and it was fantastic. It took about 2.5 hours from Zürich each way and requires paying an additional 8 CHF fare (return) for the Postauto from Sarnen up the hill. There were about 25 km of trails and they have both skating and classic, although for the most part these are separated from each other (which was nice). The nicest part was that the trails wind in and out of wooded areas a lot more than both Einsiedeln or Rothenthurm. There was also a lot of nice terrain change (more hills and dips). If you don't mind the time it take to get there then it is a great option.   
So I'm putting out a call for all of the other nordic skiers to throw out their favourite sports. It would be great to have a list of recommendations here from other English speaking folks.   
Please let me know if I should make a new thread and start accumulating info there.

If there is a cross-country ski racing club near you it might be worth inquiring there to see if they know of anyone who might be interested in selling some of their kit. Racers have a (rather expensive) habit of constantly upgrading their equipment, and it's not unusual that you can score a set of relatively new skis/bindings/boots in almost mint condition for an excellent price if you know who to ask.   
Given the relatively delicate nature of poles they are the one thing I'd make an effort to buy new. But I'd still wait until the end of the season to score some deals.   
HM   
PS-If you really do think that you're in this for the long haul, make sure you get skis that are appropriate for your height/weight/skill level. Long skis are harder to handle, so go for something shorter and with a relatively high camber (i.e. amount of flex) to make things easier.   
PPS-Zimmo's suggestion of season rentals is also excellent if you think you'll only be out a few times a season.

Where this a will there is a way.

Hey folks, thanks a lot for your responses! It's a relief to have a more complete picture, too.   
To answer a couple of the questions that came up -   
What the man did was essentially 1) take a stock boot, throw away its liner (well, not literally) and expand part of the shell using heat and a machine; 2) make a new foam-injected liner molded to my foot; and 3) make a supporting whatchamacallit inner-sole thing. All this based on some serious measurements ("stand on this computerized pressure plate... now make this motion..."). He also promised to correct the fit for free if anything was wrong with it - not only this season, but in a few years too, if needed.   
Normally, with a modicum of luck with rental boots, I used to easily ski for one day, a second day would become an annoyance, and a third day just too much trouble to be worth it. So short Saturday+Sunday ski weekends were quite doable, but real ski holidays would have been a waste of time. We'll see how I fare now in about 12 days.   
If anyone's interested, this is the place where I had it done:  . Though again with the caveat that I haven't yet tested the boots out for real, I can only say all the best about it.   
(Please be nice to me, and if you ever talk to him, DON'T mention me as a customer who was surprised by the price. It's a very easy kind of thing to misinterpret, and I don't want him thinking I had a complaint, because I didn't.)

post:
Both resorts are spread out into different areas. St, Moritz had Corvatsch, Corviglia, Lagalp and Diavolezza. The two main areas are Corviglia which can be accessed by funicilar from the town itself, or by Gondola from Celerina. Corvatsch is a bus trip away down by Celerina. I would not stay in St, Moritz itself its over rated and over priced. Celerina or Pontrasina offer much better value for money and a more authentic experience.    
Davos/Klosters is also a resort with many areas. Parsenn is the main area which can be accessed from both Davos and Klosters. Jakobshorn is the next largest area and is accessed by cable car from Davos-Platz. The other areas, Rinnerhorn, Pischa and Madrisa are all a bus ride from either Davos or Klosters.    
Davos is a little closer for you then St. Moritz, but I personally don't find the town as nice as the towns like Celerina etc. Klosters is quite a nice town to stay in, in the Davos/Klosters resort, but also a bit more exclusive and expensive.    
In terms of variety of terrain for skiing both resorts offer a lot of choice. I find the towns in the Engadin valley a little more charming then those around Davos, but I don't think you can go wrong with either place.

Quote: Niranjan       For the majority of trails, I find it more efficient to move on my normal hiking shoes (and thick pants/gaiters come in handy if you are sinking too much).          It just depends how much is too much. When I sink in up to my knees (often if the surface is partly frozen the snow 'gives way' quite suddenly) I find walking to be too much like hard work! So I prefer to use snow shoes and sink in a lot less.     Quote: Niranjan      BTW: why should "the snowshoe users may not be happy when winter hikers make great holes with their walking boots." How does it bother them           If several hikers make large, deep holes close together, the snowshoes sink in at quite an angle instead of lying flat on the snow. The path being only two snow shoes broad, to avoid this hole, I have to go into the deep snow beside the track. The first person up makes the track in the deep snow of course, but if I can follow someone else, I do. This reasoning probably won't satisfy you, but don't forget that not all of us are young fit males! I suggest we continue this discussion when you are nearer my age - say in thirty-five years time!

post:
Hi guys,   
am a personal trainer from Zurich I have just seen your dialogue and have some information which might help additionally. This is a good recommendation with the sand bags (= plyometric training with additional weight). 
But I would recommend not to train plyometrics every day and not with the same intensity. 
If you combine strenght training with plyometric training (using stretch-shortening cycle with jump serials, power moves etc.) you will have best results. A weekly shedule could look like this -  
it is not recommendable to traing plyo and strenght training for same muscle group on the same day to prevent inuries.     
strength legs low int. + upper body high int plyo     
 upper body high intensity strenght + legs low intensity plyo     
rest     
legs high int. strength + upper body low int plyo     
upper body low int. strength + legs high int. plyo   
Also, work on jumping and landing technique with balance and coordination training ( e.g. balance or squats on instable surfaces like a rolled mat or an aero step) and train on proper surface, preferably shock absorbing like grass, rubber mats or suspended floor.   
hope it helps, 
have a good day,    
Jens Baltrusch

Don't know about Nuun, but Isostar brand hydration tablets and energy gels are sold in most COOP, Oschners, Athleticum stores, among others.   
As for backpacks, you might hear some recommendations such as Salomon vs. Raidlight, bottles vs. bladder, backpack vs. waist pack etc. Ultimately though, it is purely a matter of individual preference, running style, race needs etc. just like shoes.    
If you are thinking of using it in flat city marathons, probably a waist belt pack with a large pouch should be ideal because the waist is the most stable part while running.    
For longer mountain races where you need to carry a lot more gear, a backpack may be required.   
Not seen a good selection in Zurich; buying online may be a good option which you can check through the manufacturers' websites. Either way, as you already know a bobbing backpack can be such a kill-joy even if you don't get chaffed skin, so I hope you find one that your body likes soon

post: Thank you.  Is this rink in or near Zurich?

I drive to Lenzerheide. But you are correct you can get a Post Auto from Chur to the talstation for the Rothorn Gondela. The Rothorn Gondela station is on the Rothorn side of the pistemap about half way along the length of Heidsee. You can buy your ticket there and then take the local bus to any of the other entry points to the mountain. I recommend Parpan or Fadail. Alternatively if you want to get on the mountain quicker... I am pretty sure it is possible to get off the bus in Churwalden buy your ticket there and then take the lift up towards Statzerhorn directly from Churwalden. This should save you about 15 to 30 minutes depending on ques and waiting time for the sports bus at the Rothornbahn.   
It is possible to ski/board from anywhere on one side of the valley to the other. but my personal recommendation (particularly if you snowboard) is the are between the Statzerhorn and Scalottas lifts. There are plenty of varied pistes here for all levels, the traverses are well enough constructed that you don't always have to be on one edge as a snowboarder and there is a reasonably possibility for nipping off between the pistes in search of some powder.

I got a great pair of skis at the Cristallina sport rental store in Engelberg... downstairs they have a few ex rental skis for not much at all. I asked to buy the ones I had rented and they made me a ver ygood price.     
now just need to find boots...

An article on " " has just been posted on BikeRadar.com, a major UK-based cycling website, which is run by the publishers of several cycling magazines in the UK (e.g., Cycling Plus, Mountain Biking UK). They seem to love the whole route network and the services offered to cyclists here. In fact, the article almost sounds like it was written by the tourist office (which is unusual because that site is usually very objective and doesn't mind being critical). There are a few things that I think could be improved about the national bike routes, but I guess when you put it into the perspective of what is offered in other countries like the UK, then it is idyllic.   
They also posted a nice photo gallery of pictures taken while riding in Switzerland, here are a couple of nice ones:           
BTW, it is not too cold to ride right now - I just did over 100km yesterday in temperatures between 0 and 4 C; just get the right clothing and you will be fine (if you're riding on the road, then a bike that can take slightly wider tires and full fenders also helps). This is a beautiful country to go cycling in, even in the winter

post:
you can have a good fit for your boots in the city.   
there are 3 ways to have your boot fitted:  
1- the insole, it's heat fitted and costs about 90 CHF. it takes 15-20'.  no need to go to a ski resort for that.  
2- heat or pressure fitting the shell. Usually done for free when you buy the boot at the store. Takes some time (overnight clamping for pressure fit) and sometimes a few visits, so it's better to have a shop closeby. 
3- inner shoe fitting. The inner shoe is replaced by a special one filled at the shop with foam. Costs from 250-300 CHF. Is not a precision technology, and requires a good artisan, so it might (or might not) take back and forth testing. A skilled artisan for this job is extremely difficult to find. But the mainstream bootfitters such as Stöckli, in St. Légier, do the job well enough.    
Phone Aubert sports, Schaefer sport, Yosemite or Passe-Montagne (excellent for telemark) to check if they do one or the other of these fits.   
teleHO !
Also, check out the alpinegolf website for further ideas.     =

post:
You might not find typical Round Robin here but you can enter the tournaments at different levels throughout a year, if this is what you want. You can get more info here:   In order to enter the competitive tennis and get some points in classification, you need a licence CHF60 a year (2 x CHF30 summer and winter season). This is usually organized by club which you join in April/May, but it is too late for that now and you need to wait for the next season to start. What you can do is apply for such licence from   anytime of the year.   
The amateur torurnaments are played all year round and the leagues are played only in summer season. It is usually a draw with Tableau set for seeded and unseeded players. If there are less than 4 players they make sort of Round Robin to play against one another, but only when number of players who entered is too small. In league the captain decides who plays against whom in home/visitor team.   
Pricewise, IMHO the tourneys are quite costly between CHF70-CHF80 (winter on indoor carpet) and CHF50-CHF60 (summer on clay court).   
Hope it helps a bit

Further to my previous posting about underwater hockey (" "), I am delighted to report on our first overseas trip since the Zürich club came into existence. Text and photos by Jos Visser.   
For further information on this most breathtaking of sports, that can be played on an equal footing by men, women and juniors, please see the Underwater Hockey Switzerland website,  , or simply message me.   
Martin Reed 
Underwater Hockey Switzerland             
Parma is a lovely city a bit south of Milan. It has cheese, it has ham, it has beautiful girls and, since this is Italy, it has beautiful boys. It also has an olympic swimming pool which is very well suited to playing underwater hockey. This very fact prompted about 200 people from all over Europe to come to Parma on Saturday 12 September 2009 to battle for the Parma Cup.   
Now this is a bit of a well-kept secret, but USZ (Underwater-Sport-Zentrum Zürich) has a fledgling underwater hockey section, led by former British national team player Martin Reed. We don't yet have enough players to field a tournament-strength team but we still wanted to compete and Martin pulled in a bunch of friends from other cities and countries in order to get a full team together. The resulting proud Swiss team consisted of: 1 Englishman, 1 Romanian, 2 Germans, 2 Americans, 2 Dutch, 1 Kiwi (New Zealand), 1 Columbian and 1 real Swiss person! Our goals were modest: score more than one goal in the tournament and Win The Party.       
Our first game against Genk (Belgium) did not go all that badly. We scored an early goal but were unable to keep the advantage and lost 2-1. The second game we played against the French national team under 19. They were very, very good and quite frankly we did not stand a chance. I forgot the final score but it was quite embarrassing.  The French team went on to play in the tournament final which they lost to Dordrecht (Dutch city team).       
In the subsequent games we improved our game but were still unable to win a match. This goes to show that in underwater hockey team experience only goes so far: We had two national team captains on our team (New Zealand and Germany) plus a fair number of very experienced players, but all this individual quality does not help a lot against teams that are coordinated and have their tactics figured out. It also did not help that NZ captain Lisa Thompson was recovering from a broken arm and was playing as a southpaw.       
In the final game (for 13th/14th place) we met the British Ladies Masters (over 32 years of age) team. This was our best game so far and the teams were evenly matched. We came to 2-2 and then a bad decision by an Italian referee did us in and the British ladies scored 3-2. Our appeals were unsuccessful and that was the final score. Incidentally, because of an oddity in the tournament structure, the team from Genk we played against in the first game ended below us in the final ranking!       
Fortunately due to the dedicated partying of Joëlle Meijer (NL) we did win the party and that gave us standing invitations to join tournaments in Rome and Ljubljana.   
- Jos Visser

Additionally, you will likely need to shorten the hydraulic lines to fit your bike, which will certainly require bleeding afterwards.    
In case budget is a topic of particular importance, I would mention Shimano BR-M 535 brakes. I picked them once as a spare brake, and am since then amazed how well and reliably they work for a price of 100Euro a set. Weight is  of course not the strongest feature, but the stopping power is no different to  XTRs on my other bike.  
A pair of budget Hayes HFX-9 were a disaster for me. Was almost happy when they broke down.  
On the contrary, was very sad when this year I cracked off the brake lever of a 12-year old magura louise. The mighty piece of german craftsmanship did not tolerate a silly fall.
Instead of weights, you might want to consider sandbags. Remember reading somewhere that US marines train with sandbags.

post: Erm I am not a Brit but I love running in the rain. Beats the hot sun!

You could always try looking for a mother and child gymnastics class - I do one with my 3 year old and she loves it.  It's not too strenous for the Mums, but it is exercise, and if you walk or cycle to the class it all helps.  Your local commune / gemeinde would probably have the information, or if you can make sense of their website, the FSG / STV should give you links to local clubs ( ).   
I'd also recommend buying a bike trailer - we bought a CTS Chariot when our daughter was 6 months and it's done literally hundreds of miles.  It's great for trips to the parks or shops, and also longer all-day rides.  Whilst you miss the close contact of the child seat option, it's more comfortable for the child in poorer weather and doesn't affect the handling of the bike as much.  It's certainly a great work out for you!   
I have run with my daughter in the stroller (we have a BabyJogger, which is good for running) but to be honest, once she got past 18 months it wasn't much fun.  On any sort of uphill I almost ground to a halt as the Jogger with her in was so heavy...  Perhaps it'd be better on a flat paved trail than cross country.   
Good luck with whatever you choose to do!

Hi guys    
i agree with all that is said here, the Ice bath theory is something I don't enjoy either as I used to have them some time ago, but it had to be done straight after a run to reduce the swelling of the joints and muscles and quickens the recovery time between runs.   
The oldest treatment I still think is the best is R.I.C.E. 
Rest, Ice, Compress and Elevate. Elevation is a great way after a run to drain the lactic acid that builds up in muscle areas and stop painful knots building up in muscle areas and the rest is to stop the damaged, bruised or bleeding tissue and will speed up the scar tissue replacement which in turn heals the damaged area.   
Nice to hear a few old friends on here, Basel Dragons running club has now gone over the 100 members mark and runs with between 35 and 40 people most sesions. W also had over 54,000 hits on our website last month for running advice and tips.   
Regards to you all.

post:
Good advice.... One thing to really watch out for if doing this is to keep your stomach really tight. (You should be doing this anyway) but if you do the overhead versions if there is any tightness at all in the shoulder area you tend to compensate for getting the hands up by leaning back. This makes your lumbar spine extend more then it should and could cause some problems.    
The tips are good. It really does up the effect for the exercise and focuses it a little more on the core then the standard versions, but may not be for everyone.    
BTW... as for core. Its importance can not be emphasised enough for any sport... but all the exercises I have described do actually have a core element to them too. This is why I didn't put more specific core exercises into the programme. I wanted to make it as simple as possible and something that people might do rather then decide it takes too much time. There are developments and add-ons that can be done at any time, but I think that is a good starting point given that we are at least 8 weeks from the start of ski season.

post:
You should search through the posts in the   of BikeForums for info on tandem panniers, and post this question there if you still don't find what you're looking for.    
Ortlieb are certainly the most waterproof, but are definitely only medium-sized, and are not cheap. As already mentioned, rain covers are made for most panniers, and in my experience that combination has kept my stuff dry in some pretty bad conditions. As long as you spend a decent amount of money then you should get something pretty durable - The cheaper models are normally lacking in terms of the attachment system and durability.   
Hopefully your tandem has a sturdy rear wheel - at least a 145mm wide hub and 40 spokes would be recommended for tandem touring. If you have less confidence in the robustness of that wheel, you may want to consider distributing the load a bit more evenly across the bike. Using a handlebar bag can give you lots of extra space (just make sure you don't have shifter cables in the way, but there are ways around that problem). On a tandem, you can also use a couple of frame bags. We have a quite large one that goes under the top tube behind the captain's seat-tube that we find very useful, we got ours from  , but hopefully you can find one in Europe somewhere.   in the UK carry a lot of tandem-specific parts and accessories, but I don't see that bag on their website. Plus, we sometimes put another smaller frame bag under the lateral tube behind the captain's seat-tube.       
Adding front panniers can get expensive because of needing another rack and paying for another set of bags, plus the racks are difficult to put on some forks (although never impossible, unless the fork is carbon). However, it is certainly an option that I would consider if my rear bags still weren't big enough or my rear wheel wasn't sturdy enough.   
There are also bags made to fit between two panniers on top of the rack - get a long skinny one so that it fits well, many of this type are too fat to fit between panniers because they are designed to be used on their own. Of course, if you're camping then that is the ideal place for a tent, so you can't use one of these. Here's a small image of the one we use with panniers, which comes from  :

If you don't get any personal recommendations, have a look through    
Aarau have a pool and a swimming club, so you could start there.

The Zürich Eighters were founded in 2008...hence the name.  On Sunday afternoon we play our last games of the 2009 season (our first) in Lausanne.   
To continue to improve through the winter and prepare for the 2010 season, we eagerly seek an experienced pitching coach.  As baseball-lovers know, pitcher is the most difficult position to develop, and as general coach of the Eighters I have reached the limit of my skills and experience when it comes to pitching.   
The team consists almost entirely of young Swiss guys (mid-twenties to mid-thirties) with little to no baseball experience until we began training a year ago.  Everyone is unbelievably enthusiastic, eager to learn and improve.  It is wonderful what these guys are doing for baseball in Switzerland.     
I was a walk-on last August and after unsuccessfully pursuing a few other coaching options through the 2009 season, the team's leadership installed me as coach 2 weeks ago as the American guy with the most know-how.  However, my know-how consists mainly of little league almost 20 years ago, a few softball teams in Chicago in my mid-twenties, and a lot of watching the MLB.  To this point it has been sufficient, but I could really use a hand.  Needless to say, it is difficult to find baseball coaches in Switzerland who aren't already associated with one of the many already existing teams.   
We train every Monday evening in Oerlikon, and once it starts getting too dark too early, not to mention too cold, we will move our training indoors to the KV Business School at Escher-Wyss Platz, also on Monday evenings.   
The pitching coach would not be expected to be present at each and every training, but motivation, enthusiasm and a good rapport with the team are highly valued and the more you include yourself the better.  Myself and one or two other players handled all the pitching responsibility during the 2009 season, but my goal is to familiarize every player with the fundamentals of pitching.  Lack of relief options has been a major handicap, and general knowledge of pitching techniques would (needless to say) also improve our batting.   
The position does not pay.  We are a brand new team and so far we have all paid our own way (league membership, players licenses, uniforms, equipment, etc) outside of a few nominal sponsors.  What we have to offer is a fun group of guys, and baseball baseball baseball.  This might be a really fun freetime option for somebody new to Zürich or to Switzerland.  It has been a great social and athletic outlet for me so far!   
German proficiency is not a must, but would be helpful.  I speak fairly well, and when the jargon gets too thick I will lapse into English, but the levels of English comprehension among team members is variable.  For a newcomer this would be a great way to brush up!   
If anyone is interested please respond to this thread and we can exchange information and discuss further details.  More information is available at   (team site) and at   (Swiss Baseball and Softball Federation site).   
Thanks! 
Ed Sutton

It just hit me that going over the great Grosse Scheidegg is not required to be "hard work" -- perhaps could take the post-bus up its eas side from Meiringen, then ride down the west side to Grindelwald and Interlaken. Or if you want to do   work, take the bus up only as far as Rosenlaui.   
Cheat. 
If you insist on riding every single kilometer, you won't have a story about how the official mail delivery vehicle had bike racks mounted on back, with a photo of your bike on the rack. 
You won't have a story about how bringing your bike on the famous Swiss train system wasn't as easy as people say.   
When you get back home, not many people are going to care exactly how much total distance you covered, or if you rode every mile through some regions they never heard of.  
They're going to be asking (or thinking) things like: 
* so did you see the Matterhorn? (north wall of the Eiger?) 
* do all the cows have bells? 
* how come there's no snow-covered peaks in your photos? 
* what was the cheese like?   
* castles ? Not what most people are asking of Switzerland. But the route posted so far goes right by one: The castle on the little island at the east of Lac Leman / Lake Geneva is was really great inside -- I'd say worth budgeting fewer km of distance to have time to enjoy and explore things like that.   
Ken

Well I did try it in the end........and I belive it's the first and the last time.    
I rode there the first day through the woods towards Uitikon, and could I find this place?.......even though i had a map with me it was no where to be seen, so hot and bothered I peddled home again.    
Then the following day, I decided to give my Navi a go at it, so stuffing my Tracer VP into my car (and it does fit in a Mk2 TT with just the front wheel off, as long as you put the passenger seat forward,) off I went.    
Well even with the Navi it was a pain to find, but in the end I did find it.    
Let's just say, it didn't live upto expectations.......The place is tiny and not very interesting at all.    
There are some man made trails, a bit of pump track and some jumps, plus a northshore (that I steared clear of as it didn't look that well maintained) but basically you could get around the whole thing in around 10 minutes or less.   
I didn't like at all, the tree branch lined artificial trails, and the pump track was just wrong - came away with a bad impression, and I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.    
I was there on my own anyway for around an hour or so, whilst I guess all other people were off doing some far more interesting trails.......   
Will definitely go further a-field next time to find something better.    
Cheers,   
Phil.

post:
A DH rig will definitely give you more freedom to fully explore the trails, but I expect that you could do so pretty well on a XC machine, too. I wouldn't be too concerned about shipping the bike. Investing in a proper box might be a good idea if you plan to use several times, but you do have to consider whether you have the storage space for a hard box. I've frequently used cardoard boxes from my LBS and not had a problem, although I haven't shipped my carbon fiber baby yet.   
As for slick tires and locked-out suspension making it a road-worthy machine, then certainly give that a go. However, the gearing and riding position may still be way off what you would get by having a true road machine. If you're buying brand-name bikes like Trek then buying in France won't save much money, and could cost more because they charge more sales tax. There are several online retailers in Europe where you can pick up a decent road bike for a good price, although these often don't have a wel-known brand and you have to be your own local bike shop with setting it up, fitting, tuning, etc. By September, they should start selling off last year's models at pretty good prices (10 to 25% off), particularly for brands who are making major changes to their line-ups for 2010. If I was you, I'd wait until I get here and search for something like that.   
There is currently a pro' road cyclist who is actually from Orbe - Danilo Wyss. I believe he is currently on the BMC Racing Team, who do most of the big races in the US.

New Schnuppercross date!   
Details here:

We want to start a Roller Derby league (ideally based in Zurich, but flexible) and need players who want to be a part of something new and exciting in Switzerland.   
We want to set up a league much like Stuttgart and many other European cities already have...       
We're looking for girls aged 18-whatever who want to be part of a team and part of learning a new team sport with a very cool group of women. This is a fun and full contact sport that we can all learn and share experiences together. The closest league to us right now is the Stuttgart Valley Rollergirlz, and they started much like this a couple years ago.    
Questions?  Good!   
I've never been on a team before.  Is this for me?  Probably... lots of girls have never been on a team until they join derby.   
How is this sport different? Attitude, Teamwork, Fun. We take on new names on the track, form closesly bonded teams, wear flashy uniforms, and then we sell tickets and play in front of a crowd of hundreds of cheering spectators. Anything we make goes directly back into training expenses.   
What is Roller Derby, anyways?  Check out our sister league at   or google (or youtube or wikipedia) "Roller Derby".   
Does anyone REALLY play this? In July the first European tournament will be held with 12 teams in attendance. In Canada and the USA there are hundreds of teams.   
What kind of people play this sport? All ages and professions and fitness levels can find a place here... Roller Derby attracts a very diverse group and binds them together like no other sport.   
Is this a real sport?  Are there rules?  Yes and absolutely yes.   
Check out the 400 league strong Women's Flat Track Derby Association.      
This sport looks hard! Do I need to be super fit or be a super skater? No. Just show up and we'll share skills with one another and learn and get fit together.   
Looks like fun, but I'm not a girl.  Can men play?  No - this is an all-female sport.  Men sometimes choose to become involved as referees, coaches, trainers, etc...   
If interested simply in learning more, contact us (Swiss Army Wife and Crash Test Ref) or message one of us using our facebook site...       
or E-mail us...   
See you soon,   
Crash Test Ref & Swiss Army Wife   
crashtestref (at) gmail.com

post:
Wheel size is pretty much always 26" and all the standard bikes you will find in the shops are that size. The exceptions to this rule are generally fairly specialised machines.   
Frame size depends on brand and type of bike. In my opinion you are borderline between what most manufacturers would term medium and large. You are the same height as me and I ride a medium frame. A smaller frame within reason will make it easier to ride more difficult sections of trail.    
As for bike type, it depends on what you want to do with it. If you want to just ride on nature streets and do non technical tours then a fairly basic hard tail cross country (XC) bike will do the job. The better quality of components will make the bike more expensive but also help it to handle more abuse if you decide you want to venture into more adventurous regions. The problem with XC bikes is that if you ride something that is a bit difficult it takes more skill to ride the bike. This is where Full suspension XC bikes or even All Mountain (AM) bikes come into play.    
All Mountain bikes are usually full suspension but more importantly they have a little bit more relaxed geometry which makes them somewhat more fogiving and a little less freaky to ride when the going gets rough.    
It mainly comes down to you, what you want to do and your budget. The Trek Fuel EX's and the Specialised Stumpjumpers (fully) are good middle of the road bikes that will allow you to do easy going day tours but are still capable of being ridden on almost any trail you can find. You could use these bikes as a starting point and then look at something similar from other brands or decide that it is too much/too little bike for you and go for a something else.

A. All you need is a properly fitted pair of shoes, a suitable sports bra (for women) and some comfortable sports clothing that makes you feel good.         A. Just a good all-round diet, with plenty of fluids and a slight emphasis on low-GI carbohydrate. Aim to eat 50% of your calories from carbohydrate, 25% from protein and 25% from fat. Only half-marathon runners need go wild with pasta.         A. Nothing ..(except cross-country skiing) burns more calories per minute than running. But don't forget to eat and drink enough to exercise at your best in the first place. You'll still win out.       A. The easiest way to make sure you're running at the right speed is to go with a friend and make sure you maintain 'chatting' pace - even when the going is tough you should still be able to get a few words out, even if they're just "how.. much.. further..my coach is a ****!"         A. If you're new to running, we'd call going from doing no regular exercise to doing a run-walk programme pretty good progress. Don't measure yourself against other people - if you're running or walking further, more often, more quickly or more easily, you're making progress. Improvements come in steps       A. Feeling a bit achy after running isn't uncommon. Minimize it by starting and finishing each run with a few minutes of gentle jogging or walking, and do some stretching when you finish your session. If your ache turns into a pain then you may need to ease up, or take a few days off running.         A. Whatever shape or size you are, the very fact that you are out there and getting fitter means you have plenty to be proud of. More likely than not, anyone who looks at you when you're training is envious of your get-up-and-go. Whether you're in the gym or in the park, hold your head up high.     Race day approaches!!!     Q. I've never been in a race before. What's it like?    A. It's fantastic! Busier and friendlier than you could imagine. Just don't be tempted to dash off too fast at the start - that's the most common mistake. If you start slowly, you could spend your race overtaking and moving up the field - what a confidence boost!      Q. How should I prepare on race day?    A. The golden rule is don't try anything new. Have a familiar breakfast (or afternoon snack, if it's an evening race), a glass or two of water or juice (try and stay off the beer), and make sure you'll be wearing shoes and clothing you're really comfortable in.       Q. How fast could I (should I?) go?    A. Most beginners' goal is simply to finish the race with a smile on their face. but if you need to calculate a goal in your training programme, break it down per kilometre and set your watch.     Q. What if I'm last?    A. Why not take a look at the previous year's results for your race? That way, you'll get a good idea of where in the field you might find yourself on race day. Even if you do come last, you'll probably still have a great time and get the biggest cheer going courtesy of the marshals, commentators and all the other runners especially if you run with a running club like the Basel or Zurich running clubs who promote themselves on the EF.     Keep on running     Running Man

I forgot about another important way to adjust the reach on a bike. First, you can move your seat forwards or backwards where it clamps onto the seatpost. However, this often only gives you an adjustment range of +/- 10mm. If you want a bigger adjustment, you could try changing your seatpost.   
Different seat-posts come with different amounts of 'set-back', which is the distance between the center of the post and the center of the clamp that holds the seat rails. This can range between about 0 and 25mm. I believe 20mm used to be quite standard, but now it seems that many seat posts, particularly for mountain bikes, have no/zero set back (i.e, the seat mounts directly above the post). Rather than adjusting your reach by changing your stem, you might be able to change your seatpost instead.   
When we got our new tandem, I was amazed by how short the reach was. The top tube was only 5mm shorter than on my single bike, which is the dimension that I had made my choice of frame size based on. Then I realized that the stem was 10mm shorter than the one on my single bike, and the seat post had no set-back, whereas on my single I had 20mm setback. Therefore, the reach was actually 35mm shorter, which is a HUGE difference. I couldn't comfortably hold the tops of the drop-bars, the only place I liked was having my hands grasping the very top/front of the brake hoods, but this didn't give me very much control. By changing the seatpost and stem I was able to quickly get it setup much better.   
However, changing the fore/aft position of your saddle to change the reach of your bike is not ideal because that should really be determined by other things. The old advice was that you should set the horizontal position of your seat so that when your cranks are horizontal to the ground, your front knee is directly above the front pedal. However, this rule of thumb (known as Knee Over Pedal Spindle, or KOPS) has since been heavily questioned, and there are several other theories. Keith Bontrager has a long essay on this on Sheldon Brown's website,  .   
I've never worried too much about the horizontal position of my saddle in terms of how it changes the effective angle of my seat-tube. I have always found a seatpost with 20mm setback to be quite comfortable, and have only adjusted the horizontal seat position to get the reach to the handlebars right. However, when my wife was recovering from knee problems, she played around with different seat positions to try to avoid any further aggravation in that area.   
EDIT: This all provides further evidence for the theory that the most important dimension of a new frame is the top tube length. Getting the reach right by buying the right size frame is the best way to do it. Getting the reach right by changing the stem will alter the bike's handling slightly, and changing it by altering the horizontal position of the saddle will affect the pedaling geometry. In contrast, getting the saddle height right can be done by raising or lowering the saddle, which doesn't affect too much else, making the seat-tube length pretty unimportant. In fact, after top-tube length, I would say that the head-tube length is the next most important measurement, because the head-tube length constrains the height at which you can put the handlebars, much more so than the seat-tube length constrains the height where you can put the saddle. Anyway, I'll stop babbling now.

Always run at a relaxed and comfortable pace. This isn’t the Olympics – it’s a lifelong fitness quest. To check your effort level, start a conversation with your training partner. You should be able to speak without gasping or feeling out of breath. If you can’t, then slow down.        Once you reach the magic 20-minute mark, build up to 30 minutes (then 40, 50 and 60). Don’t make the mistake of trying to get faster – don’t try to run your 20-minute course in 19 minutes. Increasing endurance is your first priority.  
Dont look at a watch or even wear one at first as you only compare yourself to your last run. This can be totally demoralising and the biggest achevement is you are out there in the first place.        I don’t have to re-tell the old children’s story here. Running works just like the tortoise-and-hare race. It rewards the patient with weight loss, steady progress, less stress, more energy and a host of health benefits and penalizes the overeager with injuries, burnout and the like. This isn’t a sport for sprinters. Be slow, not sorry.        There must be a billion runners out there, so don’t feel bad if you see someone who’s faster, thinner or smoother-striding. Running is your activity – make it work for you, and don’t worry about anyone else and enjoy it and feel good about what you are acheving.      It's good to start ith other peole going through the same thing as you and come and join us for a run on  , see the calendar.   
Running Man

Be very careful when using those high pressure water jets.   
Your bike could have many of the bearings being "non-sealed", like the headset and wheel hubs, or even the bottom bracket.     
Modern bikes and more expensive models have sealed bearings, others don't.   
You could wash away the grease on those bearings and to regrease them again you'd need to dismount the bike.

Hello All,    
Thought this may be of interest.    
I'm sure i read about this article a while back in Bike, but couldn't for the life of me find it the magazine, so I've been trawling around the net and managed to find it online.    
It's test data on various tires, and makes interesting reading.  
Here's how it works;    
RR - Rolling resistance - lower is better. Measured at 2,5 bar or 36 psi on a test roller with 50kg load   
Flattening height - puncture height - higher is better. Distance from which the tire flattens after being dropped from a certain height, it is dropped higher on each test.   
Thorn - puncture resistance using a metal thorn. A is the best.    
Cornering stability/ability - pretty self explanatory. Higher is better.    
Traction - Higher is better.   
Tire types/usage - AM All mountain, EN Enduro, CC Cross country, you get the idea.    
Will try and put these into a spreadsheet when I get a second.

To get back to the OP's questions, I have a few suggestions.  Note that I have not hiked most of these trails myself; I go later in the summer to be able to hike at higher elevations, over passes that are likely to be snow covered early in the season.   
Choosing three hikes in the Valais is as painful as having to choose   desert from the desert menu    
The OP is planning to hike in late May early June, so higher elevations are tricky, and in any case he writes:   So here goes! Whichever you choose, enjoy

My favorite was the ESP (Entrapment Snow Phone) feature: "Why not ask your buddy if hes comfortable, and has enough air for you to do a quick lap and hike back up to them. Go for it, Bra! is sure to be the answer theyll give you." Locate-and-shake was a good one as well. Nice writing.

If it's steel you "should", with a bit of luck, be alright as long as you're not spacing it too much.   
Couple of things to note though - it's worth checking the welds on the chainstay and seatstay bridge before going ahead. If there's any sign of cracking then obviously don't proceed! However if there's rust it might also be a sign the weld is degrading and could fail as you stress the tubing. On a Serotta you should be alright though unless the frame hasn't been looked after.   
Sheldon's advice is, as ever, good but I'd also suggest putting piece of timber along the length of the seat tube between the tube itself and the timber you use as the bending lever. This will spread the load over the length of the seat tube reducing the likelihood of denting it.   
Oh and be careful not to just bend the dropouts as you do it.   
Otherwise give it a go! ... or you could always instead try and source some nice retro components and build it up as it used to be!

Look at it on a proper map not the Piste map. I have traversed to the avalanche runout spot on skis from the top of the Totalp lift which also gets you to meirhoftalli. To say that there is a mountain range in the way is an exaggeration. There is a ridge which separates the two valleys, but you can access both sides from the saddle in the middle. The avalanche conditions can very easilly be similar in both places, and there are steeper slopes on both sides of Meierhoftali.    
Eitherway it was on a directly lift accesiblie off piste area on a resort where you are advising people to go.   
Edit: I will allow myself to be corrected. It is not possible to traverse to the release point from the lift I said, it is however possible to get very close underneath where the avalanche came down. It is still in the same general area, and not particularly good advice to be saying anywhere off piste is safe to those who are not in some way educated in assessing the risk level for themselves.

I never quite see the point of Davos Parsan, as this adds at least 15 minutes each way to the journey to ski the same area (unless it's Jakobshorn) as you ski from Klosters. Plus the run back down to Klosters must rate as one of the best in Switzerland and the Parsan run down is a steep and often icy black run.   
Pizol is not a major resort. But is a good 30 minutes nearer Zurich than Lenzerheide or Klosters (and cheaper), but unless there is snow down to the Rhine valley, which will likely be the case at the end of March, you need to take the cabin down...

Hi There   
I really reccomend you running with a group as you will get many different pieces of advice from many sources, the thing is you have to find the one that works for you.   
I would reccomend the Zurich running group that has been formed. I think they sound at your level. We have started one up as well in Basel from April 2nd for both beginners and 30 to 40 minute runners.  
I was a qualified British Athletics coach back in the Uk for many years and helped coach many levels from Internationals to beginners and the best advice I always give is run with a group, because you bond new friendships going through the pains and gains of your challenges.   
Regards   
Running man   
p.s. and also look at the runners world website back in England it gives lots of good advice.

Well our two kids have used Bobo's at Flumserberg and the Snowli school at Grindelwald. They've also had a few hours each with a private instructor at Flumserberg. IMHO, the Bobo school was OK but I agree with the comments about group size, especially at weekends it's very busy. The private tuition, also at F'berg, was very good but not cheap at CHF 170 for two hours. The Snowli school at Grindelwald was the best though with excellent facilities and a staggering number of blokes and blokettes wearing Swiss Ski Instructor red outfits. The children did a one week full day course at Grindelwald and I think this was the best tuition they've had. Both of them really enjoyed it and the teacher/pupil ratio was good. The facilities are excellent. 
The cost for two children for one week was around chf 800.

Salsa Lessons....   
I guess I can't help you, I never took lessons in Zürich or elsewhere, so I don't know who could be good or bad.   
However there are many teachers and schools, you could go and check for yourself if you like the style and price of the school.

post:
This sort of thing is not without precedent of course.  South Aftrica was banned from playing cricket in most countries because of the Apartheid regime (and some say Israel is practicing Arpatheid now....including Jimmy Cater).  And of course there was the 1980 Moscow Olympics and then 1984 LA Olympics which had all sorts of countries refusing to participate on political grounds.   
There was even some in the US calling for boycotts of the Beijing Games this last summer.  Steven Speilberg was pressured to withdraw from the Opening Ceremony organising job due to the Tibet issue.     
I wonder what would have happened if their was a major sporting event in Iran, Cuba or North Korea during the Bush years?   
I suppose it will always be impossible to separate sport from politics.

Thanks very much, much appreciated.

This is from the Rothorn, (Zermatt)  saw it from the cabin, but there was only one lonely snowboarder. Looked good, but it was not so near a piste that you could have crossed back. Are the rock areas visible and avoidable as you go down  ?       
BTW, for off-piste, I can recommend the first lift on to the left leaving the station below the Weissfluhjoch on the Parsenn, Davos. There are rocks intermixed, but clearly visible, its great to ride there and you are in sight of the piste, no flat spots. If you like steep, the left side of the piste, flatter on the right. From the left side, you need to cut back onto the piste to the right when you are still 300 meters from the lift, otherwise you'll have to climb back. The right side can be ridden just until you are above the lift entrance. 
This area is really great for "new" off-piste riders because you can explore this area gradually, and turn back earlier to the piste if the rocks or unknown gullys ahead freak you out.

If you are a Cross Country Skier or are looking to try it out, I can highly recommend to you 2 little side by side villages right next to Zermatt.   
They are Tasch (umlaut over the a) and Randa.  There are 12 km for classic or skating.  Tasch and Randa are typical Valais villages.  They are pristine and peaceful.  If you need some nightlife or shopping, Zermatt is literally a 10 minute ride away.  Trains run every 20 minutes so all 3 villages are very convenient to each other.   
I am also going to recommend an excellent teacher:     
Reinhard Zeiter 
Mobile 079 409 0389     
I use him as a teacher and I can say that his method is logical and each step builds upon the next.  In addition he explains why he is teaching a particular theory which is important in the learning process.   
btw, he also does mountain tours.   
Regards, 
Fraueli

We went to Francois Sports, out in Bremblens just above Morges. It's a huge shed-like place on an industrial estate, specialising in rental stuff. ( )   
A season's rental of skis, boots, sticks and kids' helmets cost around 800 CHFs; that's for 2 adults and 2 young kids. We went first thing on a Saturday morning some time in November, and only had to wait a few minutes for someone to sort us out. He was amazingly thorough, and it took around 1.5 hours to get everything just right for us, fit of boots, best type of skis for beginners, all the bindings adjusted for height and weight, etc. We were delighted with the service.   
kodokan

Assuming that the T lifts at Flumserberg work like the T lifts everywhere else in the world, the answers are "easy, two, and yes (but make sure you can move out of the way quickly when you do that)".   
Just look at how the others do before you try getting on one (make sure to point your skis in the right direction before you grab hold of the anchor, and avoid getting hit by one. Better let one or two go than fall over the first thing you do).  Try not to zigzag when going uphill, and be a bit careful when you're getting off so you or the anchor won't hit anyone else when you let go of it.   
When in doubt, ask for help.  You just need to do it a couple of times to figure out how it works.  And trust me, there's always someone nearby who's a bigger newbie than you are

Great suggestion Kate. 
We picked up a pair the other week and have found them a very good (tough) work out. I still prefer my roller skis for general cross country training, but the fact that the skikes have a brake and go off-road, make them very versatile and much safer. Perfect for people who have not skied before.   
Beware - you will get a very good, all body workout. Its not the same as cruising along on the roller blades. I guess that's why I like them.

In an effort to keep off the winter weight and get fit/stay in shape, a group of us are training and running the Barcelona marathon March 1st.  It is rated as one of the top 15 marathons in Europe.  Plus, it'll be warm and sunny there!   
A gourp of us will be training bi-weekly together in the Rolle, Morges, and Lausanne area.  Wednesday evenings and saturday mornings.  (Although the days may change)     
Now, no need to be a steller athlete.  Couch potatoes are welcome.  Only one person in the group so far has run marathons before.  Running a marathon is not ony great exercise, and an accomplishment, when your in a group and supported, it's great fun. I just got back in town (Zurich) so apologies for not responding sooner.  I'd be up for some training or racing but there aren't many events in Switzerland!   
As for organized trail runs, I'm not aware of a central site that lists them all.  Compared with the US, trail running in Switzerland doesn't seem to be as big an organized activity (in Boulder, Colorado -- as a contrast -- there are trail runs and ultras nearly every weekend!).   It's a shame as there are thousands of trails and beautiful venues, just not many organizations making it happen.  I have lots of long running routes through the Glarner Alps, Mythens, and Luzern area (it's where we hosted Untamed Switzerland this Spring:  ) if you feel up for a day on Pilatus, Stans, etc.     
If you're looking for an accredited trail run to earn points towards qualifying for future races, I think there's one in Soll, Austria in the next couple weeks that's well established.  It's too far for me to travel to, but it might be worth it to you.
There's already a   in zurich. Or you could do a search for "spinning".  If you can't find what you're looking for, do post your question in the above-mentioned thread.

post: 101 looks really cool, mate.

I've windsurfed on lake zurich less then a hand full of times. In a word its terrible. Exactly as Abfab says, gusty inconsistent wind that shifts all over the place.    
Unfortunately, Föhn is pretty much the same. Urnersee is where all the locals go and I've heard so many people speaking of epic Urnersee Föhn sessions. I've sailed a good few times in Urnersee now with Föhn and have been very dissapointed. Yes it gets insanely windy, but the quality of the wind is really bad. 45 degree windshifts and 20+knot changes in windspeed out of nowhere. Add that to a waterstate that is as confused as I have ever seen anywhere in the world and it makes for a challenging but not neccesarily terrible enjoyable sail.   
Aegerisee in Föhn is quite a bit better, but you need quite a strong one to get all the way up there.    
Best conditions I have had in Switzerland are either light Thermic with a 6.8 and 110l board in Silvaplana or  really strong Bise on Lake Neuchatel (3.7 and 80l board) Bise is much more consistant then Föhn and it is around the right time of year for getting it about now!

post:
I've found three other options on Chain Reaction.        
I bought a Be-One road bike off CRC and have been really happy with it. I reckon the bike was good value for money for what I got and I have been happy with the bike so far. This one seems to be marginally better speced then the GT, so personally I would think about this one. The advantage of the GT is you can probably find a shop in CH somewhere and go and sit on it to see how it fits. This bike like the GT will be quite cross country orientated but will do you quite well for day tours out in the alps too.       
This bike is more a trail bike. It has more suspension travel on the front and appears to have a more relaxed geometry to make you feel more secure on technical decents. If you really want to ride technical trails and put this above all out speed then this could be a good bike. I don't know much about the brakes and the components are around the deore level in the shimano range. Seems like a good value bike for all mountain riding to me.        
A little more expensive, but a bit better speced then the others. If you can afford this and want an XC bike I would go for this one. You may be able to find a dealer here where you can take a test ride too which would be a plus before ordering.    
If you want an XC bike and can afford it I would get the cube. If you want an all mountain/trail type bike the Sarecen could be a reasonable bike.    
I will make a small disclaimer that I have never ridden any of these bikes and am just giveing a gut impression based to the specs given on the site. Google might be your firend to get extra info on these bikes. I know it helped me when I was ordering my road bike from CRC.

Other fun hikes in and around Zurich:    (the old moat): start off at where the Sihl passes under HB (platform 3 side), follow it to the first bridge on the Bahnhofstrasse side, walk down the steps then simply follow the moat all the way to Bürkliplatz.     : grab the 7 tram to the Zoo, pick your route from the yellow signpost and get trucking.     : take the 13 tram to Meierhofplatz (direction Frankenthal) and hike up the hill. Walk the ridge to Zürichberg/Zoo.     : take the S4 or S10 at HB to Giesshübel, walk back across the bridge over the Sihl, follow the Sihl upstream to, e.g. Leimbach or Adliswil (where you can take the funicular up to Felsenegg on the Albis ridge) or get the S4 back to HB.     : tram 14 to Triemli/S10 stop Triemli, walk up the hill (Hohensteinweg) to the Panoramaweg (recognizable by the globe lampposts) bordering the Üetliberg forest. Walk all the way to Albisgüetli where you catch the 13 tram downhill to the city. If you like to be in the forest, walk up another 100m, there's a road running parallel to the Panoramaweg.

I moved here to Egg about 6 weeks ago and am looking for someone to run with for about 45 mins - 1 hr  once or twice a week. I'm over 40 and overweight  , so not looking for any Ironman-type performances, just a companionable plod and motivation to get out and about. Any takers?

So we all agree. High intensity endurance gives the most bang for your buck. I have always thought that most running plans are too slow & high mileage. If you are going to run and you're not getting out every day then make it count. Warmup, 20mins fast then warm down. Or if you're headbanger like me, leave out the warm bits. Do fast/slow if you must, but I doubt that it raises the metabolism any more than my method. I, at least, could get pretty decent results (35 minutes for 10k) off about half the mileage that the running magazines recommend. And my weight has increased 2kilos in 20 years.

It is important not to buy a cheap bag as they tend to fall apart.  Eastport, Jansport, Salwa, and other brands are good.  I really beat up my Jansport and it takes it very well.   
Also, look for many divided chambers in the bag.  It always stinks hwen that one thing you want is way on the bottom of your one large compartment.

Hm most people here seem to have a different approach from me. I take the usual Dutch approach which meaning I have non of that expensive 'special' cycling or sports gear.   
What works best for me in winter is a cheap windproof fleece winterjacket which I bought at vogele. Under this I wear a simple T-shirt and that's it. It is cold the first km but after that I am fine. Considering trousers, I wear normal jeans when cycling. This stuff works for me also below 0, I've gone on cycling trips during which the water in my bidon frooze   . My cold spots are toes and fingers...   
My only consession to winter is that I ride around on spiked tires (bought from veloplus) which work great. My cycling to work route takes me through the forest, the dirt roads don't get salted or anything so the tires 
are really necessary. I wiped out a few times every winter before I had these tires, never since.   
Just keep on cycling and change your clothing as the temperatures get lower and lower. This allows you to slowly adapt your clothing and it gives you a good idea of what you need to stay warm.

I've seen cricket often being played at   in   on  . There is also a baseball field, football fields, tennis courts and running tracks.

If you are certified to sail in another country then send your certification to the national governing body in your country and ask them to issue a HOCC (Helmsmans Overseas Certificate of Competency). You may get away with your certification as it stands but officially you should have the HOCC as far as I am aware. It also depends on what you qualified in, if you qualified in a dinghy then they may not cover you to sail a 30 foot keel boat.
We'll be looking for the same for our 6 year old in Nyon also once we move there later this summer so keep us posted if you find anything.

Heather

In Yverdon you will probably get strong Bise a few times a year (maybe 5 or so). Water/Air temperature totally depends on the time of year. Bise appears to blow strong enough to windsurf more in Autumn. This means that water temperature can be anything from 22deg or more in September to less then 10 deg at the end of November. Air temperature is always cold in Bise.    
You will also get a few Southwesterly days a year (Maybe 5 to 10) that that are sailable on Lake Neuchatel. These days are a little warmer and can happen at any time of year. During the summer with a strong SW storm you could have 20deg air and water.       If your used to surfing warm water, cold water SUCKS! I grew up sailing in cold water, and it was a shock to the system when I moved home from Maui after living there. Modern wetsuits are very good and they make conditions bearable. When it is really cold it takes some time to get used to the feeling of wearing booties etc during the winter. You will get used to sailing in cold water, and spending some extra money on a good wetsuit is definitely worth it. t will make your days sailing so much more comfortable.

Maybe we should find out some background info first before giving loads of advice!   
Bike for transport or Sport? 
Distance expected to cycle? 
If for Sport, Road or Offroad? 
If offroad, Nature Streets or Singletrails?   
If You are just looking for a bike to potter around to the shops and stuff over short distances, then there is nothing wrong with M-Budget bikes.    
If you are biking for sport then it is well worth spending some extra money and avoid the budget grocery store bikes like the plague.

This community seems to have quite a few cyclists (both road and mountain), a small number of climbers, and very few hikers.  Or maybe hikers tend to be more solitary?   
I will be hiking in Switzerland during late July and August, but my plans are pretty set at  this stage.   
I can, however, point you to some  .  I would suggest that you order them online (free!) as I have found the PDF versions rather grainy.  The Tours brochure may be the closest to what you need, as it describes a very large (20+) number of village to village (using huts) tours; some of them are way beyond the 3-4 hours you are seeking, but I believe that others may fit your needs.   
Each of the lateral valleys in the Valais has its tourist office, and most organize a "Tour du Val de Whatever", with special rates for the whole package (or, in many cases, parts of it).  You will find a list of tourist offices, with their web sites, on my   page.   
I spend most of my time in the Valais, so cannot help much with the rest of this wonderful country!
