I had a great day out around Schaffhausen last weekend. Get hold of a bike at either Schaffhausen or Kreuzlingen and follow bike path 2 between these towns. This path is well sign posted along the entire length. Full details of all the bike paths in Switzerland can be found by purchasing the veloland guide from   ( I think). It is about 50kms of flat bike path and quiet roads. You basically follow the shore of the Untersee until you get to the Rhine, passing Stein-am-Rhein which is worth a stop and look and finishing in Schaffhausen ( or vice versa depending where you start) with the many beautiful buildings to be found there, and just to finish in style the Rheinfalls at Neuhausen. I just have a townbike so speed was as fast as I put in effort for and it is dead flat and really relaxing ride. The trip is through fields , old hamlets with water fountains and either starts or finishes by the water, and there is always the train along the whole route if you really can't be bothered putting in th effort. 
Thoroughly recommended

Yes, they have public courses. 
The green fee is about 60 CHF for 18 holes. If by any chance, your husband works for Nestle, he can get a membership at the Lavaux golf course for CHF 2'300 / year. 
If you have a handicap card from just about anywhere in the world, its good enough to be allowed to play at most courses. 
The one in Lavaux is about a 25 minute drive from Vevey, and the one close to Montreux is about the same distance on the other side. You can even go to courses in France less than an hours drive away and cheaper than the ones in Switzerland. 
You can rent the clubs sure, but I think that would be quite expensive and I would recommend that your bring your own clubs.

At least on the snow reports for cross-country skiing, the reports tend to be overly optimistic. There are often bare patches in the middle of the trail despite them claiming to have a very good base, which must have been measured at the very best spot rather than an average. They will also generally claim that the overall conditions are "good" / "gut" when I would classify them as marginal or poor. About the only useful and accurate statistic seems to be the amount of trails open.

Do bare in mind that there is no central federation at amateur level, so if you have an idea as to where you will live, go in the Regional Verbaende section and choose the Verband you'll be part of and contact them.   
I'm pretty sure you will have no problems finding games to ref, there is a chronic shortage of refs.     
The football season in the amateurs league goes from early August until early December, then winter break, then it restarts early March up until June. There is not that much indoor football I'm afraid.

I think the best advice so far has been to split the lessons up. Once you've been told how to stand, shift your balance and string together some plough (or parallel) turns, depending on your aptitude it will take you one to ten hours of practice before you're comfortable getting from top to bottom of a baby slope. There's really no point paying for lessons during this time, you just need to practice. 
When you're happy with that, get more lessons to show you parallel turns, carving, better technique etc and keep practicing what you learned. 
When I started, I had a week of all-day group lessons and I would have been better off having a one hour lesson each morning and practicing on my own for the rest of each day, which is effectively what we did, except we ended up paying an extra 5 hours each day for the teacher to watch us practicing what he taught us that morning.   
Obviously if you're rich, by all means have permenant lessons. Even pros have coachs and can benefit from lessons, but I'd say the most cost effective way to learn is to have an hour or two of lessons and follow up with private practice till you feel ready to learn more.

I enjoy skiing and boarding in equal amounts.  While I do own my own snowboard kit, I have always (in the past, at least, I've decided to splash on some ski boots in the end-of-season sales) rented ski boots.  I've tried on boots that were uncomfortable initially, but quickly "bedded in" and were fine for the rest of the day.  Conversely, I've tried on boots that seemed fine inside the building, but nearly had me in tears after less than an hour of skiing.   
Snowboard boots, while softer, are no panacea either.  I've had more than enough of them cause me pain.  Even the boots I own, for the first two days I used them, were agonising - but once they'd moulded to my foot (or my foot had moulded to them  ) they were (and are) like wearing a pair sneakers.   
While I would encourage anyone to try both skiing and boarding, I must echo the sentiments already expressed that "bad boots" should not be a reason for changing from one to the other.  If ski boots are painful, then you either need better fitting boots, or you have very weirdly shaped feet - and in the latter case snowboard boots are unlikely to be much better (although you might get lucky).   
It's also a bit like buying a motorcycle helmet, in that certain brands have certain shapes, and some people just don't fit into some of those shapes.   
CS

Hi, we at   in Zurich will feature an 'Easing Back Pain' workshop at our yoga studio on May 27th, 2007. This workshop will be taught in English.   
This workshop will bring you the knowledge, understanding and practical techniques to enable you to reduce and manage back problems.   
We usually recommend our clients when they indicate to have back problems to consult with a nearby osteopath. Like this we can rule out that there is any clinical condition causing the back problem.   
The good news is that research has shown that only 10% of all back pain needs medical attention ( x-ray, operation, etc., yoga probably not appropriate ). In 90 % of the cases no medical attention is required and can resolve completely through yoga.   
You are more than welcome to drop in to our studio and ask for me so that we can assess what the best way forward is for you; If a group class would or would not be suitable for you, if you need a private program etc.     
Best wishes, 
Andre

The sections of unpaved surface on the cycle routes that I've been on have accounted for less than 10% of the distance, and have all been pretty tame - of the wide, curshed gravel variety. I agree, a racing bike with 23mm tyres, an aggressive riding position, and a stiff frame wouldn't be ideal; however, I'm happy on them with a touring bike with 28mm tires, drop handlebars, strong brakes, and a cushy steel (cromoly) frame. Fat tyres and suspension would be complete overkill for the parts that I've found, although you could certainly use that kind of bike quite happily.

Anybody entering the run this year?, been trying but the reminder service only comes up.

Engelberg is only a little further away from basel that feldberg. The skiing is adequate for beginners and learners (although in my opinion not so good for intermediates, where really long blue runs & would be better. The reds & limited balcks are fine for a day out). Do remember that Engelberg, like Saas Fee, is north facing. This means you don't get to ski in the sunshine & it can be several degrees colder than other villages/resorts & inadequate kit would be a mistake!     
You might like to try Davos or Klosters. They're not too far away, certainly when compared to Zermatt & french 3 valleys. You'll be lucky to find hotel accommodation at short notice though.   
My best find is this website:  . It is in english and has lots of well thought-out features for finding ski resorts & providing information about them.   
Where ever you go, get there early (not later that 09:30) or you could end up parking a long way from the lifts, and kit hire will can take a while - Oh, and pre-book lessons!   
have fun!   
JC

post:
Hey Noogie,   
Sorry but I can't help you with the climbing... my fear of heights stops me with that!   
But as for the snowboarding, pretty much every resort has a snowboard school. You can just decide where you like to go and then check out the school there. If you are going to head away for a few days it leaves more options open to you. Traveling back and forward from Davos, Laax or Lenzerheide can be a bit tedious, even though thats what I normally do myself. If you do decide to go this route I can recommend the Primus school in Lenzerheide. I took a one off lesson there once and they were really good.    
If you are looking for somewhere that is easy day trip distance from Zurich then most people here on the forum will probably recommend Flumserberg to go and learn. Personally I find it very cold (sun only really shines on one piste), and the lines at the lift can be horribly long. I learned from scratch in Hoch-ybrig,and despite one or two anxious moments on the first day it worked quite well.    
You can check out the website myswitzerland.com for  , they allow you to select the resort by region and it gives you information about the resort as well as a link to their website.    
If you have anymore questions just ask.

The people we did our avalanche course with... ...and some powder days are called   there are dates for the avalanche courses on their website (all in german). They also do powder days, if you register with them they will send an email when ever there is a forecast for snow, the first good day after the snowfall then they organise the powder days. They cost 135CHF for the guide, any extra expenses such as lift ticket you need to pay for yourself. If you don't have an avalanche transceiver and necessary equipment you can also rent it from them. This is my tip for getting in more powder then you ever dreamed of. Most of the day trips they do are close to Engelberg, so they should be worth checking out.   
If you have any other questions just ask. I hope this helps.

Marathon generally refers to MTB marathons in my humble experience.    
My girlfriend and I just ordered new bikes at a LBS in Zurich on saturday. This guy is offering 15% off bikes ordered before the end of December which is quite a good discount by Swiss standards. He will build you a semi custom bike, pick your frame and he will get a build kit together for you to build the bike you want.   
I personally was looking for a bike that I could do marathons on, but could still take to a bike park or do some alpine descents on without shaking my back teeth on, so managed to put together a 12.5kg bike with 140mm of travel (A little heavy for a pure marathon bike, but I just want to participate not win!)  Most marathon bikes are hardtail or have only 100mm travel at the back I think he could put something together for you without a problem.      is his website, I can highly recommend him. My girlfriend bought her first bike off him, and now we have just ordered two shiny new bikes.

An alternative, if you speak the language and want to get involved into this sort of stuff on a regular basis, would be to contact your local swiss alpine club to see if they're offering any courses:   .

Telemark: Norwegian for "Wait for me at the bottom". 
Randonnée: French for "Can't do telemark turns".   
OK, there are two ways of skiing in the back country, often going uphill as well as downhill under human power.  Each method has its true believers who believe that the other method is evil. post:
Had swom for a couple of times at Oerlikon. During weekdays seems pretty crowded, and even in the "Tempo" lanes you get people nearly with no clue how to swim (i.e. it's impossible to train properly). After 8.15/8.20pm the situation gets better (tempo lanes gets occupied by proper swimmers) but you don't get much time afterwards. Around 8.45 they start to modify the lane disposition, then get rid of some of them making a big pool-lane and leaving the few lanes available for some scuba course. Oh-oh, I said 8.45, weren't the pool closing at 9pm? Maybe I don't remember exactly... will check tomorrow.   
This was on Tuesday, maybe other days will be different. But I've got the impression that it's possible to swim decently only on lates during the weekdays.   
Situation is completely different on Sunday. Yesterday have been there from 4pm to 5.30pm, it's been beautiful. An entire lane for me, have been able to achieve 10x100 front crawl with 30" rest (next step is to reduce rest from 30 to 15"). Then some mixed sessions, ah, I have to buy a tablet to grip on for doing legs, there are no tools available for the free swimmers in the pool.   
The pool is pretty clean and well made. I have to admit swimming on a 50mt pool makes the difference, as you don't have the possibility to give you the sprint every 25mt and gain some distance relaxing the muscles, but I think I will get used to these 50mt :-) It also passes quicker to do the 100mt as it's just 2x50.   
Now waiting for somebody to join me.       
Fabio

Which RYA licence is it... there are many schemes.   
Dinghy Dayboat Scheme and Cruising Scheme are probably the ones you are talking about. If you have level three in the dinghy dayboat scheme or day skipper in the cruising scheme then you are eligible for the Helmsmans overseas certificate of competency which will allow you to sail overseas.    
Depending on what you want to rent or sail you may not need one. I was told that to rent a boat on the lake in St.Moritz that I could just come pay my money and go. I didn't try this yet but it will be interesting to see!   
My guess is if you want to rent a dinghy they will probably let you off after checking out out. If you want to rent a keelboat or cruiser you will probably need to show some paperwork.

Hoochie! They're called Zelttuch or Militärblache in German. The official liquidation shops of the army are:           
Dick's Army Shop must buy them there, too (probably in large quantities). So it's second hand material. Both of the above shops have their offers online but not in English. You'll have to download some PDFs to know all the offers. Swiss Army hoochies are not rectangular but square.   
Although every hoochie is second hand, there are some differences in age: The hoochies with red spots in the camo pattern are the newest. Hoochies without red spots that have a camo pattern on both sides are older. Some of the older ones are marked with yellow paint at a corner, this is the lowest quality and means that they are leaky. But I don't think they're on sale anymore.
A good friend of mine is an English Golfpro working there.

post:
I am just putting together notes for an article about swimming areas 
on  . Tell me if you think I should add something. 
Graham     
PS In Monbijoustr, find the Titanic building, 
and come and visit me sometime. In the summer I  
often go for a lunchtime swim at Marzili from 12 to 2. 
Ask for me at the reception desk.  
Graham Tritt     
--------------------------------   
City open-air swimming areas   
Marzili 
The place to be and be seen, for the young.  
It's no more the "meat market" of bare flesg 
that it was a few years ago, there are typically five thousand people  
on any hot day. 
Nearby under the Monbijou bridge, two beach volleyball courts. 
A walk up the river, a kilometer to the Schönau bridge (cross to reach the Dählhölzli zoo) 
jump in and float back down. For good swimmers only, and always go with someone  
you can trust.   
Paradiesli private for women, and an area at the other end with 
river pool which in principle is private for the men. 
European style changing rooms - open to view, so your hanging clothes are  
reasonably secure. A private room for women to change, men don't need this, of course. 
On a few evenings there is openair cinema, but the choice of movies is pretty limited.      
Ka-We-De, 
next to the Dählhölzli woods and the Zoo. 
A large shallow pool, which in the winter is an ice rink, and  
a smaller pool which is the only place in Berne with a wave generator. 
Excellent with children, there is a 60 meter slide. There is an entry fee here.     
Eichholz, in Wabern, follow signs to walk ten minutes from the No 9 tram station. 
There is an occasional bus 29. Nearby there is a large park for recreation  
including grill areas. The best place if you want to stay long in the evening. 
Swimming is in the river, on a warm day you can float two kilometers down to  
Marzili and walk back.     
Weyermannshuus 
A large pool, more than a hundred meters across, 
the best location for families with small children.     
Wylerbad, in the northeast, a short walk from the new Wankdorf railway station. 
A large swimming pool, a diving pool, plenty of room for sunbathing, 
good for families.     
Lorrainebad, a pool built on the Aare riverside, river water only. 
Reached by a walk of ten minutes from the Lorraine quarter, 
it has a a good location for sunbathing (FKK area).     
Surrounding towns 
It is worth making a visit to each of the pools, you will see which  
you like best.   
Köniz Weiermatt, newly renovated, a great area for family and young, 
with water slide. Expensive for Bernese (5.-), near bus line 10.         
Muri, pleasant and relaxing, with pool and river sunning and swimming area. 
Cheap for residents, it is a long walk from public transport   
Belp - river pool on the Aare, picturesque natural setting, 
a five meter diving tower. 
The only public transport is the Airport shuttle which stops nearby, 
but it is a perfect stop on an Aare bicycle tour.   
Ostermundigen, on the east side under the hill, 
excellent for families, with slide.   
Hirzenfeld, a pleasant location between Bremgarten and Münchenbuchesse. 
It has minigolf range and tennis courts, and the longest slide (88m).   
Münsingen - a large and friendly area offering lots of sports, 
next to the Aare river.     
Further away 
Strandbad Thun, pool and lake swimming,  
A half kilometer away, near boat hire, tennis courts, and the stage for musicals on the lake 
 there is a little island where you can barbecue and swim.   
Aarberg, on the Postbus Berne to Aarberg, or a 10 minute walk from the railway station.    
Murten, a large hall and an open pool, water slide, volleyball, and access to the lake. 
Nearby on the lakeside promenade (in Muntelier) there is also a large open area where you can swim   
Biel/Nidau 
A very nice pool on the side of lake Biel. It is also possible to swim in the lake for free 
from a park at the Neuchatel end of the town.   
Lyss 
A great park area, with openair cinema in the summer.   
Worb - four pools including one for diving pool, sport and grilling area.   
Kerzers - close to a rail station, and next to the Papiliorama butterfly and 
bird paradise ( )    
Also Kirchberg, Uetendorf, Spiez, Steffisburg, and other towns.      
And it is worth a trip to  
Schiffenensee betwen Fribourg and Murten (camping and minigolf) 
Faoug and other lakeside  
beaches on Murtensee - Sugiez, Motier, Muntelier 
Burgseeli in Goldswil near Interlaken 
Estaveyer le Lac (with waterskiing) and Portalban on lake Neuchatel     
Schwarzsee, Lauenensee,  
Aquaparc in le Bouveret Valais

thread: Aerobic Classes not at a Gym

post: That is a great site, Thanks a lot.
Thx. I have mailed you directly. D

hi there,   
you can avoid the weight machines, that isolate muscle groups, altogether and still build muscle. All you need is a squat rack, a swiss ball and some dumbells. I would stick to free weights. This way your body will have less support and therefore will have to work harder to stabilise itself during the exercise. More calories burnt off!!   
As a beginner you will build up muscle and neural adaption quickly   
Remember to stop immediately once you feel you're not performing the exercise perfectly. Otherwise it's just bad information for your muscles.   
Cardio and Weight Training: Perform these on separate days if you want to bulk up. 15-30 mins of cardio will release glucocortocoids, which are stress hormones. These are catabolic which means they break down tissue and prevent additional muscle tissue being formed. As with the weight training do 5-10 mins of one type of cardio and then switch. Keep your body guessing.   
Nutrition: Very important as previously mentioned. The way the food reacts in your body is not because of any intrinsic ingredient in the food. It's due to the metabolic balance of your body. The rate at which your body burns carbohydrates (Glycolysis) and proteins and fats (Beta Oxidation) will depend on your genetic make up and your environment.   
I recommend the book How to Eat, Move and Be Healthy by Paul Chek. Pretty good stuff in there and easy to follow!

post:
Hi All,   
I was in Scuol (Engadine) for boarding on Wednesday and Thursday and thought I would give a little info for those wondering how the snow is now there has been a fall.   
Piste conditions were very hard pack, with only very rare (and small) ice patches, so ideal carving conditions.  Off piste was mostly non existant as it was very windy on wednesday and so the area is hard blown.  In a few accumulation places there is powder, but shallow (<20cm) uneven (fast changes from hard pack to ~50cm deep in little gullies) and quite hard underneith, not icy though.  An exception is one fantastic patch (traverse as far as possible from the top of the high T-bar to the right), includes 2+ walks over rubble, but then there is a full powder slope that pops back out onpiste without walking (or pushing if you ski!), its hard in places but mostly a nice 50cm gradient from the hardpack base to fairly good powder near the top.  There was a thin crunchy cap on it in most places, but nothing serious...   
The talabfahrt was closed as they are cosntantly making snow there (maybe open this weekend?), but we gave it a try and with the exception of one small area with lots of grass and rubble coming though it was a good run to town, but don't take your new skis!   
so general - if you like good hard pack for carving on piste Graubunden looks good at the moment...   
Andrew

Basel Stadt Hash House Harriers Run #144    Sunday, November 12th 2006 @11:00    Untere Rebgasse 10, Basel         Take tram 8 to Claraplatz, leaves from Basel SBB every 8 minutes. Meet at hare's hutch, Untere Rebgasse 10. Ring doorbell "Steven". This will be an A to A run.    
Do note the day (Sunday) and earlier-than-usual start time. After the run we will move on to a nearby restaurant (known as the On-Inn) for refreshments.    
You will need jogging gear for the run and perhaps a change of clothes for after. Bags may be left at Hare’s Hutch.    
Normally we provide a drinks stop during the run plus refreshments at the end before we head to the restaurant.       We normally take a small fee - about SFr5 - (known as "Hash Cash") for the club funds and to reimburse the hares for the cost of providing flour and drinks. Virgin runners do not pay anything. You pay for your own meal at the restaurant.    
For more info, check the BSH3 website: -         The Hash House Harriers is a running/drinking/social club which was started by bored expatriates in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia in 1938. ("Hash House" is the nickname of the restaurant/bar to which they retired for food and beer after a run).    
Hashing is based on the English schoolboy game of "Hare and Hounds"; a Hash is a non-competitive cross-country run set by one or more runners called hares. The hares run out in advance of the other runners (the pack of hounds), and set a course marked by white flour.    
We welcome people of all running ability from "none at all" to top marathon runners. If you are not a runner you are welcome to stroll along.    
We endeavour to make our trails child and pushchair friendly making for an ideal family day out.    
We get people from all walks of life attending and it is a great way to make a few friends – especially if you are new to the area.    
For more general info about Hashing check this article.       
Cheers, 
Nick

For a normal adult 1-3 kilo fluctuations in weight can be due to a number of very natural things, such as water weight, your body retaining more nutrients in response to your increased activity level, etc. etc.  Keep up the exercise and don't forget- weight is just a number anyway; if your body feels and looks better to you (but that number doesn't change much), then what you're doing is a success.
